name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the joint debate on: – the report by Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing an Entry/Exit System (EES) to register entry and exit data and refusal of entry data of third country nationals crossing the external borders of the Member States of the European Union and determining the conditions for access to the EES for law enforcement purposes and amending Regulation (EC) No 767/2008 and Regulation (EU) No 1077/2011 (COM(2016)0194 – C8—0135/2016 – 2016/0106(COD)) (A8—0057/2017), and – the report by Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) 2016/399 as regards the use of the Entry/Exit System (COM(2016)0196 – C8—0134/2016 – 2016/0105(COD)) (A8—0059/2017).

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: speaker. - Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank all the actors involved, especially Commissioner Avramopoulos, the Maltese Presidency, all the shadow rapporteurs and also the legal services. The European Commission launched its final legislative proposal in April 2016, after preparing the ground in 2013 in complementary fields of study, pilot projects, budget projections and studies of different alternatives, such as biometric data or the architecture of the system. The legislative task is addressed because technical gaps have been detected in the management of the Union's external borders. Currently, the external borders are controlled by border guards who verify the authenticity of passports and visas for those nationals of third countries who want to enter the European Union for 90 days in a period of 180, but there is no procedure to control those who, once the authorized period has expired, remain in European territory irregularly. Thus, our Regulation establishes a centralized management and control system, through which the authenticity of the travel documents of third-country nationals is verified with the registration of alphanumeric data, biometric data and information on the date , the time and place of entry and exit. A calculator is also created for the actual calculation of the 90 days authorized. The objectives of the Regulation are twofold: first, to improve the management of external borders and prevent irregular immigration and facilitate the management of migratory flows; and, secondly, to contribute to the prevention, detection and investigation of terrorist crimes and other serious criminal offenses. This second objective is also crucial, since it will help to detect criminals with multiple false identities, as was the case of the terrorist who attacked the Berlin Christmas market, which had entered and left our borders with fifteen different identities. But access to information on entries and exits by the police authorities of the Member States and Europol will be under strictly defined conditions. This is essential because the Interinstitutional Agreement guarantees full respect for human rights, such as those related to privacy, the protection of personal data and the principles of necessity, proportionality and legality. To guarantee this, the European Data Protection Supervisor will be responsible for supervising the data processing activities of the system. In addition, the central entry and exit access is created, which is the technical support of the eu-LISA Agency - its manager - under the supervision of the European Data Protection Supervisor. And, in addition, there will be a website where passengers can check their period of stay. The data retention period will be three years for those passengers in good faith and five years for those who have exceeded the legal period of stay. I would also like to highlight the territorial scope of the system, which are the external borders of the Member States that apply the Schengen acquis and also those countries that, although they do not apply it, have passed the assessment. I am referring specifically to Bulgaria and Romania: this Parliament has defended from the beginning the need to include these two countries. And I want to point out that, of course, as soon as possible, there will also be Croatia. For this, it was necessary to give passive access to the VIS to Bulgaria and Romania, and it was voted by an overwhelming majority in the last plenary session. Ladies and gentlemen, interoperability between the SES and the VIS is also necessary so that the system can verify that the visa with which you are trying to enter the European Union is a legal and authentic visa. Three years after using the system, the Commission will make an assessment of its use. Finally, I want to emphasize that the Regulation will enter into force in 2020 and, to reach that date, many procedures are necessary that from the point of view of implementation must be fulfilled - we are talking about tenders, contracts, program development, tests, etc. . In conclusion, I believe that it is essential that we approve the Entry / Exit System today and not later. Why? Because it will improve the identification and authenticity of travel documents and, therefore, we will more easily identify criminals with false identities; will replace the sealing; we will know in real time who has remained at our borders irregularly; we will better protect freedom of transit in the Schengen area; it will improve the facilitation of entry and exit - that is, fewer queues - and will contribute to more protection and better management of the Union's external borders. In conclusion, it will enter faster and safer.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, our debate today, ahead of the vote, is inevitably on an important priority, for, as we all know, it is linked to Schengen. Preserving and strengthening Schengen is one of the Commission’s – and my personal – priorities. Schengen is a great achievement of European integration. As Mr Díaz de Mera García Consuegra said – and as I have repeatedly said many times in this Chamber – we need a unified Schengen, which should include Bulgaria and Romania and, soon, Croatia too. In order to ensure that the Schengen area of free movement is sustainable and secure, it is essential that we manage, protect and secure our external borders effectively and that we have full knowledge of who is coming in. It is in this spirit that we have proposed the Entry/Exit System. Its overall objectives are to improve the management of external borders, to prevent irregular migration and to facilitate the management of migration flows. It will enhance cooperation and facilitate information exchange between our Member States. I would like to express my thanks to Mr Díaz de Mera García Consuegra and the shadow rapporteurs for their hard work and for the agreement reached with the Council. This new instrument will bring several urgently needed improvements. First of all, it will enable us to monitor better the rules on short stays. The Entry/Exit System will calculate the duration of third country nationals’ authorisation for short stays in the European Union. It will alert border officials if a third country national is about to exceed 90 days in any 100-day period – for example, if someone makes several trips to the European Union. The Entry/Exit System will also check that the duration of the stay corresponds to the visa issued. Second, the Entry/Exit System will reduce the time needed to cross the border and will reduce the workload of border guards. The Entry/Exit System will allow Member States to automate most data and information—capturing steps as well as data verifications. Visitors to the European Union will benefit from process accelerators and self-service systems. For the border guards it will mean more time to focus on the most important parts of the border-check assessments. That is also why the Schengen Borders Code had to be amended. In addition, Member States may also create national facilitation programmes on a voluntary basis to further facilitate border crossings of pre—vetted frequent travellers. The compromise proposed describes the conditions these programmes must meet.  Third, as the Entry/Exit System will record travel document identity data, including biometrics, this will improve the detection of document and identity fraud and therefore increase security. Fourth, this system will support the competent authorities in combating terrorism and serious crimes. When necessary, these authorities will be able to access data in the system if all strict conditions are met. Lastly, the provisions on data protection are aligned to the new data protection framework and to the rulings of the Court of Justice. The current text includes all the necessary data protection safeguards. The coming into force of the legislation will be timely, so we can rapidly start to develop the system and get it up and running by 2020 at the latest. I am looking forward to the debate and I thank the honourable Members for their continued constructive shaping of European legislation in the area of border management.

name: Barbara KUDRYCKA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! Commissioner! We all know how important it is to return to the full functioning of the Schengen area. I often say it - it is one of the key symbols of common Europe and the great success of integration, our success. We cannot miss it. That is why today I congratulate Agustín Díaz de Mera on his report, which is another building block in the so-called Smart Borders Package. By ensuring the registration of every crossing of the EU border by third-country nationals, as well as the registration of their biometric data, we are eliminating the pre-existing gap in ensuring better protection of the Union's external borders and ensuring our security. This is a huge step forward. Importantly, the entry and exit system allows access to the visa database and vice versa, and this will reduce duplication of information and ensure the consistency of data on people crossing our borders. This will also help shorten border procedures. Our European openness and hospitality have been abused by people entering the European Union with malicious intentions, including members of criminal or terrorist organizations. The new system will allow us to protect against it more effectively. Systematic registration of entries and exits will also facilitate the identification of such persons and their manner of movement. What is extremely important, this system does not force us to give up the values ​​and freedoms that constitute the essence of the Union, above all a secure Europe, a Europe without borders. Of course, our joint work on strengthening Schengen continues, we are continuing our work on ETIAS, strengthening the mandate of eu-LISA and waiting for the European Commission's proposals on the interoperability of databases. The effectiveness of the new databases, including the reliable operation of the Entry and Exit System, will depend on their maximum use and full integration, including by being able to search them simultaneously. Therefore, I would like to congratulate Agustín Díaz de Mera once again. Today we are closer to achieving this difficult balance between freedom of movement and security for Europeans.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Thanks to the rapporteur, Agustín de Mera, for his excellent cooperation, including to other shadow rapporteurs and teams. We have more than four years of hard negotiations, exchanges of views and field visits behind us. We have before us one of the most difficult, technically and politically sensitive dossiers as well as one of the most financially difficult projects that we will introduce in the European Union in 2020. Border management is thus Europeanized and adapted to the needs of the 21st century. The journey has been very long and we did not agree with the rapporteur in many respects. I am still deeply concerned that the main purpose of the new technology will not be to manage and facilitate border crossings. Increasingly, the fight against terrorism seems to have become the main purpose. The talks were mostly held on the basic premise that any passenger traveling to Europe is a potential criminal or terrorist that we must prevent from entering. Despite the often difficult situation in speeches, we in the group of socialists and democrats managed to prevent the worst in the text of the regulation. Shorten ... We managed to establish an important dividing line between categories of passengers, shorten data retention time, we managed to further restrict access for law enforcement and cut costs. However, despite Parliament's calls, there was little understanding for greater protection of the privacy of individuals, for a single system for non-Schengen countries and for the abolition of separate visa agreements, which turn the basic purpose of recalculating residence in the Union upside down. Under great political pressure from the Member States, we are introducing the Schengen acquis into this system, I can say, which is also considerable chaos. I am sorry that the power of argument and reason in the current situation in Europe and the rise of populism has largely been replaced by the argument of misunderstanding and power. We run the risk to some extent that the quality of legislation is also replaced by quantity. Unfortunately, there was no ear in Parliament for further consideration. What particularly burdens me these days, and I honestly admit, is the July decision European Court of Justice that the agreement between Canada and the Union on the transfer of passenger data infringes fundamental rights.Under the agreement, the information would be kept for five years, which is no longer in line with the needs of the fight against terrorism.Unfortunately, we did not remove the doubts about data retention in this compromise, which is on the table.Therefore, the Socialists and Democrats propose with the amendment that we shorten the data retention period for bona fide passengers to 178 days.This is a sensible move and I urge colleagues to support it in the vote at noon.Smart borders, colleagues, will only be smart if the measures are proportionate, workable and, above all, passenger-friendly.(The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8))

name: Milan ZVER
text: Question asked by raising a blue card.- I would just like to ask my colleague, my dear colleague Fajon, whether this is a relatively negative view of her personally, or whether this is the position of the Socialist and Democrat parliamentary group.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: The answer to the question posed by raising a blue card.- As I mentioned in my speech, my parliamentary group has always supported the introduction of an entry / exit system, entry / exit from the European Union.We have managed to provide some positive elements, but the introduction of this system is to some extent a risk, because it is becoming primarily a system, a mechanism in the fight against terrorism.Above all, I want us to be reasonable, to have proportionate technology that is primarily aimed at the goal.This makes it easier for passengers entering and exiting the European Union (the President cut off the rostrum) and at the same time safer borders.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, there are no internal border checks in the Schengen area. Therefore, the external border is a common concern for all Member States. We must have an effective way to monitor who comes in and who goes out if we want to prevent illegal immigration, cross-border crime and terrorism.  At the same time, the number of legitimate travellers into the European Union keeps growing. With the tools that we have now, more security means longer queues and more waiting for the bona fide traveller. The Entry/Exit System (EES) is one answer to this challenge.  The EES is not a political project. It does not change the rules that concern entry, immigration, asylum or repatriation. This must be made clear. It is a technological update, something that brings our border management into the 21st century. It is a tool that helps us to enforce the rules that we already have. The EES should have been in place before, and as a precondition to, the abolition of internal border checks.  There has been much political opposition to the EES over the years, very often based on misconceptions. I truly hope that those who want Schengen to survive in the long term, who want a safe Europe and smooth travel flows, support the outcome of the interinstitutional negotiations. For the ECR, it was particularly important that law—enforcement authorities have reasonable access to the data stored in the EES and that data retention periods are sufficient for the system to benefit legitimate travellers on the one hand, and to make life harder for those who do not respect the rules on the other. We regret that the Registered Traveller Programme was not included in this proposal.  Finally, I want to thank the rapporteur, Mr Díaz de Mera, for his great professionalism, patience, determination and constructive approach.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra, for his open and very cooperative attitude. He was always seeking the broadest majority, and he defended Parliament’s mandate in an impeccable manner. Thanks to our common work, we improved the text proposed by the Commission, making a clear distinction between bona fide travellers and over-stayers and lowered the data retention period for bona fide travellers.  The Entry/Exit System is an important and truly European project aimed at strengthening security at our borders and ensuring systematic and reliable identification of over—stayers. At the same time, it is reinforcing internal security and strengthening the fight against terrorism and serious crime.  My Group welcomes the text as agreed in the interinstitutional negotiations and will vote in favour of it in plenary. However – and this is my personal opinion – this legislation has a big impact on the fundamental rights of third—country nationals travelling to Europe, especially when it comes to the extensive data retention period. I believe that we should be very careful when designing a system with such a broad scope. We, as legislators, should make sure that the fundamental rights acquis is respected without relying on the ex—post check of the Court of Justice, which I believe will come back negative in this case.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, this text is the first part of the “Smart borders” package, a whole program. This new border management means new digital files, new connections and more data and, in particular, now, palm prints and facial images. Initially, these texts were intended to facilitate border crossings for the 50 million third-country nationals who travel to the European Union each year. In the end, it is first and foremost, as the French authorities have just written to us, a tool to identify people in an irregular situation, via an automatic alert system signaling any exceeding of the authorized stay. It is about promoting returns and therefore expulsions. I am not satisfied with the way we worked on this text which, under very technical appearances, hides a heavy political reality. Under the guise of a legitimate right to security, we are going to increase the access of law enforcement forces to sensitive data, including in cooperation with third countries, and perhaps with Sudan, as we have just learned. of the French government. Certainly, some safeguards have been put in place, but they are insufficient and fall far short of the principles of proportionality and necessity as defined by the Court of Justice of the European Union. On these benches, we reject this bunkerized Europe, which flouts its own values, which plays with fears, and makes a very small part of those who migrate to Europe scapegoats, in defiance of international texts. This headlong rush forward will not solve anything. It serves very specific industrial interests and, as we see, election after election, it lays the groundwork for nationalism, populism and the far right. After the Council and the Commission, Parliament is sinking into it. The awakening is likely to be brutal. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162 (8) of the Rules)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – It seems from your speech that you seem incredibly uncomfortable with monitoring and understanding who it is who is entering Europe. If this is the case, I wonder: in your own home, would you open the doors to anybody without knowing who they were? Surely you need to know who is coming, why, how long they are going to stay and what their purpose is? Is this not just a natural thing, that people all over Europe would legitimately ask for their politicians to be pushing for them? (Applause)

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: "blue card" response.- Thank you for this question.On these benches, in particular, it is very easy, very often, to mix the extremes.You have just demonstrated that between extreme right and extreme left, there is a very clear difference.No, I am not afraid.No, I don’t open my door to everyone, but I watch who I bring in and I don’t need to question human rights and data protection in a systematic and pervasive way.

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, of course we need to know who is coming into our European Union, into our Schengen Area. But what do we have to do for that? We have to check their passports, and that is exactly what we are doing. We have a system, the Schengen Information System (SIS), in which – if it worked perfectly – we would have information about every suspicious person, every risky person, and at the outer borders of our common Schengen Area there would be checks against every traveller, and everyone would be checked. We would know who is coming in. If this system worked, no doubt we would have a better, more secure environment in our European Union. What are we doing? We are not fixing the system, which is not working because some of the Member States’ authorities are not thoroughly working with the system and feeding information into it. At some of the outer borders the checks are perhaps not working, yet we are building a completely new database – a database which does not focus, like the Schengen Information System, on risky persons or on suspicious persons, but one which just retains the data of completely irrelevant and innocent travellers – travellers like businesspeople, travellers or tourists who are coming to the European Union. We are welcoming them, and now are registering them for up to four years along with their sensitive personal data, their biometrical data, but without any suspicion and without any risk. Not only is that unnecessary because of the Schengen Information System, it is also not necessary to check visa over-stayers. If you really want to keep track of visa over-stayers, you need to know not only that there is a visa over-stayer, but also where the visa over—stayer is. But with this system you do not keep track of any visa over-stayer in the European Union. You just know that they have not left. There is no added value in this system. It will cost EUR one billion – that is the estimation of a study of this House. It will be an unnecessary collection of much information about travellers who are completely innocent. In July, the Court of Justice ruled that the Canadian authorities, in the case of PNR data, are not allowed to retain the data of travellers longer than the time of their travels in Canada. They have to delete the data after the exit, unless there is a risk or a suspicion. What we expect from the Canadian authorities with regard to our citizens, we should also respect with regard to citizens of third—countries like Canada. We propose to limit the collection to 181 days, which is the longest any non-EU national can stay in the European Union, and after that only on risk or suspicion. We hope that you will vote in favour of that to make a legal proposal here.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, the proposals for an Entry/Exit System using biometric data is not an unreasonable one on the face of it. The US has got a system and Britain has got a system already, and it is not unreasonable for European countries to want to have their own, similar systems. This proposal is for the Schengen area, of which Britain is not a member, so technically it will not affect us – but in reality it will. When Britain leaves the European Union – when that happy day arrives – then we will actually be a third country. Biometric data on our citizens will be gathered and will be shared with the EU’s Member States and its crime agencies. This biometric data can be accessed by all EU countries, as well as by those crime agencies. Some of those countries are deeply and institutionally corrupt and untrustworthy. The EU has been building its legal institutions and crime agencies for some years, and a few years ago I published a short study which explained how that could easily develop into an EU police state. UKIP is not opposed to countries having biometric data systems, but they should be under the control of national governments, and they should only be shared with foreign states where we can be reasonably assured that that information will not be misused. We certainly cannot say that about this system.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (NL) Mr President, somewhere along the way, the European Union has become the problem of the solution. In my LIBE Committee you see the future of the EU appear: a litany of laws that undermine the sovereignty of member states and emphasize the sanctity of the EU. The national parliaments will no longer be about anything at all: not about monetary policy, not about social policy, not about privacy, not about criminal legislation, not about migration, nor about who can and cannot be in their country. The entry-exit system now presented is a very good example of this: Member States will lose their freedom to control the external borders and a system of scanners and databases will be introduced instead. Several goals have been formulated, including combating terrorism and serious crime. Did that not go well before Schengen? In the new system, although tourists' passports are scanned before they are allowed into the EU, terrorists who arrive illegally by boats can pass through. So how does this help? Moreover, the perpetrators of the attack always turn out to be known to the secret services, but they were simply not arrested, because yes, we also fail to figure out how to deal with Islam. And crime, yes, in the Netherlands is increasingly the result of itinerant gangs that are given all the space they need due to the lack of internal borders. So why is this better? Who wants this? The new system should also help against illegality, because the computer knows at some point when someone has stayed longer than is allowed. But illegal immigrants do not leave at all. They are also not expelled. We have no solution for that either. So why then this system? Madam President, this system is not going to help against terrorism. Nor does it help with crime. It does not help against illegality. It does cost a lot of money. And more importantly, it again takes away power from Member States, power to tackle problems.So, Mr President, it seems clear to me that we will vote against.(The speaker addressed a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Mr colleague, can you please tell us, on three specific points, how we will lose sovereignty thanks to this system?You also criticize the way in which the secret services do not cooperate.Your previous speaker here said that we should have control over the Member States' own data.Isn't this protectionist way in the UK an obstacle to exchanging this information?

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: "blue card" answer.- Yeah, interesting question.How do you lose sovereignty if there is a European law that states that member states must be members of Schengen - at least the new member states, and we are also compulsory members - that states that we are not allowed toexternal borders, that there is now a system that prescribes how that should be done and in what way, and who it concerns, and how long it should be preserved, and when it should be thrown away?It seems to me… this summary alone indicates that we are not about anything anymore.That seems like a loss of sovereignty to me.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Madam President, the implementation of the "open vineyard" policy is reflected in the blood of unsuspecting innocent people and the sowing of fear among the citizens of the Member States. Internal enemies and opponents of nationalism are plotting to overthrow Europe against the rights of Native Europeans and to the detriment of national security and the rule of law. The more politicians promote national leveling through the policy of open borders and uncontrollable tolerance, the greater will be the moral complicity and criminal responsibility in the slaughter, literally and figuratively, of the peoples of Europe. The immediate resumption of control at the Union's external borders and the complete abolition of the Schengen Agreement are more urgent and necessary, as the first steps in the fight against illegal immigration, terrorism and cross-border organized crime. Sovereign states need strong and secure borders, the eradication of destabilizing and anti-ethnic nuclei, and the consolidation of a climate of order and security as primary parameters for development, sincere cooperation and solidarity between nations.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! I listen to the extreme left and the extreme right with a certain bewilderment and think to myself that the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs have had a good negotiation because it turned out very sensible. We secure the external borders to prevent kilometers of traffic jams caused by controls at the internal borders. Nobody wants those miles of traffic jams back. We want people in the European Union to be able to travel freely, provide services and transport their economic goods, and we no longer want the separatism and nationalism of centuries and decades back. I believe that a European system is also the most effective and the cheapest and that we can use it to control entry and exit. That is to say, it is not an instrument of terrorism, but an instrument for security in general, in many ways, and also for whether someone is lawful on European territory or whether they are required to leave the country. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: question with "blue card".- Mrs Hohlmeier, I have heard you say and hint that all the suffering is the fault of the far right, the nationalists and the far left.When we come to Strasbourg from Greece, before we get off the plane they ask for our boarding pass.When we arrive at the airport we pass a maze to check our passports.Which Schengen are we talking about and which single Europe when there is a two-speed Europe?

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I was only at the airport in Greece myself, and I was able to get on a plane and travel within the EU very easily.That was pretty straightforward, and there were the usual controls that we experience at Brussels Airport for the safety of people.I don't know what special conditions Greece would be subject to.I believe it is sensible to set up security checks at airports for the safety of aircraft, so that the safety of passengers and aircraft is guaranteed.I think everyone is grateful for that, and everyone wants that too.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Madam President, first of all I would like to thank Mr Díaz de Meri for this very expert report and for his dedicated work. I was also glad to hear from our commissioner Avramopoulos that Croatia, if we meet the criteria, and we hope we will by the end of 2018, will be part of Schengen. This is very important to us, because we have a huge external border, and we said that this project, or this report, is precisely for better protection of external borders. Therefore, the passport should not be shown at the Schengen borders if we adopt this project. I do not see it as a political project, I think it is solely to improve checks at external borders, but it is also very important for checking those third-country nationals who stay in a particular country longer than they are entitled to a visa. Therefore, I fully support this project, since you said that it will come into force in 2020, I believe that by then we, the Croatian state, will be a member of Schengen and that we will be able to join this great project. And to those who are between data protection and human rights and the fight against terrorism and security, I say that the safety of citizens comes first and we want the safety of EU citizens to come first, and therefore I really congratulate you once again and I am glad that we have achieved consensus. I believe that we will vote on this proposal by a large majority.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: - Madam President! Better legislation has to be more than a nice phrase: Good laws - well done. What does this mean for entry / exit? The July opinion of the European Court of Justice on the Canada PNA clearly confirmed doubts about the legality of this text. The storage of the data of people who are completely unencumbered is not proportionate, is not compatible with our fundamental rights and the right to privacy. This also applies to other measures. Our legal services remained more than vague in their assessment of the importance of the judgment for Entry / Exit. They owe a convincing assessment to this day. The Commission’s unconvincing answers to our questions are no better. Good legislation would mean taking some time to clear legal concerns out of the way or simply at least significantly shortening the retention periods for unsuspicious people, as the Commission had originally proposed. We can still achieve that this week. We would then be certain that we have done everything to ensure that this text also stands up to examination by the Court of Justice. The practical application of Entry / Exit, foreseeable for 2020, would still be possible. Better legislation: Hopefully more than just a phrase.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: - (NL) Mr President, colleagues, through the new digital entry-exit system, with the English abbreviation EES, we want to better monitor who enters or leaves the EU. Because everything is done digitally, this should normally go smoothly. This certainly benefits tourism to the EU. The EES records the date, time and place of entry and departure of travelers. For example, visa holders who stay longer in the EU than allowed are more likely to be caught off guard. The EES is also important in the fight against terrorism. The system will allow identification of foreigners who have destroyed their documents or whose passports have been stolen. It is also a detection tool, as suspected persons can be traced through the point of entry or through their fingerprints. It now comes down to keeping all databases up-to-date and effective information sharing. That is why the N-VA fully supports this proposal. The safety of our citizens and the prevention of illegal residence are absolute priorities for the N-VA.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, my group - and I thank my colleague Angelika Mlinar for saying this at the outset, despite her personal reservations - is in favor of the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council. In our view, strengthening the identification of people entering and leaving the Schengen area is a necessary corollary of the freedom of movement within that area. Thanks to the entry / exit system equipped with automatic gates, we hope - and it will undoubtedly be the case - to reduce waiting times during border controls, to strengthen the quality of these controls by more easily detecting documentary fraud and identity fraud. This will allow us to automatically calculate the length of authorized stay for each traveler and check if it is respected. Of course, I am aware that after the opinion of the Court of Justice on the PNR agreement with Canada, it was legitimate to ask questions about the compatibility of certain provisions of the entry / exit system with respect for the charter of fundamental rights. These questions, I repeat, were relevant and legitimate. However, I believe - and the overwhelming majority of my group agree - that after the analysis of the findings that has been made by our legal department, we can proceed with confidence in the agreement reached.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: - Madam President! It is probably due to my East German biography that I have a pronounced distrust of such data collections. If the citizen in general, and in this case by entering the EU, becomes a suspect, then something is wrong and the principles of the rule of law are turned upside down. Apart from my phobia about data collections, in which masses of personal data are hoarded without cause, there is still the ECJ. You remember vaguely: They were the ones who sent the passenger data agreement with Canada to Orcus. We doubt that the entry and exit system is compatible with the Charter of Fundamental Rights, and we are against the retention of data from innocent travelers, which has no demonstrable benefit at all, but squandered a billion euros. If you absolutely want to do something against terrorism or, in particular, against so-called illegal migration, then, please, create a humane asylum and immigration system - that would be something. The way the entry and exit system is now, it should easily land on the ECJ table. We will do what we can for that. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- I only have one very precise question: Why are there no concerns at all when collecting data on taxpayers and carrying out constant controls of an unannounced type - which is a general suspicion against taxpayers - when you suddenly have such big problems with normal controls at borders?So I find the contradiction a bit strange.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I don't know how you came up with that comparison, but okay.Taxes must be paid and must not be thwarted.We should do everything for this and far too little is being done for that.There are tax havens here in Europe too, and I would be delighted if you could join us in doing something against tax havens.But that has nothing to do with it, this is about innocent travelers.It is useless, it does not do anything in the sense of the matter.In this respect, I think you are on the wrong track.

name: Tim AKER
text: – Madam President, it seems the European Union has developed an alarming set of contradictions. It was only a few years ago that Angela Merkel and other European leaders said ‘come ye, come ye’, and the great waves of migration began, and we have seen the consequences as the infrastructure in Italy, Greece and Hungary is crumbling before our eyes. And now it says ‘oh no, there is a problem, so we need this Entry/Exist System’, and Mr Juncker gave the game away at his State of the Union speech that he wants a ‘united states of Europe’, he wants a country called Europe, and this is just the first part of the plan. But there is the other contradiction when you say you want borders at the European level but then you have the Schengen zone, which means that there is an internal free—for—all. It seems the European Union is riddled with panic. It is seeing parties that love country, nation and sovereignty rise across the European Union, and it hasn’t got a clue how to stop them. I am just glad that we are walking away from this, and I encourage many others to follow our lead.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: - Madam President, this proposal for a regulation aims to create a European system for entering and leaving the Schengen area.This system poses two problems for me.First, this is yet another patching up of Schengen.The objective is, in fact, to facilitate entry into the Schengen area by reducing the waiting time at border crossing points.I cannot therefore support such a reform, because I do not want to make the Schengen system more fluid, but to suppress it.In addition, it is a reform that will register all entrants in interconnected computer files under the pretext of fighting terrorism.However, I believe that the best way to fight terrorism is to watch suspects and S-files, not waste time hiding millions of decent people.You sacrifice freedom and you won't even have security.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Madam President, given recent events it is right to consider measures that allow for the smooth passage of legal, short-term travellers while continuing to enhance the security of European borders. I am confident that in negotiating Brexit, the United Kingdom Government will be keen to work with its European partners to ensure continued cooperation to keep our borders safe and secure.  My constituents in Northern Ireland know well the scourge of terrorism. Close cooperation between partners, both within the EU and beyond, whether through Interpol, Europol or on a bilateral basis, is vital in building our security. When we consider the last century or even more recent times, there have been few more reliable and willing contributors to the defence of Europe than the United Kingdom. I trust that colleagues here in Brussels recognise this and will work closely with the British Government to keep that mutually beneficial relationship beyond Brexit.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I begin by thanking the excellent work carried out by the rapporteur Agustín Díaz de Mera, whose seriousness and competence we have long admired. The Entry and Exit System also intends to contribute to the collective effort for more security at our borders. For this reason, the system is welcome. However, I said several times and since the beginning I have doubts about the added value of this system. Above all, he intends to detect overstayers, that is, third-country nationals who exceed their visa period. This information will be, above all, quantitative, but it will not allow to locate them. I doubt that its high cost is justified in its added value. I have doubts about its implementation, I have doubts about its real added value, especially in the light of existing information systems and on the ground, such as the SIS (the Schengen Information System). We have to look at managing our borders in an integrated way. Information systems must be at the service of this strategy. But let us be clear: despite any doubt, it is not legitimate to consider that this system is affected by the Court's ruling on the PNR agreement between the Union and Canada. I trust the soundness of the negotiated text and finish with how I started: I have no doubts about the work carried out by the rapporteur on behalf of this Parliament.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Madam President!One of the issues that people are right to be concerned about is the protection of external borders.The reason why so much has not worked so far is also due to national narrow-mindedness.It is therefore right and overdue to come to a joint entry / exit.This is a necessary step that we are happy to take.But there are also doubts.We often tend to delegate responsibility to big data in the hope that everything will then be sorted out automatically.That is a mistake.But it is also the protection of fundamental rights that gives cause for concern.My colleagues here have tried very hard to address these concerns.However, the open question remains as to whether we should not shorten the storage periods after the Canada PNA ruling by the ECJ, specifically to 181 days.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: - Madam President! What we are trying to do today is to repair another European prestige project, namely Schengen cooperation, which, like the euro when it was implemented, does not have the necessary legal framework to work effectively. That is why, 17 years later, we need to repair what we introduced at the time, because it has turned out that the external Schengen border has not been effective or able to stem terrorism, mass migration and others. things that one would expect border controls to perform. That is why we are on the last try. If we do not now get the external borders repaired, then Schengen will collapse, and then it is better to go back to a system of national borders and national border control, especially when you look at the great reluctance that is here in the Chamber to launch absolutely necessary measures, such as an entry and exit system. Then it is thought-provoking to believe that the external border will ever become effectively protective of the people of Europe.

name: Georg MAYER
text: - Madam President! Yes, this system is definitely a significant improvement of the status quo, and for that I am very grateful to Mr Díaz de Mera, whom I really appreciate. For the first time, it is an improvement in the status quo. Because what is the status quo? The status quo is actually total chaos, and what is the essence of a state? The essence of a state is that it protects its borders and at the same time controls who enters and who leaves the country. That is something very logical. Addressed to the Greens: You can go ahead and pursue your policy like this; the same vocabulary over and over again: agitators, scare tactics and scare tactics. Then, I think, you will only suffer the fate of the Austrian Greens, who were kicked out of parliament in the last National Council election. But in this sense we have seen that during the refugee crisis millions of people came to Europe who were not registered anywhere, who were not checked and who are now in the country and in Europe. In this respect, this system is a necessary step. We are only warning that it must not lead to excessive control of EU citizens.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! We are voting on a major step for Europe. The rapporteur of the European People's Party has shaped a very good Commission proposal into an effective instrument that uses modern technology to effectively counter illegal entry into Europe and thus create more security at the EU's external borders, and at the same time for travelers from third countries - especially tourists and business people offers significantly easier and faster border control. With the most modern electronic systems we take consistent action against those who want to enter legally, but then stay illegally longer and not leave the EU. All relevant databases are networked and immediately show irregular incidents and observations of an irregular status during border control. Multiple identities and entry with false papers will practically be ruled out in the future. In the interests of the security needs of our citizens, I am calling for this system to be used even more efficiently and also to investigate serious crime and to fight terrorism. Fingerprints and biometric data captured at a murder scene should be compared in real time. Another admonition to the left-green dreamers here in the house with a special data phobia: Trust the democratic way of working in Europe we have designed! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Szanyi has a blue card but, Mr Szanyi, you are also on catch-the-eye, so do you wish to ask the question? Mr Becker, will you accept the question? So no, Mr Szanyi is not going to ask a question. There is a blue-card question from the Greens Group; do you accept this question, Mr Becker? Yes.

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Dear Mr. Becker!You have just heard your colleagues from the FPÖ.You are adopting the same rhetoric as the right-wing populists and hate speech speakers in this House, and you are thereby strengthening them.Are you actually aware of the fact that what happened in Austria is a problem that we have all over Europe?If you carry on this phrase here in the European Parliament, you are undermining our values in the European Union and our common strength.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Please stop heckling. Thank you. I am not sure that was a question about the issue we are debating, but perhaps Mr Becker would choose to answer?

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Yes, I simply recognize a real - as I said before - phobia, a manic fear of processing data, which in our legal system does not have any criminal - as you suggest - dimensions.And the political situation is this: You keep losing elections, which makes you particularly vulnerable to particular aggressiveness.Let us remain objective - as is customary here in Parliament - and work on common solutions for the citizens of Europe!

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Albrecht, one moment. Ms Sippel, you have a point of order?

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: - Madam President!I would just like to ask all colleagues here in this House, if we are talking about such a topic, to talk about the topic, to talk about facts, and not to polemic and politicize here.That doesn't help in the matter.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Please, colleagues, we are now in a debate. We will now move on to our next speaker.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: - Madam President, taking into account the recent and serious mistakes made in the framework of the exchange of information on nationals of third States traveling to the Schengen area, the Entry / Exit System constitutes an important instrument to improve the protection of external borders and contribute to the prevention and investigation of crimes of terrorism and other serious criminal offenses. The Entry and Exit System will replace the traditional passport stamping system with one adapted to the use of new technologies. It will also retain the personal data of third-party nationals traveling to the Union on a short-stay visa, including a facial image and fingerprints. During the retention period of personal data, law enforcement agencies will have access to that information, provided certain established criteria are met. For this reason, the result of the report is positive, it has been the result of consensus and the need to strengthen border control in the current context of the fight against terrorism.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: - Madam President! The Schengen system is currently threatened with failure. Several states have suspended the application because too many migrants, criminals or even terrorists are traveling within the EU. The external borders are still not adequately protected everywhere. For these reasons, the smart border system and entry / exit system are worth supporting. It will help us to at least contain the crime and illegal migration that reaches us across the external borders. In my view, however, that is not enough to save the Schengen system. Illegal border crossings into the EU are still possible in many places. It also does not contain the crime perpetrated by people within the EU. The EU member states should be given the right to request biometric identification of all foreigners who are on their territory - and by that I also mean EU citizens in another country. If citizens had to use biometric identification when crossing a border within the EU or during a police check in another country, that would not be an inappropriate intervention and would help the authorities significantly, especially in times of cross-border terrorism.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: - (NL) Mr President, I come from Limburg, a beautiful border province in the Netherlands, wedged between Belgium and Germany. Whichever way I drive from my front door, I always run into a border quickly. So I am more than aware of the enormous luxury that open borders entail, and I will always defend it here. But there are also concerns. If we are to maintain this achievement of free travel within Europe, we will have to jointly improve the management and management of our external borders. We do this through the joint border and coast guard. We do this through the control of EU citizens at the external borders. We will soon do that via ETIAS. And we do that today with an important step: via the entry-exit system. Finally, we are taking EU border management into the 21st century, from medieval stamps to computers and scans. I congratulate colleague Díaz de Mera with this great result. It is an efficient and effective way to control who is really entering Europe and for how long they want to stay. We are reducing the time it takes to cross that border, making it easier for well-intentioned travelers to come to Europe, and by using fingerprints and facial scans, we are making it much more difficult to commit identity fraud. Recent events in Europe give every reason to do so. Visitors benefit. The citizens of the European Union benefit from it. Everyone benefits from this.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and shadow rapporteurs and all the members of the LIBE Committee from the outset. It was a work in committee and the vote shows that a balanced proposal for a regulation has been reached, which certainly brings improvements to the input-output system. The new system will be able to check whether non-Europeans entering the EU comply with the authorized period of stay and, of course, as a colleague said, the system is very expensive. I want to say that people's lives are the most important and there is no price comparison. I also thank the rapporteur for supporting the entry of Romania and Bulgaria into this system, because, yes, the borders of the European Union are also important for the two member states of the European Union. I am convinced that the vote on this regulation will contribute to a better verification of identification and let us not forget that any right of movement also brings an obligation: to respect the rules, and I think that this verification at the border is also important to fight terrorism, but not only . Thanks.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, I disagree with the removal of sovereign powers from the Member States, which must continue to control their borders. In addition, the entry and exit control system in question in the European Union should operate in compliance with personal data, the principle of proportionality, and the case law of the Court of Justice of the European Communities. But at the same time, Mr Avramopoulos, the legitimacy of Schengen operation here in France must be ensured. As you know, in order to come by air from Athens here in Strasbourg, we have been undergoing passport control for two years. Secondly, tomorrow, as is the case every time the plenary session ends, we will be waiting in huge queues at the airport for a passport check by a police officer. Is this legal? I also ask, is it legal, Mr Avramopoulos, to ask us to show a boarding pass before we get off the plane, here in Strasbourg? This is very original. I want you to restore the legitimacy of the Schengen operation here in Strasbourg. All MEPs are in line for passport control. What is happening here in Strasbourg is unacceptable.

name: Emil RADEV
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent years the European Union has taken a number of measures to improve European security, in particular security at the external borders and the fight against illegal migration. The new entry / exit system is just such a measure that will allow law enforcement authorities to automatically calculate the length of stay of third-country nationals to determine whether their authorized stay in the European Union has been exceeded. For my country, Bulgaria - as a guardian of one of the most difficult European external borders - this dossier is extremely important because it will inevitably support the work of the Bulgarian border guards. I consider a great success the fact that the new system will be effectively used on Bulgarian territory, despite the lack of full membership of the country in Schengen. The inclusion of Bulgaria in the geographical scope of the system, the introduction of a uniform calculation of the permitted stay throughout the European Union, not only in the Schengen area, and gaining passive access to the Visa Information System will contribute to increasing the security of all European citizens. Let us not forget, however, that secure external borders such as Bulgaria's mean more security inside Europe. The new entry / exit system is also extremely important in the context of the interconnectedness of European border protection systems and is of particular importance for the proper functioning of the Schengen Information System for the purposes of the return of irregular migrants. In this regard, I would like to call on you to support the agreement reached in the form that was agreed in the tripartite negotiations. Thanks to the rapporteur, Diaz de Mera, for her excellent work.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have once again shown great responsibility by pursuing, even within our divisions, a system of modernizing the management of the Union's external borders. This is what this is all about, the electronic registration of the entry and exit data of third-country nationals in the Schengen area. It is for this reason that the personal data recorded in the entry system should not be stored any longer than is strictly necessary for the purposes of the data processing. We therefore ask for proportionality to the objectives pursued but we also ask that the authorities, in using the system, scrupulously respect the dignity and integrity of the people whose data is requested. We will not accept any kind of discrimination based on sex, race, religion, skin color or any other type. The system must be used for its purposes and in no case, for any reason, to deny asylum seekers safe and effective ways of entry into the territory of the Union to exercise their legitimate right to international protection.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: - Madam President, Honorable Commissioner, I congratulate my colleague Augustine Díaz de Meri on his comprehensive report, to which, unfortunately, I have certain remarks. Member States located at the external borders of the European Union are more exposed to security threats due to their long external border and their openness to threats coming from third countries. I therefore believe that special attention should be paid to them within the regulation establishing the entry and exit system for the registration of data on the entry and exit of third-country nationals crossing the external borders of the European Union. Although this Proposal for a Regulation aimed to establish an effective mechanism for further strengthening security within the European Union, from its aspect of implementation there are certain shortcomings that could seriously jeopardize the security of the European Union. What I see as a key shortcoming in this Proposal is unequal treatment of all Member States in the application of this mechanism, ie application in the Schengen Member States, while implementation is delayed in countries located at the external borders of the European Union, which include Croatia. The application of this regulation in non-Schengen Member States may affect the impossibility of registering the residence of third-country nationals, and thus possible omissions could pose a threat to countries at the external borders, their citizens, but also to everyone else. Unequal application of the regulation, postponement of application in the Member States of the European Union located at the external borders, are waiting for full membership in the Schengen area. .

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: - Madam President, congratulations to the rapporteur and thanks to the Commissioner and the rapporteur who mentioned the need to join the EES of members that are not yet in the Schengen area as soon as possible.This is a system of improvement and security of the European Union, but until it is applied in all member states, we cannot, unfortunately, talk about the protection of the external borders of the European Union but about the protection of the Schengen area.Precisely because it is a system that will facilitate the fight against terrorism, organized crime, illegal migration and that will facilitate cross-border traffic, all member states should be involved from the beginning of the operational implementation of the regulation - protect external borders.Only in this way will this regulation have full meaning and positive effects on the internal security of the European Union and on cross-border traffic as well.Croatia makes 1350 km of the external border of the European Union and, if it is not in this system, it makes the whole European Union vulnerable, not just Croatia.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, today we will vote for the entry and exit system in the Schengen area. We fought for such a unique European entry and exit system that would include Romania and Bulgaria and it is very good that we managed to get them. The establishment of this system also facilitated Romania and Bulgaria's access to the visa information system. We thus formalize the result of many months of negotiations in which many of you participated and I congratulate you for the result. We also formalize, and I am very proud of, another step towards the full integration of Romania and Bulgaria into the Schengen Area. The two countries deserve and meet all possible criteria for Schengen accession. Moreover, even before accession to the European Union and especially thereafter, they have acted continuously and in accordance with the provisions of the Schengen Agreement and for its observance and consolidation. The Council of the European Union, driven by Parliament and the Commission, Commissioner, must take new steps to take action to recognize an indisputable reality, that our place is in Schengen.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, as an MP from Croatia, a member with the longest external land border, I am extremely pleased that the Union is finally approaching the challenges of migration in a constructive way and striving to bring order to the system and protect its external borders.However, a good legal solution cannot give results if it is not applied consistently, so I expect that the regulation, contrary to some announcements, will be implemented at the external borders from the beginning of its operational implementation, as its name suggests.Unequal application of Schengen members and countries like Croatia, which are not yet, would devalue our efforts to protect the interests of all members without discrimination and to raise the level of security throughout the European Union.The operational challenges that would arise from the unequal application of this regulation are also not negligible and that is why I believe that equal application should be an absolute priority for us.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, a European Union without internal borders is of course only possible with strong, smart external borders.That is why I can only applaud this new entry-exit system.The system of stamping passports at the borders will be over, with the long queues, and we will be able to give bona fide travelers faster access to the territory.But my main concern is that we will be able to stop and track down the rogue travelers, illegal migration and terrorists much better with this system.We are going to stimulate data exchange and, above all, we are going to ensure that we can maintain our current system of free travel within the European Union through strong external borders.We will support this wholeheartedly.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Madam President, in order for the Schengen Agreement to be implemented, there must be proper and effective control at the external borders. However, since the European Union, in the context of the removal of competencies from the nation states, did not allow them to control their borders and undertook to do so itself, we have a complete failure. Consider the examples of Italy and Greece. When some useless and pro-European organizations, such as Frontex, the Coast Guard and the European Border Guard, took over the guarding of their borders, this chaos ensued, effectively breaking the Schengen Agreement. For decades the control was carried out by the national authorities without any problems. After all, it is very naive to believe that the terrorist and the illegal immigrant will come from the official checkpoints. Let us be honest, Commissioner. Just the fact that the European Union is trying to correct another mistake worth 1 billion by one mistake means a clear confession of failure. Will you tell this to our compatriots, Mr. Avramopoulos?

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Epitideios, your time of one minute is up, please stop speaking. I would ask you to respect the request of the Chair to keep to your time. Mr Sógor, I am sure you will respect the one minute.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, in 2015 alone more than 50 million non-EU nationals visited the EU, crossing the external border of the Schengen area more than 200 million times. These passenger flows are expected to increase substantially in the future too. A system of stamping passports, a legacy of the past century, is inefficient, slow to cope with the increase in traveller numbers, unreliable, and inadequate in addressing the complex security challenges we face today. The basic building blocks of the Entry/Exit System (EES) – precise and rapidly delivered information, better monitoring of the authorised stay, more efficient border checks and automated border controls – will further bring our border controls into the 21st century. As to the link between border controls and internal security, I very much welcome the rapporteur’s work on granting security forces access to the EES with the aim of fighting serious crime and terrorist threats.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Ms. President! Whatever decision is taken on the motion for a resolution, it will seriously affect the security of the Union on the one hand, and the rights of well-meaning travelers and tourists and the protection of their data on the other. Whatever we decide, however, it will certainly remain a substitute and a sham measure as long as the EU tolerates the vulnerability in the Schengen border protection system that the practice of so-called establishment bonds, EU citizenship for money, poses. The weakest link in this system is Hungary, where in recent years the government has provided thousands of Hungarians with uncontrolled backgrounds, often considered criminal or terrorist suspects, with loose conditions. . The Hungarian example is striking in two respects: the revenue from transactions does not directly increase the state coffers, but largely off-shore companies that can be linked to government leaders. Two: the same Hungarian government, meanwhile, is campaigning unscrupulously against all strangers.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their contributions to this debate and their comments. Our external border management is the nexus of our policy on security and migration and the European Union is implementing several initiatives in this domain. I therefore welcome the negotiations starting today – indeed now – between this House and the Council, and I hope a compromise will be reached soon. The compromise on the Entry/Exit System will modernise and strengthen the Schengen area’s external management. It will help Member States to deal with increasing traveller flows without having to increase the number of border guards. It will also promote mobility between the Schengen area and third countries in a secure environment, while contributing to the fight against terrorism and serious crime, and safeguarding fundamental rights. I want to be clear on a point that was mentioned earlier. The Court of Justice opinion on the EU-Canada Passenger Name Record (PNR) Agreement does not have any direct and binding legal effect on the Entry/Exit System. The Court ruled on a specific legal situation, which cannot be automatically extrapolated to other situations. There are significant differences between PNR and the Entry/Exit System. The legal basis, the purpose and the scope of data gathered, and the basis and rationale in respect of retention periods are not comparable. I am glad that this long process is now coming to an end and that we can soon start developing the system. I therefore encourage the honourable Members to support these important pieces of legislation when they vote later today.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: speaker. - Madam President, thank you very much, ladies and gentlemen, for this rich debate. The fact that there have been 44 interventions gives an idea of ​​what I am saying: I appreciate them all. I thank all those who have supported the report, those who have supported my work, those who have expressed eloquent silences. All, in short, have contributed to enrich this debate. I would like to end, Madam President, with a literal quote from the legal services of the three institutions so that, in a diaphanous and clear way, it is established that there has been no ambiguity in the pronouncement of the three legal services with reference to sentence 1 / 15 of the Court of Justice in relation to the international agreement between the European Union and Canada PNR. The report of our interinstitutional legal services literally says: «Judgment 1/15 has no direct or automatic impact on the SES due to many differences between the system and the PNR. In particular, in this regard, the objectives, scope and personal data collected.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 25 October 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: written.- The new border control system for travelers traveling to the Schengen area allows us to strengthen the protection of the external borders and close the loopholes.Until we know who is entering our borders, we cannot guarantee the security of our citizens.This automated system replaces the manual stamping of passports.The stricter border control registers the biometric data (fingerprints and face scan) and entry and exit data of the more than 50 million travelers who travel to the Schengen zone every year and compares this information with data from Europol, European and national databases.This makes it possible to immediately stop suspected persons with a false identity at the border.In this way we make it impossible for terrorists to travel under the radar into the Schengen zone and then move unnoticed from one Member State to another.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. - The entry / exit system is, in particular, an electronic database for recording the time and place of crossing borders and the duration of stay of third-country nationals in the Schengen territory. The old so-called the stamping of border controls has proved insufficient in the context of the increase in the number of passengers, but also in the face of challenges such as the increase in migration and international organized crime. The new system brings a thorough identification of persons based on the collection of biometric data. Police authorities, as well as other security forces, will be given a more detailed overview of the movement of third-country nationals in the Schengen area, if necessary. Their control will be strengthened. No Member State of the European Union can do its own in the fight against terrorism or the suppression of organized crime. Deepening mutual cooperation and supporting the development of the so-called smart borders are thus highly needed in the fight against existing threats.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - We are witnessing an unprecedented flow of migration from third countries to the European Union. In 2015, more than 50 million people visited the EU. And while the growth of tourism is positive for our economies, according to FRONTEX there is an increase in the illegal crossing of the EU's external borders, as in 2015 alone the number of these crossings is more than 1.8 million. It is clear that this fact calls for increased security at our external borders. The collection of biometric data provided for in the amendment of Regulation (EU) 2016/399 in connection with the use of the Entry / Exit System is a step in the right direction. This would prevent illegal migrants from discarding their passports claiming to be refugees. Also, the collection of biometric data would create an indisputable database with information about potential terrorists trying to enter the EU. I want to mention one more thing. The map of the European Union is not complete until Bulgaria and Romania become part of Schengen. We are already fulfilling all the conditions for entering the zone and the fact that we are illegally passing through Bulgaria is minimized is the indisputable proof of that. We are defending the EU's external borders with dignity, and I believe that we should be rewarded for our efforts.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - The introduction of the use of biometric data of persons when crossing external borders across borders will have several positive effects.In addition to smoother and more effective controls at the Schengen borders, controls on the movement of persons within the Union will also be improved and strengthened.Given the increasing migration of the population, this will contribute to greater security and earlier detection of potential threats.It is important that biometric data are used exclusively in accordance with the objectives of this measure and that the conditions under which such data can be made available to law enforcement authorities in the context of the fight against cross-border crime and terrorism are clearly defined.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - The Republic of Croatia has made all the necessary preparations and is ready to take a step further in its belonging to the European family and become a member of the Schengen area. This is good for Croatia and other member states. In addition to removing border controls with EU member states, as well as passport controls at airports when traveling to and from Schengen countries, this will also strengthen security at the EU's external borders. The longest external border of the European Union is precisely the border of the Republic of Croatia with Bosnia and Herzegovina, so it is in the interest of the European Union to protect that border even more strongly, as soon as possible. Croatia should also have access to the entry / exit system for the registration of data on the entry and exit of third-country nationals crossing EU external borders, and I hope that by the time this system is implemented we will be part of the Schengen area and an active stakeholder. The European Union must ensure equal treatment of all its member states and must not discriminate against countries on their way to Schengen, so I expect Croatia to automatically become part of the entry / exit system so that it can better collect data and participate in their exchange.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - In a volatile geopolitical context, recently marked by both the migration crisis and an increase in the number of terrorist attacks, it is important for the European Union to have "smart", efficient and integrated borders to manage the flows of people transiting the territory. or. As rapporteur for the S&D Group of the EP Committee on Budgets on the Commission's proposal for a harmonized system for the entry and exit of non-EU citizens into the Community, I believe that doing so would significantly help Member States. to manage the EU's external borders in a uniform and timely manner. Given that this report has established that Romania and Bulgaria are an integral part of the EES system, and that Schengen is a benchmark of European unity and cooperation, I call on European leaders to speed up the completion of the accession process of those countries. They have already proved that they meet all the conditions for a proper participation in the Schengen Area. European security can only be achieved through close cooperation between Member States, and this requires first and foremost equal treatment.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing. - The subject discussed today has been carefully prepared by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, as the report touches on very important aspects of the security and privacy of individuals in the EU Member States. The increase in passenger flows at the European Union's external borders over the last few years has highlighted the ineffectiveness of current border control systems, which could be exacerbated by the influx of refugees. We must modernize our traveler management systems to make them more coherent and efficient, as well as safer. Controls cannot be based solely on checks on passengers' passports and the stamps on them, which can not only be forged or illegible, but also place an excessive burden on border guards, preventing them from focusing on their real work and thus jeopardizing security. The introduction of a European entry-exit system will benefit passengers by reducing their waiting times at border crossing points. It will also benefit Member States by speeding up formalities for bona fidae passengers and at the same time increasing the security of the EU's external borders.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: in writing. - In the last few years, the sense of security of citizens in the EU has deteriorated, which is related to, inter alia, with the increase in the number of illegal immigrants and with cases of terrorist attacks. One of the conditions for limiting these disturbing phenomena is the adoption of the EU entry system. The submitted proposals improve, in my opinion, the identification system of people coming to the EU. The identification of illegal immigrants through the creation of pan-European databases of biometric data is particularly important here.
