These databases will make it possible to trace the travel histories of third-country nationals, also taking account of criminal suspects. The point is that the proposed solutions should enter into force as soon as possible, so that the Member States not only collect the necessary data for their own needs, but also share this information with all Member States and EU institutions responsible for the fight against terrorism, such as Europol or Eurojust.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on combating sexual harassment and abuse in the EU (2017/2897(RSP)).

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, this Chamber has already debated the issue of violence and harassment against women on many occasions. We on the Commission side have highlighted the seriousness of the problems with statistics and studies. We know that at least one in every three women has been a victim of some sort of physical or sexual violence. But these statistics do not tell enough personal stories, and the reason we are debating this today is because of the global ‘Me Too’ movement. Real stories have exploded in social media and other communication forums during recent weeks, stories that have been kept locked in in the memories and the hearts and minds of millions of women across the world, who have been suffering, who have been silently trying to forget or cope with this or ignore the pain. Women who have been in some form or other harassed by their boss, by their colleague, by their teacher, their neighbour or a stranger in the street. These stories shout to us. It is a feminist outcry from all across the world from women who say: ‘enough! This is enough! We refuse to be silent, we refuse to accept this.’ This is an impressive movement, and we can only listen to those stories and try to reach from the stories to some action. We must continue to work towards eradicating this problem. Workplaces all over the world, including in the European Union and EU institutions must look at how we can address this. Are we doing enough? Are there enough tools to listen to their signals, to catch those stories, to act in an appropriate way? This is work that needs to be done by men and women together. Since the creation of the Daphne funding programme in the 1990s, the EU has supported the work of NGOs at grassroots level and of national local authorities, because this debate is much broader. We need to empower volunteers and professionals to work with victims and perpetrators when it comes to sexual violence. Local actors are best placed to tackle the problem on the ground. Without them, victims would be all alone. We set aside EUR 6 million last year and have set aside EUR 12.7 million this year, and projects across the EU have been a lifeline for many organisations who would otherwise not be able to do their work. In September, in partnership with the United Nations, the EU launched a major spotlight initiative, with an initial investment of half a billion euros, to eliminate all kinds of violence against women and girls around the world. Thanks to the budget that you have advocated, we will come up with an EU survey on gender-based violence, to be carried out by national statistics institutes and led and coordinated by Eurostat. Together, we have dedicated this year to focused actions to combat violence against women. Many things happened this year and are still happening. The Commission, for example, launched a campaign which is engaging and supporting professionals, Member States and NGOs in combating the problem. Under that campaign, we set aside EUR 4 million for national campaigns and selected 10 different national projects that are now kicking off. To give an example, we are funding a campaign in association with the Italian football league, focused on passing the message to football fans that violence against women and girls is not acceptable. From a regulatory perspective, as you know, the EU’s accession to the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence (Istanbul Convention) is an important step forward. This convention brings binding rules on a wide aspect of the types of violence, including sexual harassment and abuse. Sexual harassment is already sanctioned in EU legislation, but victims – as we have seen lately – do not come forward or cases are not reported or not brought to court. And here we must look at how we can work with national equality bodies to address this problem, so that we contribute, in time, to the support given to those victims. The model structures of the Istanbul Convention and the EU Victims Directive, with a strong focus on victim support and on the training of police, can make a difference here. We need to keep an eye on implementation, and that is why, under the Victims’ Rights Directive, we have already launched an infringement case for non-transposition of this Directive. We are continuing our compliance check and looking at how the Directive is actually applied on the ground in Member States. Today you have raised a broad problem that has got legitimate attention through the recent ‘Me Too’ movement. Here we need to go forward, hand-in-hand, we need to work – everybody, especially men – to say no to harassment, no to violence against women. So thank you very much for putting this on the agenda today.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! Sexual harassment is a type of violence against women - many laws and international agreements say it. The phenomenon is so common that we hardly notice it. It's hard to find a woman who hasn't experienced harassment, insulting jokes, unsolicited text messages, unwanted workplace proposals, and sometimes worse things. Since this phenomenon is so common and so old, we may wonder why we are talking about it today and why yesterday, today and probably tomorrow all the media and the Internet are writing about it. After all, no new law has entered into force, and there has been no breakthrough in procedures. The goblet just overflowed, the silence was broken. Victims of harassment began to speak anonymously in the crowd, simultaneously, and this synergy made the voice heard again. Thanks to this, all institutions dealing with the problem of harassment saw the light of day. We learn that they exist, how they are structured, how they are financed, how they operate, how effective they are, which is the biggest obstacle in reporting harassment. We learn that it is possible to maintain privacy and confidentiality. We also learn that most of the cases reported in the media have never and nowhere been reported for fear of shame and job loss, and if the situation took place in an important institution such as parliament, there are other barriers: fear of being accused of disloyalty. , about damaging the company, about lowering its prestige. Thus, we analyze the behavior, opportunities and barriers faced by victims of harassment. Again, as is usual with violence, our focus is on the victims. Meanwhile, we are missing an important aspect of the external context in which acts of violence and harassment occur. We talk little about the perpetrators and little about the witnesses of violence. In a recent interview, the French finance minister was asked if he would have reported on his colleague if he had he knew he was a harasser, and without hesitation replied no, of course not.The answer of the French minister should not surprise anyone, because everyone does - they close their eyes and it is the first thing to stop.Today I am not satisfied that we are paying so little attention to the perpetrators of harassment, and I am not satisfied that we are also talking today about the European Parliament, where laws are made and social justice is mentioned.After all, we have procedures, regulations and tools, so I think they should be finally used.(The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: blue-card question. – You spoke a great deal, madam, about cases not being brought to court and cases being blocked. You are well aware that the press are now talking about cases of sexual harassment in this Parliament. The press have picked that up. I was made aware several months ago on the grapevine, by a very reliable source, that this was going to hit the newspapers very soon, so much so that I actually mentioned it on the Daily Politics programme some months ago. And then it did not hit the press and nothing happened. My equally reliable source told me that the proceedings had been in some way impeded and blocked by Mr Schultz, who had been instrumental in intervening and stopping that happening. Are you aware of that and will this House take that into account in this discussion?

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card.- Of course, I cannot comment on a specific case, because I do not know the story you are talking about.All I can say is that in Parliament, and this, and in all other parliaments, and in most institutions and companies, including private ones, there are committees, procedures that can help in cases of harassment.The problem is that this is a hidden phenomenon and that these cases are not reported because there is widespread public consensus that the phenomenon should remain hidden.This is what needs to be changed.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, thank you, Commissioner, for your intervention. According to the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights, around 45 to 55% of European women have suffered harassment at some point in their life. I am going to tell you some phrases that are sure to be familiar to you: "It was an open secret, she liked to provoke", "but have you noticed how she dressed?" These phrases are complicit and are intended to downplay behaviors that originate in an unequal society, where one party considers and establishes power relations over another. Hence, sexual harassment is born. And, unfortunately, this reality does not escape from any place or space, not even from public institutions, not even from this Parliament. We could put a blindfold on ourselves and think that it has nothing to do with us and that it is not necessary to make any problems about it; or on the contrary, we can give visibility to this situation and try to put solutions on the table. Today Parliament itself has instruments to respond to this type of situation, but it is evident that they are not working, and that is why we ask in the Resolution that we reinforce them, with external advice, to assess how it can improve and be really useful to the victims. We must be in solidarity and stand on the side of the victims. Do not feel ashamed. Do not be afraid of losing your jobs. That they stop feeling guilt for something for which only those who harass and who attack are responsible. For this reason, let us put in place the necessary instruments to resolve these situations, so that the shadow of doubt does not lurk over everyone, but falls solely and exclusively on the bullies. Not one more attack on the dignity of women. Not a complicit silence. Not a look away. Because you are not alone: ​​«Me too», «Me too».

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! Today we are talking about a very important issue of sexual exploitation of women and harassment. We are talking about these matters in the context of the European Union. We say that such acts also take place in the European Parliament, and it proves how completely ineffective our institution is, that it is here, in the heart of supposed democracy, in the European Parliament, that women are harassed. I think our debate today should empower women to shout out loud and say no. The power of our debate should do just that: women should have the courage to say that they are being abused, if they are. I also think that the consequence of this debate cannot be just an order for an audit on harassment in the European Parliament. I think that we, all ladies, should ask for adolescent girls who are subject to forced marriages with adult men. Let us also claim them. Maybe someone will do an audit and see their pain.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President! The past few days have been all about sexual harassment in the workplace on social media as thousands of brave women shared their experiences and exposed the prevalence of the problem. Still, I was surprised that this fact was perceived by the public as something new and surprising. Suddenly everyone is shocked and lamenting behaviors that have always existed and have affected the lives of many women. Social media campaigns alone are not enough. What has to change is how we deal with power and ultimately the power structure itself and the awareness that sexual assault is an exploitation of a position of power. All men wrote in the studbook: Sexual violence is not an expression of strength, but an expression of weakness. Sexist and discriminatory behavior must never and nowhere be tolerated. We have to go from a hashtag “MeToo” to a hashtag “NotMe”.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: for the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President! "#MeToo" has been an eye opener for many. It's good, but we who work with these issues know that this is a part of our lives, it is risk assessments we make, it is a constant boundary that we do. "#MeToo" also shows me that it is about sisterhood, and I want to give all support to those who are exposed and exposed. We must support each other and not least support those who are now talking about it and breaking the silence about what is happening in this house. I want to give that support to colleagues who are now breaking the silence, including those who name their perpetrators. "#MeToo", it is also important to see that it is about structural problems, not - as some in this House sometimes try to claim - that it concerns certain cultures or certain religions. No, it is a structural macho culture problem here in Europe, in our house, in our societies. The "#MeToo" campaign also shows that we must demand responsibility from men. If you are not part of the solution, you are part of the problem. It's time to dump her and move on. I say this to all my male colleagues: It's time to stop holding each other's backs. If you do not say and say no when someone is harassing or behaving sexistly, then you are part of the macho culture problem. This is also a campaign for change. We are actually legislators and policymakers here in this House. We are creating change and we will start by cleaning our house here and voting tomorrow on measures to remedy the abuses that have taken place here. Same here, we must show that we are part of the change, that we are part of the solution.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, ‘Me too!’ I have been sexually harassed, just like millions of other women in the European Union and I think it is about time that we very clearly say that we should not be ashamed but that the perpetrators should be ashamed. Sexual harassment is such a widespread problem all over the European Union, and we will need legislative steps to combat it. Accession to the Istanbul Convention is a first step but, in order really to do something about this, we will need a directive on the fight against violence against women. The shocking reports about events in this Parliament also give us the duty to do something about this matter. So we will need specific measures to work on, and improve, the mechanisms for fighting sexual harassment in this House. One last point. Yes, this is about women, but it is not a women’s issue. We need men to speak up. So, to all of the men in this Chamber and to all of the men in the European Union, I would say: ‘You cannot be complacent anymore. Speak up, stand up against sexual harassment. We cannot take this, we need to fight it together.’

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the FEMM committee we deal daily with issues such as sexual abuse and all other forms of violence against women, including in the workplace. This is a sad reality, which affects every workplace, and the European Parliament, alas, like any other workplace, is not immune from such despicable behavior. Many of you were outraged by the news spread by the newspapers, by this veil of silence that fell on the institution to which we belong. Many others have found the courage to denounce small and large events related to sexual abuse, which without this journalistic investigation would have remained in silence and oblivion. Jumping in the chair in front of accusations of this kind is an understandable reaction, just as it is understandable, on the part of the institution, to clarify and clean up immediately so as not to risk seeing one's authority and honor damaged by infamous actions carried out by individual characters . But let's try not to be hypocrites and not to do, as often happens, a series A and a series B justice. The same indignation, the same resoluteness and immediacy in the measures, the same severity and zero tolerance towards such atrocities must be applied yes within the European Parliament, but equally and with the same vigor in all workplaces, both public and private. It is good to set a good example, it is good to act firmly, but let us not forget that this Parliament is the mirror of what is happening outside, in the real world, where a subculture based on sexual exploitation permeates every sphere. In how many universities, for example, are young female students to be sexually harassed by some unworthy teacher? In how many offices, including public ones, are the employees the object of special attention from their managers? And how many women are offered a workplace, today more than ever often a mirage in reality still devastated by the economic crisis, in exchange for services that are not properly defined as a professional type?It is anger to think that for every complaint, which then ends up in the newspapers due to clamor, there are hundreds of cases that remain silent out of fear, out of shame, out of guilt.Here, we can say that we have acted for the best and that we have done the good of women and even men victims of such obscene behavior when we act against all forms of sexual abuse within the borders of the European Union with the same diligencewith which we are acting today to counter what is happening inside our home.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, the Weinstein affair has exposed the world to the sexual abuses committed by some influential predators on the women around them and with whom they work. It has allowed these women to speak more freely and to demand justice. We must do everything in our power to enable women victims of such acts of violence to obtain justice and redress. However, as horrific as these acts may be, they cannot justify the public pillorying of alleged perpetrators. It is crucial, now more than ever, to call for respect for the rule of law. Women must be able to bring complaints without fear and defendants must defend themselves in court. The famous "#balancetonporc" is indicative of the mistake we must not make: confusing media lynching and justice. This hashtag is also the door open to public denunciation, and no rule of law can tolerate it. I believe, finally, that we should not treat this issue like this hashtag, making every man or every boy a potential pig. Dear colleagues, rather than overwhelming all men, let us face the problem. Let us restore our innocence to our adult boys and girls of tomorrow. For example, in France, one in three children under 13 has seen a pornographic film. Let's protect them from this violence which makes women an object of sexual enjoyment, which damages our children and which makes Weinstein's Hollywood the standard in terms of male / female relationships. I would also like, in a slightly more political register, to condemn the sectarianism of certain parliamentarians in this assembly, who excluded my political group from the resolution, de facto weakening the voice of the European Parliament. This unacceptable behavior given the subject will not prevent me from voting in favor of this a resolution which deserves something other than this political meanness.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Madam President, from media attention this week we finally know that there is a problem with sexual harassment in this Chamber. But the focus, seemingly, is on sexual harassment of women by male MEPs only. That totally ignores – and I mean ignores – what could be going on. I am only suggesting, but I understand it does go on. Therefore, sexual harassment should not be gender-specific. We have got to address this. Ms Malmström, the rapporteur, spoke very eloquently about what needs to happen, but what is clear is that we do not currently have a process with which individuals and alleged perpetrators can engage, and ask for a suitable investigation. I believe that the vote we are going to have tomorrow morning is bringing this forward too quickly. We have not addressed sufficiently the scale of what is going on and the nature of what is going on. I would suggest we go forward on this with responsibility given to the Quaestors.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are once again talking about an issue that deeply afflicts the European Union and its institutions. Following the Weinstein case, many women have finally had the courage to report harassment and abuse, even within these walls, too often. Women all over the world are afraid to speak. 13% of women in Europe said they have experienced violence in their lives at least once. So to date, the most effective tool for combating harassment and sexual abuse is the Istanbul Convention. The latter introduces the criminalization of violence against women, psychological violence, stalking, physical violence, sexual violence, including rape and harassment. There is still no legislation in all of Europe, which is why today I still want to insist on the Istanbul Convention. The criminal laws of the Member States counter violence in principle, but there are still many obstacles and therefore, consequently, there is no homogeneous protection of victims. What I ask for, for Parliament and for the Union as a whole, are certain penalties and exemplary punishments. Kofi Annan says that violence against women is one of the violations of human rights, perhaps the most shameful, because it has no geographical, social or cultural boundaries. As long as this exists and is perpetrated around the world we cannot have reached high levels of development, peace, sustainability and acceptability.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Today we bow first to the courage of those affected, because it is not easy to address these processes, to stand up and talk about them. But these brave people create the space for an urgently needed debate. It's about more than individual misconduct. It is about a dimension that we can easily notice, that we can easily tap into if we simply look at the remarks made by the current US President on how women should be treated. What does that show us? It is this climate of permissibility, this culture of permissibility of attacks. It always has something to do with stupid dominance behavior, with violence, with attempted abuse, but with oppression. There is always something stately in it. We must uncover the causes of this behavior. We have to talk to each other and oppose a culture of respect, a culture of dignity. That goes for this house, that goes for Europe. One final request, Madam President, that is a very personal matter for me. Let us not forget - today on this day - what is happening at the external borders of Europe, in the refugee camps and in the reception camps, how girls, young women, how children are abused, and what scandal we let our eyes open! Dignity and respect must also be part of our development policy and our refugee policy. That is part of the debate today.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Madam Chairman, the culture in the entertainment world seems to be that those – particularly women – who want to work in the industry, are preyed upon by powerful individuals, mostly men, who can make or break their careers. The term ‘casting couch’ is so well known that it has entered the English language. So this is not a new concept, and I’d like to thank all those brave women who have come out in the ‘Me Too’ campaign. I would particularly like to thank the brave employees of this Parliament who have spoken out in recent days. It is really important, I believe, to seize the momentum, and do something in our own workplace and I’d like to see the resolution concentrate on that aspect. The structure is in place and I’d like to thank our Quaestor, Ms Bearder, for sending round a note yesterday that showed us that the structure is there. But people still don’t feel confident to use that structure, and that’s the real problem: that we don’t take it seriously enough. So if there’s fear of losing a job we can actually individually as MEPs do something, certainly for our accredited parliamentary assistants. I’d like to pledge here and now, I, as a Member of this Parliament: if there is an assistant out there who feels they are going to lose their job, come and work in my office then temporarily, I will offer you a safe haven. And I’d like other Members to join me in that pledge.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Madam President, I believe we are the first parliament in Europe publicly to debate the issue of sexual harassment and intimidation. Unfortunately, it is necessary. We have to talk about how we put into practice what we preach, and provide a free and safe working environment for the people who work for us and for all Europeans. Yes, we have a harassment committee, a complaints procedures and so on, but why have only 10 cases been brought forward since 2014? That means that the threshold is too high and that procedures alone are not enough. In recent days, after the ‘Me too’ campaign, I have been getting the following question, often from men: ‘I am not so sure anymore what I can and cannot do. When do I cross the line?’ I would say it is easy. If you have a daughter, just ask yourself how you would want your daughter to be treated. That is the way you are going to treat other people. It is not just about violence, but also about sexism and sexist remarks. They are not harmless. Sexist jokes are not funny, they are just sexist, and they lead to harassment and violence. I have one final comment: to be clear, women and men decide for themselves. Of course, what consenting adults do between one another is not our business, but when a girl says ‘no’, it means no.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, feminism taught me starting with myself: Me too. I was 19, in college. He had about 70, a fellow professor, an intellectual companion. Months later I took the exam with another professor and the satisfaction of that 30 cum laude taken with another professor, after having said no, I don't forget, just as I don't forget all the time it took me to understand what happened that day, the shame, the anger. And most of all, I'll never forget the women who helped me get through that crap. Me too. We together. I believe it is important today, as parliamentarians, with the presence of the Commissioner, to say "we together" against male violence against women. From women the strength of women, women who give themselves strength. "Not one less" is today a global political movement, a global political force, which will take to the streets again on November 25 against male violence, against exploitation, against racism. Why do many women not report? Because macho solidarity and complicity is still too strong, we must fight against macho culture, we must ratify the Istanbul convention, we must do more. We together.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: - Madam President, first of all, to show the rejection of the denounced events and really thank all those women who have dared to denounce it, because it is essential that this absolutely comes to light. This is a very widespread phenomenon: 55% of women in the European Union report having been victims of sexual harassment; Thirty-odd percent report that this harassment has come from colleagues, bosses, work friends ... Therefore, we are talking about a very widespread phenomenon as a result of an insufferable patriarchy. But today, I would like to make two reflections that have to do with this House. The first is that, of all the cases that have appeared in the press - more than a hundred in the European institutions - how many have been officially denounced in the mechanisms that we have in this institution? Very few, practically none. We have to find ways for this to be denounced. And the second reflection that I want to make, colleagues: this is also our responsibility and, today, in this debate, in which there will be more than forty speeches, only five men will speak. This can not be! This is also our responsibility, we have to report when we see these situations that happen near us. Let us also commit ourselves against sexual violence.

name: Margot PARKER
text: – Madam President, sexual harassment is, shockingly, all too common in today’s society and in this European Parliament. Whilst statistically women are over five times as likely as men to experience sexual assault, it is important to note that sexual harassment and abuse affects both men and women. We have all heard the stories and rumours that have been going on for many years. The very place that claims to legislate against this sort of disgusting behaviour is turning a blind eye to its practice. The idea that MEPs or staff are using their positions of power to perpetrate abuse is shameful and unacceptable. I want some clarification. Can the members of the Bureau tell us all they know about their in camera meeting at the end of last year regarding 15 MEPs who are accused of sexual harassment? These files should be opened up to public scrutiny. Please action this immediately.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Madam President. Recent revelations in the media and on social networks show that sexual harassment is a problem for Europe, its Member States, but also its institutions. As with violence against women, we must talk here not only about helping victims and punishing perpetrators, but also about prevention. And the only effective prevention is education from childhood to respecting the dignity of every human being. Perpetrators of sexual harassment often abuse their position and function, while victims who choose to report the case face the risk of dismissal, reassignment and a personal file that is an obstacle to their future careers. As Members, we can only call on the Member States to emphasize in their educational programs the need to respect the human dignity of everyone and to help the victims. But we can do more to help the victims and punish the perpetrators of sexual harassment and violence in this House. Awareness that inappropriate behavior will have serious consequences, for example in the form of deductions from the salary in favor of the victim, would undoubtedly have a preventive effect. At the same time, such compensation would at least partially offset the victim's disadvantaged position.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, in recent weeks, thousands of women have denounced the sexual harassment of which they are victims through the hashtags “#MeToo”, “#MoiAussi” or “#BalanceTonPorc”. Thanks to them, gender-based violence comes to light. Yes, it is a scourge that is raging dramatically across Europe. One in two women has been the victim of sexual harassment. This is too often seen as a private matter and far too easily tolerated, especially as filing a complaint is too often a struggle. All these testimonies call for a political response. I am addressing the Commission, the Presidency and the States here. The Istanbul Convention is the first legally binding treaty at international level on combating violence against women. The convention begins with these words: "Violence against women must be understood as a violation of human rights." This is serious and must be firmly punished. What is no longer tolerable is the impunity of the perpetrators. Article 40 of the convention specifically provides for criminal penalties for sexual harassment. In our report voted on last September, we urge Member States to speed up negotiations so that the European Union can ratify this convention faster, in order to act now and more effectively for women's rights. I also ask the States which have not yet done so - and I salute Estonia, which has just done so - to ratify this Istanbul Convention, because the Union's membership does not exempt them from their obligations. . I end by recalling that violence against women is rooted in our society. We need a profound change in mentalities and behaviors to break free from them in the long term. Women and girls must be protected everywhere and at all times.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - Mr President. Money, sex and power. This is a godless trinity of sin that defiles many leaders, and it is a poisonous cocktail that attracts many ambitious people, but only people with complexes. But this is said about machismo, that there are bad men here. But I think you want to stereotype it anyway here, because women also harass, and you know that among the reported cases, even in institutions, there are also cases of harassing women. Please don't just talk about men. And sexual harassment also happens among homosexuals, even in this community, and they are simply silent about it. And we must stop the process that makes men and women objects. Objects that we then, simply in fantasy, use. And it is an explosion of pornography, relationships without obligation, a rejection of sexual morality. These are the tragic consequences that we now see happening here. So whether it is an institution of the European Union or Hollywood, we must demand respect for both men and women as individuals, demand self-control and an emphasis on the family. Because these are things that know how to stop sexual activity.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, sexual harassment continues to exist because fear continues to exist, because fear continues to silence the victims. And that silence is the wall that protects the bullies, it is their shield from impunity. Victims of sexual harassment are afraid of being singled out, stigmatized, of losing their job, of not being believed. But why does a woman have to put up with it and shut up? Why is the stalker not afraid? How is it possible that a European law that has protected since 2002 and that considers this to be a crime does not scare enough those who perpetrate that crime? Why are these criminals not afraid? Why don't we rigorously apply the law and our rejection to them? 55% of women in the Union say they have ever been sexually harassed. If we go to female managers, we go up to 75%. This happens everywhere, in any environment and also here in our house, in Parliament. And this is intolerable, and we are not going to take it anymore. This is a joint effort. The victims who have opened this gap of silence must have our full protection, and all of us who are here must denounce it and say, of course, "Me too."

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: - Madam President, fortunately this time we are not hiding behind our finger. We acknowledge that sexual harassment also exists in the European Parliament and should be one of the most protected workplaces in the world, where women are in the majority and the level of education is high. Think, colleagues, how much worse things are for a refugee woman in a camp or for a domestic helper. Let us start here, with the European Parliament. We first need a clear mechanism to protect victims of harassment to deal with fear, otherwise they will not report it. Then, in order not to accept bias, we need a democratic composition of the committees that deal with complaints between MEPs and associates. Finally, we demand that complaints of harassment be investigated in the European Parliament by an independent committee of experts so that the cover-up is not legalized.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: - Madam President!"#MeToo."Yes, I have also been subjected to sexual harassment and abuse.It is very painful to see that person, powerful, continue just as before.My overwhelming feeling right now is still solidarity and joy.Finally, we talk about these painful memories that we all share.We must break the silence and that is what we are doing today.I want to see more men as role models in this struggle.This is not women's responsibility.We need more men standing up in the public space and saying stop when harassment and abuse are going on.We need more men who come out and tell us about their abuse and their experiences as perpetrators.We also need more men who break destructive male norms that are about aggression, dominance, simply more equality in society, and that will really change our societies.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Madam President, the Weinstein case has given confidence to many to come out and to speak and to tell their story of how they have been treated. Sexual harassment should not be tolerated in any form: it is an abuse of a powerful position. I would like to pay tribute to all those brave women who have come out and told their story; they have facilitated others in coming forward, and I think it has been a very important step. We should look at the role the media has played in this – both traditional media and, indeed, social media – in giving young women in general (and it mostly is young women) the confidence to come and tell their story. But we need to ask ourselves how the structures that are in place in this Parliament have not facilitated those women to come forward. They do not have confidence; they do not feel comfortable; and, most importantly, they do not feel safe in coming forward to the structures that are in place. That is a question for all of us. The EU Employment Equality Directive is designed to protect employees from sexual harassment, and that legislation must work for all employees in every workplace across Europe. Here in Parliament, we need to provide a safe workplace free from harassment of any kind, and we need to provide the structures and the proper reporting mechanisms so that individuals can come forward in a situation where they feel safe. I think the onus is on all of us to ensure that, and to ask questions as to why that has not been happening to date.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: - Thank you, Mr President. Sexual harassment is a universally damaging phenomenon. He balances between a ruined career if the victim does not succumb to harassment, major psychological trauma if the victim surrenders to him nonetheless. Although cases where a victim of sexual harassment reports the incident to the relevant authorities, the harasser is punished and the victim - that victim - successfully maintains his or her career is probably solitary, this is a problem of abuse of power that results in human rights, women’s rights, violation. Unfortunately, there is such a phenomenon, such a problem in our European Parliament, who would think. And I therefore agree with the need for an independent inquiry in the European Parliament, with the help of external experts, because it is clear that the current complaints system in Parliament is simply not working well enough at the moment, and we must create an effective mechanism for professional lawyers and psychologists to advise our staff. After all, it is necessary to provide and sanction those who believe they may abuse their power. Yes, the European Parliament has a code of conduct, the administration has the European Parliament's Rules of Internal Ethics. But that is certainly not enough. Both of these documents must result in serious sanctions for sexual harassment, and I wish that there would be not only speeches but also deeds.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: – Madam President, all forms of harassment are wrong and must be stopped, but sexual harassment is particularly pernicious. This Parliament has a committee that deals with harassment cases when MEPs are involved, and I sit on that committee. We have a constant stream of cases, but coming forward is very distressing for the victims. Disclosure is a professional and financial risk for them, so victims don’t come forward and their cases go unreported. So we don’t see the full extent of the case. The situation is not acceptable. We cannot be complacent. We must get better – better at preventing harassment in the first place by introducing mandatory MEP training, better at encouraging the victims to come forward by giving guarantees that they will not lose their jobs, and better at acting swiftly once the investigation has been completed, with sanctions imposed against the MEPs. We have a long way to go, as do many large institutions. This Parliament must demonstrate that we are a fair, safe and respectful place for all to come and work at.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: - Madam President, at the beginning of the session we decided to include this debate urgently in view of the information that appeared in the press, which defines this Parliament as a hotbed of sexual harassment. Some will be caught, of course, by surprise, but for most of the women in this institution we know what is being talked about: it is an open secret. We have to thank the courage of the women who have dared to denounce and all the participants of the "#Me too" campaign, but this is not about making statements today, voting on a resolution tomorrow and forgetting about it. For this reason, we again urge the European Commission to propose a Directive to combat violence against women and also all the Member States to ratify and implement the Istanbul Convention. We know that most cases are not reported for fear of social stigma, but, above all, also for fear of losing the job. In this Parliament there is a committee that monitors complaints of harassment between assistants and MEPs, but the majority is made up of MEPs, and that is why the fear of reporting by victims is understandable. Let's not forget that job insecurity is a great reason that encourages abuse.

name: Karima DELLI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there are two men among my staff.Have I ever locked one of them in my office, hugged one of them in a closet, or pinched their buttocks in an elevator?Never, never in life!On the other hand, it happens to so many women here in the European Parliament.So we'll have to sweep in front of our door.The political world is made by and for men.How many of you knew?How many have said nothing about such unacceptable behavior?Power gives so many men an intolerable sense of impunity.It has to stop.Not tomorrow.Now!For all the girls and women of Europe, we must act quickly, do prevention everywhere and all the time, give more resources to the justice system and train the police services, because, dear colleagues, fear and shamemust change sides.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President, I have one minute and 30 seconds. I will speak in Hungarian. We have been talking for a few weeks now about the importance of combating violence against women, and in recent days it has become clear to an even wider public how serious, yet how long, it has been swept under the rug. More than 250 million women in the EU are affected by some form of violence, and one third of women have been physically abused at least once in their adult lives. Not only the next generation needs education about violence against women, not just young people, but everyone! This question is about respect, whether we are able to respect each other as human beings, whether we are able to respect each other’s decisions, our will, whether we are women or men. Never, no woman should feel humiliated because she was born a woman. Half a year ago, we launched a campaign in Transylvania, Romania, to raise awareness of the fight against violence against women, tightening up legislation, informing women of their rights and opportunities - we have also launched trainings for students these days. As we have seen, the public, the media and advertising have a huge role to play in ending the abuse of women, which is why we need to support all Member States so that they can take concrete action in cooperation with the civil society. Victims of women also need institutions that provide immediate protection, free legal advice and information, and adequate financial security.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I want to thank all the women who, through their complaints, have opened a debate that has again highlighted all the difficulties, all the imbalance, of a debate that still sees women victims twice: the first when they are abused and the second when they are judged, when they are still judged for how they dress, for how they behave, for their sacrosanct ambitions. So these women, dear colleagues, talk about each of us, they talk about all of us, who in any condition of wealth, class, religion or race are subjected to physical or verbal violence, subtle or explicit, but which in any case remains an intolerable limit to our free expression, to our career, to our life, ultimately. We have the duty to go beyond this indignation, we have the duty to produce a new thought that concerns, dear comrades and colleagues, especially men: men must stop thinking that the problem of violence against women is a problem of women. On the contrary, it is a problem that mainly concerns men, and it is good to say it clearly. It is everyone's problem, including this Parliament, which must give a clear message of attention and presence and say with one voice: Me too.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, that #MeToo has brought us many shocking stories, from all sectors and unfortunately also from this Parliament: masturbations on the desk, the women are sitting in the elevators, ... 2017 should no longer exist. The difficult thing is, of course, that it often concerns power relations. Because what do you do when your boss is touching you, but you love your job, you have a loan to pay off and you have children to raise? I think and hope that #MeToo that has broken the taboo brings about a number of things. Firstly, that women straighten their back, say "no", "no" right away, use their knee when necessary. Secondly, that men realize they are going too far and say "not me", "I will not do this" en masse. Finally, Madam President, I call for it - I always thought the European Parliament protects its workers enough, but I fear we are not doing enough when I read those stories - so let's take action and the victims here in Parliament to protect. (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Sexual harassment should never be tolerated, and I am sure you agree with me. Whether in the streets of Cologne or in the corridors of power in Brussels it is absolutely intolerable, regardless of sexual orientation. However, some liberals here are in favour of stereotyping. Ms Vautmans, did you not say something that was, I believe, reported in ‘Politico’ – that sexual harassment is commonplace in southern and eastern Europe? Is that not stereotyping people? I do not think that is quite right. If a right-wing Eurosceptic had said such a thing, everyone would go crazy here. Would you take that back? [...] (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: blue-card answer. – I don’t think I said it here, but I told it to a journalist who wrote it very harshly, and more harshly than I said it. I only said that here in the Parliament you have a mix of cultures and some cultures are more open and warm, and more open to touching people. Other cultures have different opinions on that. I never wanted to stigmatise any culture. It happens in every culture, it happens in every sector and it happens in every place. The only thing I wanted to say is: maybe some cultures have to think a little bit more before they touch a woman.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, almost 25% of women in the European Union have experienced physical or sexual violence from their partner after the age of 15. I would like to express my deep solidarity with them. Almost half of women in the European Union have been the victims of verbal, physical or internet harassment during their lifetime. It shocks me that more than a quarter of Europeans think that sexual intercourse without the consent of a partner can be justified. More than one-fifth of Europeans think that women often make up or exaggerate their allegations of abuse or rape. Victims of violence often do not report the crime. People around them are sometimes reluctant to intervene on their own, even though they know about the situation. Sexual forms of cyberbullying are also a problem. Whether it's sms messages or sexual emails. A few days ago, Commissioner Jour herself announced a 'mee too'. It is necessary to change the widespread perception in society that such behavior is normal, or to evoke a sense of guilt in victims that they are to blame for such harassment. It is also a problem for the European institutions, as has been said. The European Union should accede to the Council of Europe Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women and Domestic Violence (Istanbul Convention). I think it is our real duty to intervene .... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Anna HEDH
text: - Madam President! In our work as MEPs, it is extremely important that we take all forms of discrimination, harassment and oppression as seriously as possible and actually act to combat this form of violence. We have the opportunity to legislate to prohibit discrimination, but we also have a major role to play in forming opinions in the European Parliament to actually say: Now that's enough! We will not be able to legislate these behaviors completely. Therefore, we need to act through other channels to change the norms, structures and power relations that result in women being subjected to this form of oppression. I also want to be very careful to point out one thing. When we now ask everyone who has been subjected to various forms of discrimination and harassment to come forward, we must also be aware of the employees' situation in our own house. All those who work for us MEPs and the European Parliament must feel that they can tell about their experiences without risking being fired.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: - Madam President, I think that in this European Parliament there is no more harassment than elsewhere, but there is no less either. Through this open debate, I was about to say that we are realizing our responsibility, but apparently not for everyone. Mr Škripek, how many times have you been sexually assaulted? So let's not forget that we are in the spotlight and what we decide here will have repercussions on the rest of society. Obviously, we are not to blame for what is happening, but we have a collective responsibility to stop it. If we didn't, then we would be guilty. We are therefore making three proposals: first, we must put an end to the precariousness of the employment contracts of our assistants by giving them a real possibility of denouncing. Let’s not forget that 95% of women are fired when they report. Second, an external audit should assess the scale of the phenomenon and the effectiveness of the measures taken, to bring out the culture of the institution and not to denounce personal cases; and, finally, a special committee on sexual harassment should be set up.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: - Madam President, this is a big test for the Parliament to show that we are ready to implement the recommendations we send ourselves. This is a very important moment when a long-term message is being sent to victims of abuse, both in the European Parliament and throughout the European Union. I consider the proposal of the European people to form an investigative body within Parliament unacceptable. That way, a message is sent that something might want to be covered up, and that’s the worst message we can send at this point. I call on colleagues to support the Socialists 'and Democrats' proposal to set up a body of external experts to investigate the allegations. We cannot send our assistants a fifteen-page brochure and say we have solved the problem. Some want to show that it is the Istanbul Convention that harms families and women. It needs to be said loud and clear here: it is violence that harms women and families. We need to create a secure framework for reporting, empower victims, and on the other hand show with harsh punishments that Parliament has zero tolerance for violence.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: - Madam President, our institution has a duty of care - this is how things are called legally - towards each member of this institution. Sexual harassment is therefore a problem that we must address. On the one hand, we need to lift women out of the humiliation and shame they find themselves in, and on the other hand, we must all together stop turning a blind eye. Yes, I chair the anti-harassment committee. I am an EPP and I work with my colleagues on it with energy, but I believe that we need to make progress on three points. The first point is the release of the testimonies. I suggest that we set up a network of trustworthy people who, in close proximity to each other, will listen to the victims in order to help them speak out. That’s the first thing. Things are not said, the victims are ashamed, they do not speak and they must be able to speak. I deal with cases that arise, but this word must be released. Second, there needs to be a mediator between the institution - this house - and the victims. I am not in favor of having two anti-harassment committees and I will explain why. It is simply because between psychological harassment, Madam President, and sexual harassment, the line is so fine. It starts with one, it ends with the other and, therefore, of course, there is a real cohesion between the two and we must not multiply the structures. This is not what we need; what matters is that these structures operate objectively. We have experts there. Finally, Madam President, I want everyone here to be informed, that Members know what they are risking, what they are doing and that they are aware that this is not ethically sustainable.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: - I strongly condemn any sexual harassment.We must have zero tolerance for these discarded actions.Sexual harassment is a problem that we must not close our eyes to, as this does not reduce or eliminate the problem.It is important that victims speak up and that we protect them appropriately.Namely, there is often a fear of losing a job and stigmatizing the victim.Therefore, the right approach and awareness in terms of recognizing sexual harassment is important.We need swift and decisive action, both at the level of the European Parliament and at the level of the courts.I therefore welcome the fact that we are talking about this important topic in this plenary.We must not be silent about this.We must protect human dignity and human rights.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the sexual harassment and abuse that still takes place, both in the family context and in the workplace, and today also through the net and new technologies (I am thinking for example of the so-called revenge porn), represent one of the more hateful forms of human rights violations. I quote only one data, provided by the FRA: one in ten women has suffered forms of sexual violence since the age of fifteen. These are abuses that often cause long-term traumatic consequences to the victims and, just as often, are not reported because they are accompanied by psychological pressures or by the fear of those forms of secondary victimization deriving from attitudes or behaviors of reproach towards the victims. Faced with this situation, the European institutions must work towards more effective action to combat the phenomenon. For example, the Commission needs to continue its investigations and actions to ensure that all Member States fully implement the directives on victims of crime and it is essential that all Member States ratify and implement the Istanbul Convention.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, a greater public effort against sexual harassment at work seems very timely, another manifestation of inequality. The greatest institutional contribution must be the support to the victims and the fight against impunity. Subject the bullies, after a process with all the guarantees, to public shame. But without the militant commitment of men and women in their personal lives, without a firm attitude towards the chains of jokes that offend the victims, without any other treatment for the image of women in the media and even in school matters, we will continue like this. We need other attitudes, other tools, another daily commitment. Here is simply power and domination. Let us encourage empathy, because while there are men so unconscious as to say between laughter that they would like to suffer sexual harassment because they are that macho, that attractive, that bad - ask the few who have suffered it to see what they think - because as long as shameful television reality shows continue to make money while supporting stereotypes and dominance schemes, we will have the losing battle.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: - Madam President, after the harassment scandal in Hollywood, the "# YoTuo" campaign has brought to light millions of testimonies from women and has made visible something we already knew, that sexual harassment is everywhere and is carried out by close people and strangers of all ages, colors and classes, in everyday situations and that are not so, on the street, in public transport, in the workplace or study, in spaces with strong power relations. Ladies and gentlemen, sexual harassment can be common, it can be common, but it is not normal: it is violence. It must be made visible, it must be punished and it must be eradicated. And, ladies and gentlemen, it is a shame, as this campaign has revealed, as reported by The Times and many other newspapers around the world, that harassment is a common practice in this Parliament. Let's be exemplary: let's start with this House. We guarantee the complaint with guarantees; Let's do an in-depth investigation into harassment situations, give it a name and surname and be exemplary with the sanctions. They are here, they are among us; they are violent, they are dangerous and they cannot go unpunished.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Madam President, sexual harassment in the workplace is a bad habit that must be eliminated. First of all, it must be eliminated here in Parliament, where MEPs have increased powers and assistants are completely dependent on them for the maintenance of their work. In my view, an MEP who takes advantage of his position and sexually oppresses or exploits his assistants is primarily a coward. In order to tackle this problem globally, we must, of course, consider and condemn the case of sexual harassment of women by men, but also of men by men. Finally, I would like to ask the Commissioner what is the point of informing football fans about violence against women. I have been watching football since I was a child, I have been on the field and I have not seen any violence against women. When there are fights, fans of both groups are men, not women and men.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Madam President, I am shocked by the allegations I read in the media regarding the accusations of sexual harassment of assistants by some members of the European Parliament and I advocate a thorough investigation to shed light on the whole case and sanction the perpetrators. Unfortunately, no institution in the world where many people work together has been spared the abuse of position and inappropriate behavior, including the European institutions. However, it is important to respond appropriately to such atrocities so that they do not recur. Praiseworthy are campaigns like Metoo that allow for the creation of a secure platform on which victims feel safe enough to share their experiences, which they would not otherwise have the courage to do out of fear or distrust of the system. Abuse has a corrosive effect on society as a whole and it is the obligation of all of us to respond to all forms of abuse, violence and abuse of office. Only with openness, support and courage is it possible to make the changes needed to eradicate any kind of inappropriate behavior.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, like many, I was shocked by the Harvey Weinstein scandal. I was shocked by the violence of the stories told by the victims, but I was not surprised. Some people have said they were surprised by the number of victims who subsequently spoke out online, using the ‘Me Too’ hashtag, but I was not surprised. Most women and girls have been victims of sexual harassment or assault at some point in their lives.  The fact that this recent crop of appalling revelations comes from within my own sector, the creative industries, is doubly distressing. The myth of the casting couch was never a myth, but rather an institutional practice which has its parallels in the boardrooms and staff rooms of all workplaces, including both the public and private sector and in the community and voluntary sector too. Trade unions have a particularly important role to play in establishing systems and support for reporting and dealing with abuse, but the education of boys and men should play an important role in the fight against sexual harassment and abuse. Instead of telling girls how to dress or behave, we should educate boys about consent.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, yesterday the sentencing of a journalist, who was regarded as eminent and highly respected, for child sex abuse offences has been criticised for the leniency of the conviction and sentence. He received two and a half years, and the chief executive of the Dublin Rape Crisis Centre has led complaints about this. I suppose what that shows is that even when the law takes its course, society and families are not always satisfied by the outcome. That is something we need to be conscious of.  I visited a women’s refuge recently in my constituency and sexual violence is all too prevalent, but I am glad to say that there is help and support available, and people should reach out for that support. I would ask colleagues in this House, staff and Members, to put their faith in Elisabeth Morin-Chartier, our colleague who takes on her shoulders an enormous responsibility and does it with great effect. Please, if you have not approached her, do! She will listen. She will act.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Madam President, a recent EU survey on harassment and abuse gave some shocking findings, not least that 55% of women have experienced sexual harassment. It must be called out for what it is: a brutal form of discrimination, a basic assault on human dignity, and both a cause and a consequence of persistent inequalities between men and women. I welcome this debate today, but it must form part of a long-term, serious effort to tackle this scourge because there is a long road ahead. Sexual harassment knows no class or culture and is not confined to the home or the workplace. As such, it is the job of every employer, family member, colleague and friend to stand up for all people who are affected. For our part, here in this Chamber, we must ensure that the information, the support and a zero-tolerance approach in dealing with this are in place. Be it in Hollywood or in our own communities across the European Union, including my constituency in the UK, sexual harassment is a cancer that must be stopped.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I think that the subject of today's debate is very important, not because we are currently discussing it and giving victims another incentive to complain and claim their rights, but because it is a matter of which existed, exists and unfortunately will exist, as long as there are loose consciences and morbid mentalities. This is despite the fact that European legislation has been in place for fifteen years. But when we talk about harassment in the European Parliament, please be very specific in the complaints, if there is a will on the part of the Commission to condemn them immediately, because otherwise we give the impression that they may think outside that the temple of democracy is the European Parliament. characterized by immoral behaviors.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Madam President, equal rights, non-discrimination and gender equality are fundamental values ​​of the European Union. Today, many women victims of sexual harassment testify to violations of these values. As a man, I must say my distaste for these behaviors. The dignity of men is indeed to respect the dignity of women, and this in all circumstances and in all places, whether in employment situations, in the office, in the factory, in transport, and even in the European Parliament, which indignant me, I must say, in particular. It is zero tolerance that is required in these circumstances, as in those, for that matter, of hate speech between people of the same or the opposite sex. Basically, it is through education that we will provide the best answers to this question. But, for those who would be impervious to these teachings, or who would have difficulty in controlling their impulses, it is of course for an independent justice to intervene. Protecting the filing of complaints and adjudicating quickly constitute measures, it seems to me, to combat this sad phenomenon.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent weeks, as a result of scandals that have come to the fore in the media, we are finally discussing the necessary aberration of violence against women. I have already said this on other occasions and I want to reiterate it in this House, also in the light of the latest absurd news concerning this Parliament: any kind of violence against women, in every form it is perpetrated, must be condemned and punished without "if "and without" but ", also here, also in Parliament. In Europe, nearly 25% of women have experienced physical or sexual violence, but the drama within the drama is that more than one in four Europeans still believe that non-consensual sexual intercourse can be somehow justified. The time is ripe to address the issue of violence against women with determination, ensuring the application of existing measures and working to ensure that the principles contained in the Istanbul Convention are rapidly incorporated into the national laws of all member countries.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, sexual harassment and abuse cannot be justified by anything.When it comes to the European Union institutions and harassment in the workplace, it is unfortunate that a major public scandal is needed for the authorities to address this problem.If it is true that this has been happening in this building for years and that victims have often been discouraged from reporting because a climate has been created in which such primitive behavior was more or less acceptable, it should be shown that it is not and must be severely punished.All those who report harassment or abuse should be maximally protected by being guaranteed that they will not lose their job due to the report, and they must be provided with professional assistance.If we want a Europe in which disadvantaged people will not be seen as a commodity and treated as unworthy of a human being, the European Parliament must lead by example and therefore responsible behavior must begin here and today.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: - Madam President! Thank you for the opportunity to speak here today. Ms. Reintke said in her speech that the problem of sexual harassment is not and should not only be an issue for women, and with that she has just hit the point: she is right. The fact that almost only female colleagues spoke today is part of the problem we are facing. Sexual harassment almost always comes from men. Therefore we men have to say: Not with us. That's why I'm here today and I wish that many more colleagues would do that today. Here in the house, too, we see what is going on and have to critically question what happened there. That we have a complaints committee that is equipped with MEPs, where women can complain if they are victims of sexual violence or the exercise of power, that cannot be the right starting point. The courage of those affected must pay off, and in addition to adopting the report tomorrow, we must continue to take action.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a useful debate has proved its worth. And yet we have gained solidarity from our fellow men who have taken the floor, but, as the Commissioner is present, we, as MEPs, need to address our countries and find synergy between non-governmental organizations, between civil society. Women who report this violence must be protected. We need projects for education, education and infrastructure, because we can not take them from family life where, sometimes, even there they suffer sexual abuse or from work if we do not find an infrastructure to shelter these women and then , legal aid: many cannot stand trial to find justice. That is why I strongly believe that we must have a partnership at national level as well. It's not enough just here. Congratulations and this is just the beginning, we must continue.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I think that every woman in this House – and quite a lot of men – have a story to tell on this, either a personal experience or someone that is close to us: stories about sexual harassment, sexist comments, and possibly even violence and rape.  This is not new. It didn’t start with the ‘Me Too’ movement. It has been going on for decades, for centuries, but the novelty this time is that there is a global movement of women crying out: ‘this is not acceptable’. Many men as well. This is not something we will continue to accept. We do not accept that this is hidden – the shame and the silence around this phenomena – and that is so powerful. That is why I thank you for this debate. There are a lot of laws in the European Union. There are projects, there are directives and there are codes of conduct. These are important. The arsenal of legal and policy measures at the EU level covers most of the actions to support Member States in their work in fighting all kinds of violence against women and girls. Now we need to focus on implementation, and here there is work to do. We also need to dedicate all our efforts to complete the accession of the Istanbul Convention.  We also need to look at ourselves. What are we doing? The Commission has a helpline. We have strong rules to protect whistle—blowers who come and alert us on this. We have a network of confidential counsellors who can support women and girls – and men – who are victims of this. We have internal campaigns and courses and formal action. We will subject all this to external evaluation. Possibly we can do more. I am sure that in the European Parliament you have your own rules and you are looking at them. Possibly you can do more on a formal basis. But the most important thing, as this campaign signals, is to support the victims, to say that what they have experienced is not OK and that we will go with them. The majority of the men in this House and elsewhere, who would never dream of harassing a woman, you need to speak out. You need to support this woman and say that what their colleague did is not OK and that they will walk with her and support her in making sure that justice is brought on this. So let’s support each other. Let’s encourage the network to function in this regard. Let’s make sure that not only is this ‘Me Too’ campaign heard all across the world, but also that it is also transformed into action, where hopefully this will eventually lead to the eradication of this violence. The problem is much broader, as we have discussed. We will do what we can from the Commission side. Member States have their role to play, but the most important is a change of attitude, and here we can all contribute.  Thank you very much for having this debate. I think it is of extreme importance, but let us not let the work stop after the vote tomorrow.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: I have received, in accordance with Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure, seven motions for resolutions.The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- This resolution condemns all forms of sexual violence and physical or psychological harassment, encouraging member states to take further measures to put an end to sexual harassment effectively.Prevention and awareness are fundamental, because we must also act against emerging forms of violence, such as those implemented online.Unfortunately, even within this Parliament there are too many cases of harassment: adequate measures are needed to combat this sad phenomenon and to support the victims.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - In the XXI century in a society as advanced as Europe, we find that sexual harassment is a common and widespread practice suffered by many women, most in silence because they feel ashamed, are afraid and do not dare to report incidents , not even to talk to those closest to you. Enough of complicit silences and unreasonable doubts, there is no valid excuse, the stalkers must be punished. Harassment has its origin in an unequal society, where one party establishes power relations over another. We need a European strategy to combat all forms of violence against women, including sexual harassment and abuse. Unfortunately, this reality does not escape from any place or space, not even from public institutions like this Parliament, which, although it has instruments to respond to such situations, are clearly not working. That is why we need external advice, to assess how these instruments can be improved so that they are really useful to the victims. Not one more attack on the dignity of women. Not a complicit silence. Not a look away. You are not alone: ​​"Me too", "Me too".

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- In my opinion, it is significant that we discuss violence against women in some form in almost every plenary session.It shows me that violence against women is still commonplace, also in Europe.Sexual harassment is mostly violence against women - positions of power are used to intimidate and suppress women.How massive the problem is, shows how often the hashtag “MeToo” was shared.I hope that we can raise awareness that sexual harassment is not a trivial offense, that we can find rules in this House that break the silence of the harassed.I hope that we will soon have a hashtag “MeNot” - under which women write that they have never been sexually molested.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written.- If anyone in the European Parliament or any other European or other institution has abused their position to the detriment of another's dignity, then both the perpetrators and those who knew and kept silent must be held accountable and severely sanctioned.Harassment at work, or anywhere else, must not and cannot be acceptable in any form.People who have experienced any form of harassment in the workplace and elsewhere should be encouraged to report the harassment to the police.It is up to the rest of us to support them and remove abusers from positions of responsibility in the European Parliament, where most perform their duties honestly, responsibly and with the invaluable help of members of their teams.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I only steal a very few seconds because I wanted to inform the House that on 17 December 2015, right here, we passed a resolution on the case of Ibrahim Halawa, an Irish citizen arrested and imprisoned in Egypt. Yesterday, after four long years of harsh detention, Ibrahim finally returned to Ireland, free. News of this kind are unfortunately rare and for this reason they must be strongly emphasized, because they represent a great sign of hope for many people: activists, human rights defenders, journalists or lawyers unjustly imprisoned everywhere. And if on the one hand we welcome the decision of the Egyptian Court of Justice to drop all the charges against Ibrahim, on the other we cannot forget the many who are still imprisoned in Egypt today. For this reason, it is imperative that the European Parliament continue to firmly ask the Egyptian government to proceed with the release of all those imprisoned solely for exercising their free right of thought, expression and association.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Mr President, yesterday we held a minute’s silence in honour of Ms Daphne Caruana Galizia. After that, I proposed that we offer a EUR 1 million prize for the murderers of Daphne Caruana Galizia, dead or alive. I was told by Mr Rainer Wieland that this was impossible because there is no provision in the budget to offer a prize for the murderers, dead or alive. I want to have a budget in which we can offer a prize for the murderers, dead or alive.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, very briefly, I would like to point out to this House that the HDP presidents' hearing will be held on 6 and 7 December next and that the European institutions are being asked to supervise the progress of these processes.At the moment there is no news on the health of President Öcalan.This House has been very concerned with Turkey and I think it must continue to concern itself with the rights of the Kurdish people.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is voting time.(For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I have to inform you of two technical corrections to be applied to two amendments on the budget tabled by the Committee on Budgets, in line with the actual committee vote. The first technical correction please is line 09047705, it is Amendment 1 735. The final level of payments should be read as: EUR 1 250 000.  The second technical correction is in line 240107, Amendment 1 838. The final total amounts, including the 10% reserve, should be at the level of the draft budget. These are the two technical corrections which I have to introduce to you ahead of the vote. Other than this, I would like to thank all colleagues who have worked on Parliament’s position on the EU budget for 2018, all shadow rapporteurs, all rapporteurs of the opinions of the specialised committee.
