It is important that we are sending today a clear and strong message to the Council by supporting the budget with a large majority. What we have agreed and what we are voting today is a budget for a strong, future-oriented Union, a Union which can offer a perspective of prosperity and safety to the citizens. So thank you very much to all colleagues who have worked and supported me in this.

name: Märt Kivine
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me congratulate the European Parliament on adopting just now the Council position on the draft budget for the financial year 2018. From the Council perspective I take note of the pertaining differences between the positions of the Council and Parliament. Therefore, in my capacity as a President of the Council I would agree that the President of the European Parliament convenes the conciliation committee, as required under Article 314 (4)(c) of the Treaty of the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – Mr President, I would like to draw your attention to, and try and get your support for, this oral amendment. I know we have the support of the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D) and the European Free Alliance Group (Verts/ALE), and this was indeed accepted by the rapporteur. It is basically concerned with peace and stability, something I think this House should be supportive of. It is highly concerned with the rise of instability and uncertainty, both within and outside the Union, and insists on the need for a renewed focus on the Union’s approach to cohesion, integration, peace, sustainable development and human rights. It calls upon the Commission and the Member States to connect and boost efforts towards further sustaining peace and conflict prevention, and recalls the worldwide inspiration brought about by the Good Friday Agreement, while acknowledging the unprecedented challenges and pressures in the aftermath of the United Kingdom 2016 referendum. It calls upon the Commission and Member States to enhance their support for reconciliation to secure peace and stability and Ireland.  I would therefore urge you, colleagues, to please support this amendment.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, on behalf of the S&D Group, under Rule 59(3) of the Parliament’s Rules of Procedure, I request that the plenary vote on the amendments before the final vote on the provisional agreement.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: speaker.- Mr President, my very brief words are not intended to limit or block the right to vote and the right to amend that all Groups in the House have.My word is simply to indicate that those who support the rapporteur and the Popular Group should vote against this claim for an elementary reason.The reason is that we would break an interinstitutional agreement that has taken four years to achieve.With just one of those amendments voted favorably, we would break the interinstitutional agreement.So please vote against that claim.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: - Mr President, I just want to denounce that precisely coinciding with the presentation of this very important report by Mrs Post, an exhibition has been put out there on the gypsies in Perpignan that reproduces all the archetypes and stereotypes that we want to abandon precisely with reports such asMrs. Post's.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: - Mr President, dear colleagues, I am the organizer of this exhibition.I invite you all to go see it, it takes place next to the Members' restaurant.For once, in the European Parliament, we will talk about the gypsies.And indeed, thanks to Marine Le Pen, there is an exhibition on the gypsies and I thank her.I invite you all to come and visit this exhibition in due time.And to those ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Soraya POST
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to express how proud I am of this Chamber today. To you who really took your responsibility as politicians to vote in favour of no more exclusion of the 12 million EU citizens with Roma ethnicity, it is a good start, taking your responsibility. Thank you very much. I would also like to thank my shadow rapporteurs – Pál Csáky, Bodil Valero, Cecilia Wikström and Marina Albiol – and all the people included in this. For me it is a step forward; thank you very much. (Applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: This concludes the voting round.(The session is suspended for a few minutes)

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, the draft budget for 2018 is, in my view, balanced and takes into account all the political priorities that the European Union wants to follow.It is about strengthening key programs for employment growth and for the growth of the European Union.At the same time, however, it continues to consider the security of the European Union and the cessation of illegal migration to be crucial.There is also a need to strengthen the immediate neighborhood programs with the European Union, to strengthen European agencies, especially those working in the field of justice and home affairs, such as Europol, Eurojust, EASO and CEPOL.Of course, a suitable increase in funding for the Internal Security Fund (ISF) and the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) is also related to this.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I also supported today the mandate for the trialogue on the 2018 budget, especially as it includes an increase in key allocations to support economic growth, job creation, increased security and protection of external borders and overall surveillance of migration.I consider this, I personally, to be very important.There is an increase in Erasmus +, Horizon 2020, EaSI, ie programs related to education, employment and social innovation.Europe for Citizens and Creative Europe is also very important in terms of citizen engagement and cultural promotion.Of course, we want to support exchanges of students, scientists, artists, but also higher employment.The increase in funding for security and migration control concerns Europol and Eurojust, as well as internal security, which I also consider to be very important.That is why I supported the budget.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: - Mr President. This is how the Commissioner for Transport spoke at the European Parliament's plenary a year ago, supporting the proposal that every young European should receive an Interail online ticket for free on their 18th birthday. Today, several million euros have been approved for this purpose. Although this project sounds tempting, I am afraid that not all the young people involved will be able to take advantage of it. Last year, I asked the Commission what it would be like for young people with disabilities. Many of them need a barrier-free environment or even an assistant. With regard to accessibility, the Commission referred in its reply to the Accessibility Directive, which, as we know, is not yet final. And when asked whether an assistant of a young person with a disability, who may not be just eighteen years old, will receive a free ticket, the Commission did not answer. Therefore, I would also like to appeal to the competent authorities not to forget in the case of this project those who, unlike many of their healthy peers, who have no problem paying for travel themselves, have not been excluded once again and pushed to the margins of interest.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, this 2018 budget fails to meet the real needs of the citizens of the Union. And the question that arises is whether this Europe is dreamed of by its citizens. A Europe where, while we all realize that it is leading to disaster, the political elite is concerned with the management, financial settlement of the Union and the Member States. Ladies and gentlemen, when balanced budgets are the only end in itself, initiative, ingenuity and innovation are destroyed. When money is a pursuit, dignity and morality are set aside. And when the sovereignty of the Member States is plundered and the homogeneity of nations is altered, Europe dies. That is why I voted against.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman!Almost 2,400 amendments were tabled and, fortunately, the budget was not damaged by these amendments.It is on the verge of a miracle, it was a great job of the Committee on Budgets, but also of us here in this plenary hall.What I am most pleased about is that the overall budget has been increased by just 2 billion, as well as by 2 billion in commitments, which are the most frequently due liabilities.This is a minor correction when looking at a budget of EUR 164 billion.However, what I am most happy about is what my friend Šojdrová said, i.e. saving the Erasmus + scholarship program, which not only was saved, but its condition was improved.Creative Europe has also been successful in this respect in three key sub-programs, ie it has defended itself.And the pilot programs - only 4 out of 16 were not approved, but I would like to thank you very much for these 12.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Mr President, as every year, we address the budget of the European Union and, as every year, I vote against it again, and the reasons for voting against are accumulating. This budget does not meet the objectives of growth and employment, much less quality employment. It does not serve to correct the negative effect of the cuts - the misnamed "austerity" - and this budget will not solve the problems of social or territorial cohesion either. Furthermore, existing imbalances are being reinforced. They will tell me that the budget of the European Union does not finance social protection expenses, but supposedly neither does it finance defense and, nevertheless, the items of investment in defense and military spending are growing. They tell us that there are no more resources, that the existing ones have to be adjusted but, nevertheless, defense spending is new, in the interests of supposed security. Security is achieved with quality employment and rights, with budgets for social inclusion, with public policies, working to end poverty and inequalities, but for this there is nothing new in this budget.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this document, agreeing especially with the rapporteur’s reservations regarding the Commission’s cuts foreseen under Heading 4 expenditure (global Europe). Such reductions, I am afraid, are in contradiction with the EU objectives set out in its global strategy. We have to find the resources to be allocated from the EU budget in order to address the newly arising challenges when there are direct repercussions on our long-term security. One such complex challenge is the information warfare. Therefore, via the budgetary procedure, I, along with other colleagues, called for the allocation of adequate resources for the development of such capabilities – both inside the European Union (strengthening the external service StratCom team), and via the delegations of the EU’s Eastern Neighbourhood and the Western Balkans.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, I voted against the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2018, because it does not meet the needs that exist today in European society. First of all, it does not have the funds to tackle unemployment, especially youth unemployment. Secondly, it does not regulate issues related to inequality, poverty, social exclusion. It does not take steps to bring the regions together. In addition, it has funds for Turkey, a country that threatens the national security of Greece, violates Greek airspace, has set as its main element the casus belli against Greece and has occupied 37% of the territory of the Republic of Cyprus. At the same time, the budget strengthens Albania, a country that is aggressive towards Greece and oppresses the rights of the Greek national minority in the Northern Epirus.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Mr President, yesterday Mr Timmermans presented the Commission's work program for 2018 under the motto 'A program for a stronger, united and democratic Europe'. I do not see exactly how Europe will become more united and democratic, since programs like Erasmus +, Creative Europe and Europe for Citizens are chronically underfunded. Erasmus + is the European Union's most successful program, however, the EUR 50 million agreed in the 2018-2020 budget in the revision of the multiannual financial framework is not included in the 2018 draft budget. The political commitment to strategic investment in young people seems to be people are just empty words. In addition, funding for the new European Solidarity Corps is again coming mainly from the Erasmus + program. I am convinced of the added value for young people of volunteering initiatives, but when Mr Juncker launches new initiatives, I urge him to make sure that they are not to the detriment of Erasmus +, a program that is already underfunded.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Mr President, today I have voted for those elements of the budget that provide strong support to the programmes, from which the United Kingdom benefits most and which contribute to a strong, sustainable and stable Europe. The Parliament’s budget sets the framework for further negotiations between the European Union institutions. I have voted to restore cuts proposed by the Council, which fell disproportionately on areas from which world-leading UK institutions gain substantial benefit. I voted to support Labour Party priorities, such as tackling youth unemployment, strengthening research and boosting programmes such as Horizon 2020, from which UK organisations are leading beneficiaries. The budget proposals, for which I have voted, continue to strengthen the EU’s negotiating response to the challenges of migration and security. I have voted against increasing the administrative budgets of the Parliament and Commission. I believe there is considerable scope for savings, not least through the creation of a single-seat Parliament. I have also voted for greater transparency for MEPs, the Labour MPs, implement ourselves, if we can, you can.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I supported this draft budget for the trialogue mandate. I want to say that this is, in my opinion, the maximum possible. It is a compromise that responds in part to the new challenges facing Europe, while being based on the rules of the multiannual financial framework. When the multiannual financial framework is changed, we may perhaps reflect more of the new challenges facing Europe in a concrete draft budget. It is an area of ​​law and security, in particular the protection of external borders and terrorism security in general, the strengthening of activities that contribute to the security of European citizens. Towards a democratization of Europe: the Erasmus program, the European Solidarity Corps, has already been mentioned here. These are, of course, good initiatives; it would be better if more money were found for them. Unfortunately, this is not the case today. I would like to say that I acknowledge with gratitude that cohesion policy has not been fundamentally weakened in this budget.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman!This is a bit of a pretext, but I would like to draw your attention to the way in which this case is handled - a matter related to occupational safety.The Commission has made a good proposal, a moderate one that is spread over time, but in the course of the negotiations changes were made quite suddenly, which for many economic actors is a disaster.The time needed to adjust the conditions of performing a specific job is shorter, the expectations regarding protection in the workplace are increasing, and as a result, economic entities are surprised by the suddenness of the situation, announced in the official messages as much milder.Once again, I would like to draw attention to the fact that, as parliamentarians, we should work in such a way that economic actors, citizens of the European Union, are not surprised by our decisions.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Mr President, I supported this report because I believe that workers must be provided with normal and safe working conditions. This includes protecting workers from the risks associated with exposure to carcinogens and mutagens at work. Cancer is the second most common cause of death in Europe and the most common cause of death related to work. All cancers in this regard are preventable. Having an up-to-date and precise legislative framework in the European Union will contribute to better prevention of this type of work-related illness. The annual cost to Member States is estimated at € 334 billion. I consider the attitude of my colleagues from the center-right political groups to be unworthy, who considered the proposed standards and working conditions in the agricultural sector to be too high and voted against a text in defense of those who are building European agriculture. The adopted report is a step in the right direction.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, I think we are living in the 21st century, so it is important not to rely on passport stamps, but to create a new electronic system that controls the entry and exit of third-country nationals into the European Union.In my opinion, this system, as it was designed and approved, will help make Europe a relatively stable and strong port.It will help to make people feel safe here and to avoid the case of some people who have entered the European Union illegally on fourteen different documents and have stayed there longer than they are entitled to under European law.That is why I supported this report, and I think that this is a good step towards ensuring the security of the citizens of the European Union.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, I voted against this proposal. Attempts to shore up the external borders of the European Union are a classic case of trying to close the stable well after the horse has bolted. The inability of the European Union to shore up its borders during the migrant crisis has ensured that there are already millions of migrants in the European Union, broadly unchecked and unverified, able to float around the continent causing potentially great societal damage. This attempt by the European Union to introduce chip technology at the borders will cost billions, be a nightmare to manage and leave the security of the European Union wide open to cyberattack. And what’s the point, anyway? The migrants are already here.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I would like to explain why I supported the new regulation establishing the entry and exit system.This regulation introduces a number of measures, such as extending the retention period for stored data to up to five years.It uses, of course, new modern digital technologies.I believe that this new system will really improve the management of the external borders and ensure a higher level of internal security, thus reducing illegal migration.It will also ensure the provision of accurate information on persons exceeding the length of authorized stay.On the contrary, it will facilitate the entry into the territory of the European Union for legal passengers.This should, of course, reduce the time to check them in.I believe that the launch of this entry-exit system could be an important step towards restoring the confidence of European Union citizens in their security.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, I voted against the introduction of an entry-exit system because the test response to the needs created by reality is not covered by the Commission's actions. The proposed entry-exit system needs a comprehensive review, as does the Schengen Agreement. It is not enough to create a register of third-country nationals, to tighten border crossing procedures, to make systems interoperable and accessible, even by law enforcement authorities. In addition, there is an urgent need to restore control of the Union's internal borders and a comprehensive review of the Schengen Agreement as the first necessary steps in the fight against illegal immigration, terrorism, jihad and cross-border organized crime.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Mr President, I appreciate the support of my group for the implementation of this regulation and at the external borders of the Union, not just Schengen. However, a compromise involving only members in the application of the Schengen acquis is not acceptable, and not those in the process of meeting the Schengen criteria. This proposal excludes Croatia, the youngest member with the longest external border, after Croatia successfully implemented the Schengen Information System in June. Since then, Croatian border services have conducted 74 million inspections and detected over 4,000 perpetrators of various offenses in EU member states. The application of such a regulation prevents a change in the validity of a Schengen visa, which Croatia recognizes as equivalent to Croatia. Due to the impossibility of insight into the new system, the Croatian border services could miss a person with an invalid visa. Joining Schengen is Croatia's strategic goal. We expect the successful fulfillment of all criteria next year. Therefore, but also due to the principle of equality of citizens, this proposal should cover all members from the beginning of implementation. Security should be available to all our citizens without exception.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, I voted against the entry-exit system into the European Union, first of all because I believe that it robs the sovereign rights of the Member States, without them even having their consent, without the consent of the national parliaments. I think it is important for the states themselves to be able to safeguard their borders and this is not a right that can be delegated to the European Union. In addition, I consider it the exclusive right of states to clarify which third-country nationals can enter their territory with or without a visa. This system robs us of all these state rights. In addition, we have a system here where, in practice, the European Union will determine which third-country nationals will have a visa requirement and which will not. Let me remind you that recently the European Union said that Kosovars do not need a visa when entering the European Union, at a time when we know that Kosovo is the wasp nest of jihadists.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, in my opinion, security is really one of the key areas of the European Union that we need to pay attention to. The management of the external borders and the system connected to it is an essential part of it. Within the Schengen area, it is desirable to create a uniform system with electronic recording of the exact time and place of entry and exit of third-country nationals into the European area, granting short-term residence permits and monitoring compliance with their length of stay. Those known excesses of entry for forged passports and exceeding the permitted length of stay should be suppressed by this proposal. I'm not saying it will disappear completely, but it is undoubtedly a step in the right direction. I also believe that it should be made clear which authorities in each Member State will have real access to the system. The processing of data should be proportionate to its purpose so that competences are not exceeded.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, the current EU border control system is inadequate to meet the challenge of the ever-growing traveller flow to the Schengen area, with the expected number of arrivals by third country nationals on short-term visits estimated at up to 300 million by 2025. Therefore, I congratulate the authors of this proposal, which is aimed at improving and modernising traveller management systems. Establishing a European Entry/Exit System to register travellers’ data will both enable tighter border security and reduce waiting time for bone fide passengers. Needless to say, this system will allow the EU to manage immigration better and will indicate transnational threats – ultimately resulting in improved internal security. At the same time, we must not forget proportionality, and we must carefully set the time frame for how long personal data can be held in the system, in order to protect people’s privacy.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I supported this regulation, which relates to modernization and also to the security of protection and control at the borders of the Schengen area.This Regulation on the Schengen Borders Code specifies specific requirements in the entry and exit system, specifies the requirements for the categories entered in the system, its technical structure, the rules concerning its operation, use, interoperability with other information systems in the Member States.I also appreciate the introduction of standards for automated border control systems, which increases the requirements for sufficient quality of the data collected for use in the automated comparison of biometrics, such as the face, fingerprints.In any case, it is about improving the quality of the control and protection of the Schengen area.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman!I have stressed many times that there is no dilemma as to what is more important: the physical security of citizens or the security of personal data of the same citizens, that these two elements must be taken equally seriously and are mutually necessary for each other.I am also talking about this today because this proposal to keep flight data for 3 years for all those who have obtained the right to stay and 5 years for those who did not, in the first element is correct, in the latterthe proposed period may be too short.Especially that we must remember that refusals to grant a visa, stay in the European Union are different - from time to time purely technical, and from time to time related to evidence of contacts with terrorist groups.I believe that in the latter case, this time should be much longer.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, I voted against the report because I believe that Greece's participation in Schengen turns my country into a magnet for thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants to come, all of whom believe that they can reach the other Schengen-type transit documents through Greece. countries of the European Union. The question is why thousands of refugees risked drowning in the Aegean in order to come to the Aegean islands and did not go to Bulgaria by land. For the simple reason that Bulgaria was not a member of Schengen. Therefore, as long as Greece remains in Schengen, it will be a magnet for thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants to come. I therefore consider it necessary for Greece to leave Schengen. In this way it will cease to be a magnet for refugees and illegal immigrants and will thus be able to deal with the situation that has been created. In Greece we now have thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants and Greece can no longer stand this situation.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I agree with the proposal, although I have had different votes in some small cases, which may not be entirely small, and they should probably be mentioned here. I am not of the opinion that the data retention periods for residence permits or even non-residence permits are sufficient. In my opinion, they should be at least doubled, because the protection of personal data cannot definitely outweigh the interest in keeping these records. In my opinion, it is important that these deadlines be extended, because it is about the safety of citizens. Furthermore, for the system to function properly, it is essential that the appropriate technical standards are adopted and subsequently complied with, and that a sufficient number of staff are provided to assist in automated border control. It is also appropriate that sufficient money be set aside in the budget for this purpose, otherwise it will not be possible to implement these measures.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, if we really want to include the Roma and we really want to do something about the Roma issue, we need to change our approach to the Roma issue.We need to place more responsibility on the Roma themselves, not on us trying to forcibly integrate them into the majority society.I worked with the Roma for several years.At present, as an MEP, I am still trying to continue this work.I see that many Roma have also understood that external motivations stink.That is why we need to really motivate these people to want to study, learn and be part of our society.The Roma are skilled people, many Roma are very well educated, but without giving impetus and acknowledging their diversity, inclusion will not be possible.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, Roma are part of Europe's culture and values, but we all know that there is latent hostility towards Roma, at all levels of European society and in all geographical areas of Europe. I therefore voted in favor of this resolution, recognizing that Roma must be considered vulnerable and that the European Union's Charter of Fundamental Rights prohibits any form of discrimination. The special case of women and girls who are victims of discrimination, which feeds a vicious circle of inequality, exclusion and marginalization, must be carefully monitored and tackled. In fact, in 2016, only 16% of Roma women had jobs, 72% of Roma girls did not study or work and 71% of Roma women between the ages of 18 and 24 left education or training early. Ladies and gentlemen, this resolution that we are adopting today expresses deep concern about discrimination against Roma and proposes relevant measures for Roma access to healthcare, social services, education, justice, employment opportunities and housing. I believe that the implementation of these actions is undoubtedly an expression of a just, humanistic and inclusive Europe.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - Whether we recognize it or not, the Roma are, of course, an important part of European culture and values and, of course, they also contribute to the recognition of cultural wealth, the common history of the Union.That is why, of course, it is very important what kind of relationship and what kind of coexistence we create with this community in different parts of the European Union, that is, in different countries.Above all, I am in favor and I think that it is also very important to refrain from any kind of violence and to try to prevent violence against the Roma community and to encourage young people to understand that the Roma are also part of the wider European area.not only cultural but also coexistence culture, which is also a feature of the European Union.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: This concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the fight against illegal immigration and the smuggling of people into the Mediterranean area.Thematic debate (Rule 153a) (2017/2898 (RSP)) I would like to inform my Members that this debate does not apply to the catch-the-eye procedure and does not accept blue cards.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking to the Commission, I am speaking to this crowded Chamber: there are 26 of us, I do not know if they are following us from home, so obviously the subject of illegal immigration warms the hearts of fellow MEPs. I will try to repeat what we as a Lega and as Italian MEPs have been repeating for some years, with little success: these absent and unsuccessful policies on illegal immigration are doing the harm of the European peoples and the evil of the African peoples. Whoever is governing Europe, with the complicity of some governments - including the Italian one - is serving the interests of the mafias, smugglers, slaveholders and multinational exploiters. Let's talk about numbers: in the last three years at least 15,000 people have died in the Mediterranean, more than 600,000 alleged refugees have landed in Italy alone, who are not refugees, 30,000 children have disappeared feeding a prostitution market that now knows no rules , and after three years we find ourselves talking about what we should do. What should we do? Europe does not do it, national governments will do it, including the Italian one, if the League wins the elections: protect the borders; cut off contacts between NGO vessels - which this European institution continues to finance - with smugglers; guaranteeing legal and positive immigration quotas for those men and women who really bring added value to our societies, as it works in Canada, Australia, Switzerland and developed countries. For the moment we are importing slaves, slackers or thugs. In Tunisia in 2017 more than 4 000 offenders were released from prison thanks to the prizes and pardons of the Tunisian authorities. Well, these are all arriving in Italy. Italy has the record of Tunisian prisoners: 67% of Tunisian prisoners from all over Europe are in Italy. So beyond the Mediterranean the galleys open and we in Italy open the doors of our house. I hope that this Commission will wake up, I am not so convinced, and at this point we will do it, facilitating the arrival of women and children who really flee from war - women and children, who around Italy and Europe they are not seen, or are seen too little - and, above all, by facilitating the arrival of legal immigration from the countries closest to our values, and I am thinking of countries with a Christian culture. Here everyone's rights are guaranteed, even today Roma rights have been dealt with, because if every month in Strasbourg, Roma rights are not dealt with, someone is not happy. I remember that Islamic countries adopt a declaration of Islamic human rights which provides that justice is applied only on the basis of what the Islamic law provides, which provides that freedom of thought is applied only within the limits of what is provided for by Islamic law , that with regard to gender equality, about which so much is rightly written, in marriage, in article 19 of the Islamic declaration of human rights, it is said that men have a certain supremacy over women. So: I'll put you in jail if Islamic law allows me, you can say what you want if Islamic law allows it, man and woman have the same rights but the man is worth a little more. I think the time has come to re-establish the rules for those who want to enter Europe: he must do it legally, he must do it positively. For the rest there is the rule of expulsion, refoulement, defense of borders. If the European Commission or the European Union do not want to do it because they respond to the interests and logic of multinationals, the peoples will do it, who wake up and vote in Germany, Holland, France, Austria and soon also in Italy.

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, speaking in this very room yesterday, the President of the European Council, President Tusk, said that protecting our external border is the cornerstone of resolving the migration crisis. There are many aspects to this, but the fight against irregular migration and people smuggling has been at the forefront of agendas of both the European Council and the Council for a while now.  It remains at the top of our agenda even though we have seen a dramatic reduction of almost 70% in the number of irregular migrants since spring 2016. Our aim is to ensure the effective control of our external borders and stem illegal flows into the EU. We are determined to break the business model of smugglers and reduce the high number of human beings losing their lives while crossing the Mediterranean Sea in unseaworthy boats and flimsy dinghies. To achieve these aims, we reaffirm our commitment to strong cooperation with international partners, as well as with countries of origin, transit and destination. On both the central and the eastern Mediterranean migratory routes, the EU and its Member States have taken decisive action to reach these objectives. Since spring 2016, we have implemented the EU—Turkey statement to address the flows from Turkey into Greece. We have taken a number of measures to reduce the irregular migratory flows, to break the business model of smugglers and human traffickers, and to advance the effectiveness of returns.  At the peak of the crisis, in October 2015, 216 000 arrivals from Turkey to the EU were registered over a period of one month. Subsequently, average monthly arrivals into the EU in the period from April 2016 to September 2017 were reduced to 2 465. On the central Mediterranean route, we commend the significant contribution made by Italy, including on a bilateral level. Over the summer, a number of initiatives were taken by the Presidency, the Member States and the Commission to complement the bilateral actions taken by Italy. I refer here in particular to the Commission’s Action Plan of 4 July and the respective Presidency implementation plan.  Let me highlight some of the achievements so far. We have intensified efforts to train the Libyan coastguard so that the Government of National Accord can improve the control of its territorial waters. The extension of the mandate of EUNAVFOR MED operation Sophia until 31 August 2018 enables us to continue this task in a sustainable way. In the EUR 46 million EU Trust Fund programme for border and migration management in Libya, adopted in July this year, about EUR 30 million are dedicated to the training, equipment and maintenance needs of the coastguard. We continue to promote the development of local communities across the migratory routes in Libya. Under the EU Emergency Trust Fund for Africa, projects worth EUR 42 million have been contracted for this purpose. Since last year, we have more than doubled our financial support for the work carried out by UNHCR and IOM to provide adequate reception conditions for migrants and persons falling under the international protection mandate in Libya, and to coordinate assisted voluntary returns from Libya and Niger to countries of origin. We wish to reinforce our support to the most vulnerable groups by setting up a voluntary resettlement scheme, as presented by the Commission in September in its recommendation on enhancing legal pathways for persons in need of international protection.  Six countries along the central Mediterranean route are among priority countries for resettlement, including Libya. Some Member States have already submitted ambitious pledges. There are many more strands that we are working on. I think it is important to bear in mind that they are nearly all medium- to long—term measures, for which patience and resilience by the EU are required.  Another limitation we should take into account is the unstable political and security situation in Libya, preventing our full presence in the EU delegation and EU Border Assistance Mission in Tripoli and in the field. We are working very closely with our Libyan interlocutors to bring about change in this country. In addition, our aim is to intensify our cooperation and, based on the European Council conclusions from 19 October this year, to rapidly establish a permanent EU presence in Libya.  Let me mention some of the actions to fight people smuggling. In the framework of the Malta Declaration of 3 February 2017, we now have a very efficient system for the monitoring of departure points in third countries. Furthermore, the identification, detection and tracking of suspicious vessels has improved. Frontex complements the EUNAVFOR MED operation Sophia, to which it provides solid intelligence.  Europol’s European Migrant Smuggling Centre focuses its activities on the central Mediterranean route in order to target and disrupt supplies to smugglers. In an effort to further disrupt the business model of people smugglers and human traffickers, the Council introduced restrictions on the export and supply to Libya of inflatable boats, also known as dinghies, and outboard motors. Finally, the Council adopted the EU’s priorities for the fight against organised and serious international crime between 2018 and 2021. This was done in May 2017. They will include the fight against the facilitation of irregular immigration.  In conclusion, despite the encouraging developments mentioned, the EU remains vigilant on all migration routes and continues a comprehensive, pragmatic and resolute approach by using all the relevant EU policies, instruments and tools.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the fight against illegal immigration and people smuggling is, and remains, one of the key features of our comprehensive migration policy. As outlined in the mid—term review of the European Agenda on Migration, the implementation of the Action Plan on Smuggling adopted in May 2015 and of the measures to address illegal immigration remains a priority. We all know that while the irregular flows towards Europe are decreasing overall, we have to remain vigilant. This is why we will pursue our actions to build a proper management of migratory flows to the EU to prevent irregular immigration and fight smugglers. To tackle illegal immigration along the central Mediterranean, cooperation with the Libyan authorities remains an important element. The training and equipment of the Libyan coastguard prevents illegal immigration and helps save lives at sea. This year alone, the Libyan coastguard brought back to the Libyan shores more than 16 000 migrants. The EU has also engaged with the Libyan authorities to allow international organisations, mainly the IOM and the UNHCR, to assist vulnerable migrants in Libya before they embark to Europe. As a result, this year the IOM has assisted 8438 migrants to return safely to their countries of origin. The Commission also supports the UNHCR’s plan to evacuate vulnerable migrants out of Libya for onward resettlement.  We also continue to help Sahel countries to better manage the borders and enforce their capacities in relation to the fight against migrant smuggling and trafficking of human beings. The Niger Project is very encouraging. More than 100 offenders have been arrested and brought to justice in the first half of 2017. More generally, in the first quarter of this year, we proposed a revision of Immigration Liaison Officers Regulation to support actions to counter migrant smuggling in third countries. This will allow exploiting the full potential of the network of European immigration liaison officers, who have been deployed in 12 priority countries to coordinate closely the work of Member States on the ground. To prevent smuggling and illegal immigration, we also have to use all our leverage to improve the readmission rates of countries of origin and show more solidarity with Africa to address the root causes of migration. To this effect, EUR 2.85 billion has been made available by the EU Trust Fund for Africa. The refugees who need protection will be offered alternative solutions to smuggling. By enhancing safe and legal pathways, persons in need of protection will no longer have to rely on smugglers and risk their lives to find protection in the EU. This is why the Commission recommends that Member States increase their resettlement efforts by at least 50 000 persons over the next two years. We are also exploring how we could enhance the legal pathways for migrants who are not in need of protection. The Commission is ready to coordinate pilot projects with select third countries in 2018. Moreover, to clamp down on migrant smuggling networks, Member States need to increase their capacity to investigate this crime, for which timely and practical information sharing is key. National investigators must talk to each other and fully use the resources provided by the European Migrant Smuggling Centre at Europol. Indeed, the European Migrant Smuggling Centre at Europol, launched in 2016, has shown substantial added value in providing operational support to Member States in fighting smuggling. It has provided support and conducted proactive high—profile investigations against criminal networks, with 68 cases reported this year so far, and 93 cases in its first year of operation leading to 147 arrests in 2016, and over 167 so far. Finally, we must address all the factors in our system that fuel irregular immigration, such as undeclared labour, by better enforcing the Employers Sanctions Directive. To conclude, let me stress that we will continue to fight this ruthless business in order to save lives, to prevent irregular immigration, and to provide protection for those in need.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, trafficking in human beings in the Mediterranean continues to be a highly lucrative organized crime business, with a turnover of between € 5 billion and € 6 billion a year, and plays a catalytic role in . It is tragic that the Mediterranean has in recent years become a place of exploitation of human misery in the worst possible way. There are 22.5 thousand deaths and disappearances of migrants worldwide from the beginning of 2014 to June 2017, while most deaths are recorded in the Mediterranean. Last year they even reached 5,143, the largest number recorded annually since 2000 until today. My country, Greece, due to its geographical location is a crossroads in the smuggling of people and, despite the initiatives that have been taken, which are important, we have not yet managed to control the phenomenon. In August, September and October alone, more than 10,000 people arrived on the Greek islands. It is worth noting that traffickers are rapidly changing routes while organizing and advertising on the Internet. That is why the fight against the crime of human trafficking is achieved mainly by limiting the demand from the migrants themselves. The development of legal routes to Europe is the only appropriate way to achieve this and we strongly support this effort. Strengthening cooperation with third countries of origin and transit, renegotiating Dublin and promoting a European refugee resettlement framework are at the heart of our efforts. Solidarity, mutual trust in the exchange of information and effective co-operation between law enforcement authorities is the key to bringing this criminal and repulsive phenomenon under control. As long as agree that the responsibility belongs to all of us.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, sometimes democracy has these things. With the democratic rules of this Parliament, the Group proposing this debate, which sits here primarily to try to end the European Union, has the possibility of proposing a debate whose approach is absolutely regrettable, morally unworthy, xenophobic, racist and deeply anti-European . The very title of the debate distills anti-immigration ideology and tries to place the framework of the discussion in terms that the Socialist Group, of course, rejects. Some believe that by calling immigration "illegal" they are categorizing human beings themselves, as if there were categories of "legal persons" and "illegal persons." You see, gentlemen proponents, there is no fight against immigration. Immigration is regulated, managed, ordered, and injustice is fought; and they fight for the dignity of human beings who are forced to migrate. Tell the truth. Immigration is not a crisis at this time. Immigration has made this continent and many others, it is an eternal human phenomenon, and what you have to do is order it, not fight against human beings. We, the Socialist Group, are not going to be intimidated by the debates that you propose, because they seem to us the worst version of politics, the one that feeds on spreading falsehoods, on spreading fear to try to get some electoral revenue. We are here to save the values ​​that you fight, the values ​​of solidarity, the rule of law, the dignity of people, international conventions, of which we are all signatories. Europe is not being invaded. Europe needs immigration, even if you don't want to understand it.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is certainly one of the most important debates of the mandate.What good is such a debate if we cannot bring the contradiction?I wanted to ask a "blue card" question, which was forbidden to me.So, ultimately, you stay with each other.We are not here in a democracy.You stay on clichés.I believe in defending nations today against this immigration problem and I am truly appalled that we cannot intervene.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: For your information, Mr Ferrand, this decision by which this debate - yesterday was another debate where the same thing was applied - takes place without 'catch the eye' and without blue cards is a decision taken unanimously by the leaders of all political groups,and I have received this notice, which I am obliged to inform you at the beginning of the debate, so that everyone may know what the rules of the game are today.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - (NL) Mr President, colleagues, the NVA has been arguing for pushbacks at sea for some time now. We do not want boat people to be automatically brought to the EU. We do not want illegal access to Europe being rewarded with a right of residence and all kinds of benefits. By the way, pushbacks were possible in the Mediterranean before 2012, but in 2012 the European Court of Human Rights put an end to that. This is how the dogma of the right to asylum in Europe arose. This makes it almost impossible for Frontex to guard European borders and stop the influx. In addition, the European Parliament recently decided to oblige member states to transfer 200,000 refugees from the Middle East each year. It was also decided that no pressure should be put in exchange to conclude a take-back agreement. This means that illegal immigrants and / or criminals cannot be returned. The vote on this in the Committee on Home Affairs was not quite according to the rules - thanks to the left, which otherwise always insists on respect for those rules. And while there are voices in Germany and Austria to impose an absolute maximum limit on the reception of refugees - something the N-VA has been advocating for years and also an idea that is invariably dismissed as impossible by left-wing politicians, but now nevertheless makes its appearance, albeit only in national politics for the time being. Fortunately, we can still count on the Member States for more realism.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, let us be very clear on a number of points. First of all, despite all problems and challenges in Europe, we are on the best continent – one of the best places – on the planet in which to live. This is naturally why a lot of people from all around the world would like to make our continent their home, in order to enjoy the freedom and prosperity that we all enjoy and that exist here. Let us also be clear that this has not always been the situation. From the mid-1800s until 1920, about 1.5 million people from my country, Sweden, or at that time one third of the population, left for the USA in order to escape difficulties such as religious persecution and poverty. Secondly, human beings are migratory to the very core of our nature. If we see no prospect for the future where we are, we move. Nevertheless, in the EU, we must obviously have a policy of regulated migration for the foreseeable future. Anything else would be irresponsible, but it would be equally irresponsible to cut ourselves off from the rest of the world: we all live in a globalised village today. The right to asylum and international protection is an individual human right that every Member State of the Union has signed up to defend. The only way to find out if a person qualifies for international protection is for them to go through the asylum process. Everyone that asks for asylum has the right to apply, but not everyone has the right to obtain international protection (asylum). Public support for the asylum system will depend on our ability to complete the ongoing work on the common European asylum system, so as to put the EU’s house in order and make sure that the procedures are fair and efficient throughout all the Member States. We must also do much better in returning those who do not qualify for international protection in a dignified manner. That would restore the credibility of the system. The most important measure to discourage people from dangerous trips across the Mediterranean would be to say that it is difficult to obtain international protection. There are no shortcuts here: only hard work. We need to put a resilient common European asylum system in place, and once again to deserve the respect – and live up to the expectations – of the citizens out there.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to ask the Commission and the Council three questions about the battle to stop the arrival of forced migrants in Europe. The first concerns the priority fight against smugglers, agreed with Libya, Niger and Chad. We begin to know the outcome: frightened by the Nigerian authorities, the smugglers dump migrants in the desert or lead them on roads where there is no water. The result is that the deaths in the desert increase exponentially, they do not reach the Mediterranean. According to Danziger, IOM responsible for Central West Africa, there are now double the deaths at sea, about 30,000 in four years. The second question concerns the Libyan coast, where gang warfare reigns. How to distinguish the smuggler from the militias or coast guards that the Union and Italy form and pay? According to the UN High Commissioner, the abuses in detention centers are appalling. The third question concerns the guarantees on UNHCR assistance in Libya. According to the High Commissioner in Tripoli, assistance is more than precarious. Libya has not signed the Geneva Convention, nor does it have a memorandum with the UNHCR. For this Africa, transformed into our prison, for these dead, the Union is responsible. I think one day we will pay for the sins we are staining ourselves with. I would like to say something to Mr Salvini that you know: you have more support in the EU than you say you have.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - (NL) Mr President, I would like to address Mr Salvini, a colleague who started the debate here. Mr Salvini, your country is a big exporter of tomatoes and we in the rest of Europe, we cook with those tomatoes. I just checked: in a supermarket in the Netherlands a can of peeled tomatoes costs 39 cents. But it can be even cheaper. A small tin of tomato paste to make the sauce really tasty costs 18 cents. And why am I telling you this? Because last week, a prosecutor in Italy sentenced a farmer in southern Italy to the manslaughter of a migrant worker, a man from Sudan, Mr. Abdullah Mohammed, who had a heart attack while picking tomatoes. He picked those tomatoes under terrible conditions, seven days a week, twelve hours a day, in the sun. If you know that, and you know that there is no real labor inspection in agriculture in Italy, and we all only pay 39 cents a can of tomatoes, then I think the real problem in fighting irregular migration and smuggling is the fact that we are not want to pay for our products, that we do not check them. The only way to keep those products cheap is to exploit people. And you nod. I'm glad about that. But it is your profit and it is your labor inspectors who do not come to see it. If we want to do something about irregular migration, we will have to pay people properly and increase control. Until that happens, there is a huge pull factor that will not go away.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: for the EFDD Group. - Mr President! In Sweden we call them undocumented. People who have had their asylum application rejected and would have left our country, preferably the day before yesterday. The word undocumented can easily confuse, they have received paper after paper that they have had their asylum application rejected. These people who should have left our countries get, hear and be amazed, access to our welfare such as health care, dental care and in some cases income support, many times more beneficial than our poor pensioners who are struggling. A reform that we in the Sweden Democrats are alone in wanting to repeal. We know that these people go underground and are often impossible to deport. They live in a shadow society where we know that many of them work illegally, commit crimes and commit terrorism. Just look at who carried out the terrorist attack in Stockholm this spring where five people lost their lives. The person lived illegally in Sweden and became radicalized. The authorities had no control over the person in question. Each Member State must speed up deportations, otherwise the risks I mentioned earlier will increase. We must also do better to keep those who have had their asylum application rejected detained. Sweden can and should not be an ATM for all the world's fortune seekers. The Swedish government should act much tougher immediately, otherwise we in the Sweden Democrats will replace them next year and do the job ourselves!

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, last Thursday the LIBE committee adopted a dangerous report by Mrs Wikström, which will soon be debated in plenary. The purpose of this text is to modify the famous Dublin regulation, currently "Dublin III", which provides, in particular, for asylum seekers to be taken care of by the first country in which they arrive. So today, if an illegal immigrant arrives, for example, in Italy, it is Italy that processes his request. If the same illegal immigrant subsequently arrives in France, the latter has the right to request his deportation to Italy. With this report, the regulation would turn into an automatic mechanism for distributing illegal immigrants. This "Dublin IV" would thus provide that a candidate for asylum is offered four countries in which he could settle while awaiting the processing of his application. The mere fact that asylum seekers can choose the state in which their claim will be processed is, strictly speaking, ludicrous. Are they really fleeing war on a transitional basis as claimed or do they simply want to choose the most advantageous social system? Ms Wikström’s report ultimately aims to establish a real right of asylum à la carte. Asylum has been misled, it is completely distorted by increasingly flexible and lax criteria, and has unfortunately become a full-fledged channel of illegal immigration. I would like to end by responding briefly to Ms. Valenciano. By your words, you have demonstrated that your approach is purely ideological, that the simple fact of describing reality is absolutely unbearable for you and that you and the group you represent have no solution to solve the problem of illegal immigration to Europe.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: I call on all colleagues to try to stay focused on the substantive issues in our debate and to avoid addressing as many colleagues as possible.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - President! It follows from the subject that we cannot fully comply with the President's request, because here the past and the future are fighting here. The past, when politicians and so-called intellectuals who professed to be left-wing and liberal, became accustomed to them being told by their telling people, their minds, on the issue of migration. The future, however, is what is happening today, with our Italian fellow Members speaking here honestly, reflecting the experiences and opinions of the majority of the European population, and joined by Swedes and others. Here are the Visegrad Four, here is my country, Hungary. We say that, yes, Europe's external borders must be protected, yes, migration must be tackled at the roots and there, locally. We thank you for the amount of support we receive as Hungarians to protect our country and Europe, and we are glad that we have more and more allies.

name: Barbara KUDRYCKA
text: - Mr Chairman! Today we are talking about fighting smugglers, destroying boats, breaking down smugglers' nets. After more than one and a half years of operation of the European Center for the Fight against Migrant Smuggling, we can congratulate Europol, Frontex and the national border services on the results of their joint work. However, smuggling is not the source of the problem, but a result of the previous lack of a comprehensive approach to the issue of migration, especially in terms of effective treatment of the causes of mass departures from the country of origin. Therefore, it is good that a lot has started to change in this matter. There is also no doubt that the migratory pressure has decreased significantly in the last year. So it is clear that European migration management is starting to show success. It's a good sign. It is most important, however, that we continue our joint efforts in those areas where we all agree - that is, the effective protection of the Union's external borders: financial as well as personal and professional support for border countries, the implementation of return programs and the European strategy for Africa. The latter is especially important. According to UNHCR, many sub-Saharan Africans would not have embarked on the extremely dangerous journey to Libya and further to Europe if they had known the magnitude of the risks and available protection programs. That is why all measures based on the Trust Fund for Africa are so badly needed. Above all, the Trust Fund for Africa should also help to improve conditions in the Libyan camps, which are indeed dramatic. We cannot be deaf to reported cases of violence, rape, torture, and repeated violations of human rights. Therefore, the activities of international non-governmental organizations in these camps should be supported. If we are doing so much to tackle the immigration crisis, we can do it too.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Together we want to restrict irregular migration in the EU, at best prevent it. That is why, in addition to a common asylum policy, we need a migration policy that allows legal immigration. It's good for both sides. It enables us to control and shows people who are looking for a better future for themselves and their children with us, a possible path. This path does not always work - maybe not the first time - but it is an alternative to the often hopeless attempt to obtain asylum or, above all, to risk one's own life while fleeing. We need a policy that combats the causes of flight and migration. The sustainable fight against the causes of displacement such as climate disasters, instability and war-related poverty must be carried out through a networked approach to development cooperation, humanitarian aid and a common security policy. This also means that we radically review our own trade policies, our own subsidies, to determine how far they contribute to poverty and inequality. Above all, we have to remain credible. We have an Africa TrustFund, which should initially have EUR 1.8 billion twice. For us, the EU, the result is quite okay: over 2.5 billion are in it. The member states have paid in just 176 million, albeit only with the help of Switzerland and Norway. I ask myself: how many millions of refugees still have to come to Europe for those in the Member States to stop chattering and finally act? It's time.

name: Jussi HALLA-AHO
text: – Mr President, there will be smuggling in the Mediterranean for as long as illegal crossing is rewarded. The demographic and socioeconomic trends in Africa and the Middle East guarantee that people will keep coming indefinitely and in large numbers. We have the tools to manage the influx: the problem is that we do not have a political decision on what we want to achieve. Europe cannot afford this kind of immigration, socially or economically. We have failed in integrating the immigrants that we already have, and that failure will become catastrophic as the numbers grow. So, we must stop the flow. Migrants who are rescued at sea must be returned to the port of departure, and not brought to European ports. This will also stop smuggling, because nobody wants to pay for nothing, and it will stop the tragedies at sea.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: - Mister President! As already mentioned several times at this point, the best recipe against uncontrolled and illegal immigration is a system that enables legal migration and at the same time coordinates the refugee flows to be separated from it. In the debate, these two different phenomena are constantly and unfortunately far too often mixed up. A common European asylum policy is on the way with the reform of the Dublin Agreement. But what is still absolutely necessary is a common European migration policy that also deserves this name. Only if we keep moving in this direction can we end human smuggling, save lives, and reap the economic benefits that coordinated and controlled immigration brings to our economies. The European Parliament is ready for it. And here and at this point I appeal to the governments and also to the Council Presidency to take the necessary steps and, together with the European Parliament and the European Commission, to decide on a European migration system. Because that is what people expect from the European Union and from all of us.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: - Mr President, this is a debate proposed by the extreme right-wing group entitled 'Fight against illegal immigration'. Illegal can be weapons, violence, things, but not people. And if you call the people who come to seek a better life in Europe illegal, it is because our governments have given themselves the power to decide who can be saved or who should die, denying citizenship to millions of people. They are illegal so that, when interested, the doors are closed on them and they die in the Mediterranean, they are locked in a CIE or they are returned hot in a fence. They are also illegal so that, when interested, the doors are opened to them and they can be sexually exploited or work in semi-slavery conditions. But who should be locked up in a CIE is characters like Mrs. Le Pen or all those people who think that because we were born in Europe or being white we have more right to eat than the rest. And we are going to build the wall —of course we do—, a wall that you will not pass through, a wall of anti-fascist solidarity.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, the issue of people smuggling and illegal immigration in the Mediterranean is, in essence, a simple one. The first step that we must undertake is to ask why this happens. Firstly, we must acknowledge the phenomenon of economic migration. European nations are wealthier and generally more stable and enjoy greater social benefits. By contrast, many African nations are poor, some politically unstable, many with lower health-care standards, and little chance of social benefits. Secondly, there are vast amounts of money to be made by people smuggling. Indeed, the last Europol report estimated that turnover in this area was between EUR three and six billion per annum. This has led to an increase in modern slavery. Something has to be done. With no effective control over our borders we remain vulnerable to terrorism. Also, we must address the increasing detrimental health issues, such as the fact that in 2014, 80% of tuberculosis sufferers in London were born abroad and a third of London boroughs were in that year’s World Health Organisation high incidence threshold. This necessarily contributes to the greater pressure on our own health services. Secondly, we must ensure that people smuggling is halted, the perpetrators’ vehicles confiscated and destroyed, and any NGOs found to have assisted in this despicable trade must lose all public funding and, like the people caught people smuggling, also face prosecution. Illegal immigrants are something very different to refugees. They should be turned away at the borders as a measure to send a message back to their homeland that such a journey will not be rewarded. Only by taking such a stance will we then be able to address the issue of support for genuine refugees.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: - (NL) Mr President, less than three percent of migrants in Italy were granted refugee status, but of 14,000 rejected migrants, only 120 were deported.Without an effective deportation policy, people will continue to step on boats with a high risk of drowning.Mr President, we must prosecute people smugglers.We must criminalize illegality.We must return anyone rescued at sea immediately, and certainly not allow them to enter the European Union.But above all, we must expand more and more quickly and inexorably.EU legislation is already getting in the way, but now this Parliament proposed last week that everyone who arrives automatically be assigned to a country.Such a call is almost malicious.No policy will work if Parliament is going to do things like this.Chairman, how many more lives can this still cost?

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: - Mr President, the war has never stopped; on the contrary. That is why the waves of refugees are strengthening again, while the confinement in the Greek islands in inhuman conditions like Moria in Lesvos is perpetuated. The responsibilities of the European Union and the Greek government are intact and great. The directions of the last summit are summarized in the position "keep the refugees outside the European Union in every way". You call the "fast track" deportations elegant "returns" that feed the networks of traffickers who otherwise fight and encourage the fascists. Reinforce the Schengen entry-exit dossier system, the upcoming new Dublin barrier and a new asylum system. On the one hand, selected cheap workers who will be accepted and, on the other hand, in the name of immigration prevention, large "businesses" in Africa and the Middle East. In other words, in the service of the monopolies. It is necessary to strengthen the solidarity of the peoples in order for the refugee migrants to reach their final destination country, fighting against the imperialist wars, NATO, the European Union and exploitation.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Mr President, illegal immigration is first of all a human tragedy. It is a gesture of desperation, which is exploited by traffickers of all kinds. The situation of refugees and migrants currently detained by smugglers in the town of Sabratha in Libya is a case in point. The fight against illegal immigration in the Mediterranean must be done on two fronts. It is first of all a question of stopping the traffickers, not only by arresting them at sea, but above all by adopting sanctions against the leaders of these regions. Stopping them also means supporting the peace process in Libya, because the smugglers make their fortune and operate thanks to the political and security vacuum. The new peace plan proposed by the United Nations special envoy is a step in the right direction. We must help this country out of the blockage. The second front is that of solidarity, which is not an option but a duty. Unfortunately, the numbers speak for themselves. Our Member States are not fulfilling their obligations under the mechanism for the relocation of refugees in Italy and Greece, adopted in September 2015. Hungary and Poland have not taken in any refugees, the Czech Republic has taken in 12 refugees. , Slovakia 16 and Austria 15. Solidarity is also almost non-existent when it comes to the Emergency Fund for Africa. This has reached its limits and, if the Member States do not contribute more, we will no longer be able to pursue our policies of voluntary return, border security, education and vocational training. How to offer an alternative to these candidates for migration without financial means? We are faced with a very short-termist vision while the European Union needs a strategic vision to make a difference and solve this problem.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Mr President, it is a very important debate, but look around the room: there are, what, 50 colleagues here? The European governments are focusing on pushbacks to the Mediterranean. We are not seriously addressing the despair of thousands of migrants that are crossing the Mediterranean. Almost half of them do not get international protection in Europe – that is what really worries me. Thank you, Mr Salvini, for stressing the importance of opening safer and legal ways to Europe for people that are in need for international protection. But your Group, which bases itself on anti-immigrant and xenophobic rhetoric, does not match your words with actions. You constantly vote against the European solutions that we are working on in this House too. It is clear that Italy cannot handle the situation alone. It is clear that we need a true European asylum system. We did our job here in the Parliament, and I blame the European governments for not moving forward. Yes, we have to improve our policy of return, but it can only be successful if we also establish efficient resettlement schemes. What about the fund for Africa? Members States promised the money, but where is this money today? What about the smugglers? We have the measures to fight against human trafficking. Where their smuggling profits going to? The Mediterranean remains a deadly sea, and I have to say, seriously, that I am ashamed of that.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, saving lives at sea and combating trafficking in human beings must continue to be the priorities in the current migration crisis in the Mediterranean. Trafficked people are often at risk of being tortured and killed. Corruption is always at the root of human trafficking. Some may not reach practically the other side of the continent, where they want to go. And then, in practice, trafficking in migrants not only endangers their lives, but also supports terrorist acts, because, through migrant trafficking, for example, terrorism is financed. So we need to stop this trafficking, help those in need of protection to get to Europe and, I repeat, stop human trafficking, including the cutting of terrorist funds. I would like to say one more thing: what we decided to adopt in Parliament, after the mandatory quotas, was the relocation procedure, which means that we go there and we choose the ones we bring, as Canada and as other countries do, after checking security, health and criminal records, whether they exist or not.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: – Mr President, I am sorry, ENF Group, but this is neo-fascism and racism dressed up in suits. You should not be able to set the agenda or frame our political responses, let alone frame our future. You should stop putting people against each other and stop lying about migrants and refugees, and you should stop confusing migrants and terrorists. It is beyond all dignity and sense. Smugglers exist because there is a lack of legal pathways. To externalise borders – in the way that some people here want to do – is not to save people. It increases death in the Mediterranean and in the Sahara. Yes, the left wants other responses. We want to close detention centres, we want to stop chasing people who are in an irregular situation and to stop the obsession with deportations. We want to open more legal pathways.  We have had two votes in Parliament that point to the possibility of humanitarian resettlement and the shared responsibility for receiving more refugees in Europe. Now it is up to the Council to deliver. To flee is not a choice. Nobody is illegal.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: - Mr President, every day counts and to this day, October 25, 2017, Europe's great shame continues to be the lack of safe entry routes for refugees, but also of an orderly system for the entry of migration. Let me give an example: there are 5 000 refugees who are living poorly in Moria, on Lesbos, suffering from depression, suicide attempts, conflicts due to inhuman conditions. Those who arrived on the Greek islands after March 20, 2016 are excluded from the relocation plan. They are trapped without hope. And many Member States are not up to the historic challenge - because this is one of the challenges of the century - or to their political commitments. When the principles and values ​​of the Union falter, we are left to cling to the rule of law and, if it is violated, apply sanctions. This, ladies and gentlemen, is one of the reasons for the failure we have. There are no mechanisms to sanction the States, which can make more efforts, which can also do so by other means (study visas, work visas, rapid family reunification procedures), but they look the other way cowardly.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, illegal immigration and human trafficking in the Mediterranean is above all a gigantic business, which begins in the countries of origin of the migratory flows and continues in the European countries of destination, in those reception centers too often. object of mismanagement and speculation on public funds. A phenomenon that ends up fueling sexual exploitation, illegal hiring, obscure interests and illegal activities managed by criminal groups. This is why we believe it is essential to have legal and safe ways of accessing the European Union, which must be involved in recognizing those who are entitled to forms of international protection already in the countries of origin or transit. Establishing legal ways of accessing the European Union means having a legal alternative, it means that those fleeing from wars and persecutions would have the possibility of not putting their lives in the hands of unscrupulous criminals, it means fighting human trafficking, crossings and deaths at sea and the pressure of migratory flows on the external borders.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: - Mr President, from the Strait of Gibraltar to the Greek Islands, from Lampedusa to the shores of Calabria, Europe has been undergoing a wave of migration and, for several years, for basely economic reasons, the European oligarchy has knowingly organized this invasion. But why do you persist in not recognizing that the thousands of illegal immigrants who die every year while attempting the crossing are victims of your own policies? 100 years ago, the disastrous Bolshevik revolution plunged Russia into a totalitarian, violent and liberticidal regime. Several countries have followed this terrible path. The one chosen by the European Union is as bad as the one taken by the former Soviet Union. The peoples of the East who have undergone the Communist yoke are not mistaken. Let’s end with these immigration policies that undermine the cohesion of our peoples and seriously endanger our civilization. Finally, have the courage to take dissuasive measures, to put an end to the collusion between traffickers and pseudo-humanitarian NGOs and to return the illegal boats. In short, have the courage to have courage.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, tackling immigration is the European Union's greatest failure of all time. A failure the consequences of which are present for the present generations and we do not know how many more in the future.
