From the moment the European Union fell victim to the populist slogan "we will not make Europe a fortress" and deprived the host countries and the external borders, namely Italy and Greece, of the right to protect their borders, this the flood, this invasion of illegal immigrants, which creates the problems we mentioned. In this way, these people live in miserable conditions in both Greece and Italy. Thus, the populists achieved a great victory. Europe did not become a fortress, but a huge concentration camp of impoverished and unfortunate people living in miserable conditions. But the populists of the left do not host these people in their homes, nor do they feed them. This is what we do, who love our country and who will save our country because we have an effective and correct way of dealing with it ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Kinga GÁL
text: - President! To eradicate human trafficking, illegal migration must be stopped outside the borders of the Union. Only an asylum system that can separate illegal economic immigrants from those who are truly eligible for refugee status outside the Union can be effective. It must be made crystal clear that only genuine refugees can enter or be granted refugee status in the territory of the Union. All other solutions are interpreted as an invitation to the Union by thousands of illegal migrants. To achieve this, refugee centers should be set up outside the borders of the Union, where it should be possible to process asylum applications. In the meantime, above all, we must protect the Union's external borders. We must also help the Member States that protect the external borders financially with this, otherwise more lives will be sacrificed at sea or in the desert, because it is now well known that human trafficking has become an even bigger business than the drug trade in recent years. Only in this way can we crush the business model and growing influence of human traffickers, who are increasingly benefiting from the migration crisis.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - President! We don’t like to talk about this, but we all know that the Mediterranean has become the mass grave of tens of thousands of refugees in recent years. Sometimes we raise our heads in connection with a horrible tragedy, but then everything goes on as it went before. Today, it must be clear that we are at a dead end. It is clear that human trafficking must be combated with all the means at our disposal. But it must also be made clear that neither the most deterrent border protection nor the unfounded accusations against NGOs helping refugees will solve or resolve this situation. We should finally understand that we will not be able to resolve this situation simply by closing the borders and controlling them as closely as possible. A common European asylum policy will only be able to work if the Member States finally put aside their own considerations and really want a common policy. As long as we simply acknowledge that there are Member States that can refuse to participate in the common policy without any consequences, nothing will happen in the sky. Mr Tusk's understanding of the Visegrad countries' rejection asylum policy only helps those who oppose a common European policy. Over the last year and a half, the European Parliament has presented and prepared a number of reports and motions, the implementation of which could provide a framework for immigration and asylum policy that offers regulated legal routes. There is only one reason why no progress is being made, namely that the Council is not willing to negotiate at all and is unable to reach a united position. Yet any further delay will drive the water to the mills of human traffickers, and we need to know that no one, but no one, can escape shared responsibility, not even the Council.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Mr President, Mr Preda is mistaken. Poland has accepted around one million migrants without relying on the EU mechanism. On the eve of the EU-Africa summit, I acknowledged the heart-breaking poverty and the huge violence on the continent. I therefore welcome the Trust Fund for Africa and other endeavours to diminish both disasters.  Based on said experience, I pay tribute to Europol, Frontex, EUNAVFOR MED operation SOPHIA, NATO and EU Member States, such as Italy and Greece, for their endeavours to manage the migration problem and to eradicate both illegal migration and the criminal activity associated with it.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: - Mr President, as the Union continues to take responsibility for wars, imperialist interventionist policies, poverty, the violation of peoples' right to sovereignty over their natural resources and the effects of climate change, more and more people will be forced to emigrate. . What you call illegal immigrants are people who have been forced to leave their homes to fall victim to traffickers in the Mediterranean to save their children. As long as the Union continues to treat them as criminals, it will only succeed in strengthening the far-right movements and increasing the trafficking ring. How many more refugees must die helpless to stop the Union's xenophobic racist approaches? The ongoing tragedy raises the need for the Union to carry out a radical overhaul of immigration policy, ie to combat the causes of immigration and refugees. For us, the unacceptable refugee exchange agreement with Turkey must be abolished or immediately lifted, humanitarian aid must be strengthened, Dublin II must be abolished, safe and legal routes must be established and a network for the redistribution and relocation of refugees must be established.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Mr President, irregular or illegal immigration is a political disaster. It undermines the positive case for controlled immigration, it is corrosive of public trust and it rewards law-breakers, as opposed to honest applicants who have stuck to the rules. It follows that facilitating or encouraging, even indirectly, the flow of irregular migration is the height of political irresponsibility. Yet this is what many senior European politicians have done: from Mrs Merkel inviting everyone to Germany and then seeking to strong-arm her neighbours into bailing her out, to those campaigning against the Dublin rules that quite reasonably expect asylum applicants to lodge their claims in the first safe country they reach. The answer to the Mediterranean migration crisis is not to force other EU countries to take in those being sheltered by Italy or Greece. That will merely add to the pull factors which already lure so many young men from Africa and the Middle East to Europe. No, the solution is to intercept the boats coming from Libya and elsewhere, and to escort them back to their points of embarkation. Irregular migrants need to be seen to be losers – not losers of their lives, like so many have been in recent years – but losers in their battle to circumvent the rule of law. Only that way will public confidence be restored.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the last three years Europe has spent, has thrown away, something like over EUR 20 billion in grueling taxes from European citizens on crazy reception policies. So we must ask ourselves: what were the effects? The answers are there for all to see: more poverty, more insecurity, more crime, more attacks. So we need to reflect on whether the 20 billion spent in these three years have been a cure or have fueled the disease of the problem. It is necessary to reflect on whether the 20 billion of such a rich loot was an element that fueled the hospitality business, which determined the negative effects of this reception. And I would say that making mistakes is human but persevering is diabolical, so it is essential to stop throwing public money into criminal and continuing reception and change policies. I say "yes" to reach out, to invest in aid for 2 euros a day in the countries of origin; I say "no" to throwing 40 euros a day in insane hospitality in this country.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - Mr Chairman! The matter is serious, I listen to it with amusement. First, let me make it clear to the left that illegal immigrants have nothing to do with racism. This is just a man who does not have a valid passport and visa. I myself have been to a country several times illegally. There are several hundred thousand illegal immigrants from Poland in the United States, and of course there is no racism in this. Secondly, I have the impression that the Left hates entrepreneurship so much that they are more concerned with the fact that smugglers make money from it than they are interested in the problem of immigrants. Even Mr. Preda said he hates the smugglers who earn their money from this practice. He just hates capitalism. Now let's talk about it seriously. Benefits are the cause of evil. Socialism is a system in which one heroically overcomes difficulties unknown in any other system. If there were no social benefits, there would be no immigrants. There would also be no demoralization of Europeans who receive the same benefits. Time to abolish social benefits and the problem of immigrants will be reduced to normal size: only those immigrants who want to work honestly will come

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: If only it were so simple.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the invasion we have witnessed in recent years has made the debate heated and divided us immensely. The added value of a compromise agreement, based on shared responsibility, was and remains the only possible solution. Italy as a border area has put its internal stability into play to stem the flows. We have repeatedly requested the intervention of the international community and the Union to help us face this emergency. I am convinced that the real phenomenon to be tackled is organized crime, which profits from trafficking and finances terrorism. According to data provided by the European Commission, 79% of the victims of trafficking are destined for prostitution and sexual exploitation, but if on the one hand we must strongly condemn the traffickers and protect the victims, on the other hand if there were no demand there would be no market . So, in this case, I've always been a fan and I've always appreciated the Nordic model and, above all, the criminalization of the customer: the more rigid we are and with ourselves, the less interests there will be at stake.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union in recent years has shown all its political fragility in dealing with a crisis that I would call institutional in managing the flow of migrants rather than a migration crisis. We do not respond to the issue of illegal immigration by thinking of policies of closure and externalization of border control towards those fleeing war and misery. The Council, in the recent summit, declared that it is ready to monitor all migratory routes, but it continues to underestimate the fact that the new routes to Europe could prove to be more dangerous than the previous ones and above all it continues to be overlooked in the meantime, tens of thousands of migrants who are victims of rape, illegal detention and abuse of all kinds are paying the price for a policy that is not up to par. Now it is evident, unlike what Mr Salvini imagines in his complex dream activity, the need for a change of approach, which addresses the structural challenges that are at the root of this process, such as underdevelopment, population growth, inequalities, the absence of opportunities, climate change, and the need to govern this process by strengthening common legislation on asylum and immigration. Only a coordinated approach, based on the principles of solidarity, equal sharing of responsibilities and strong financial investments, will be able to deliver tangible results in this decisive challenge for Europe itself.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: - Mister President! We're talking about people smuggling here. We are talking about smuggling. The rule violations, the legal violations that so many speakers have complained about here, that's only one side of the coin. The other and much more terrible side of the coin is the loss of human life that we see: when people are sent by tugs into boats that are unseaworthy, when they are in part deliberately driven to their death because the helm is determined, if there is not enough drinking water on board and more similar things. Something has to be done against this smuggling, against these criminals, against these murderers. I miss the initiatives there. Why are we not doing what we do with the apprehension of murderers in the European Union, by offering rewards to those who contribute to the apprehension of these murderers? Why don't we praise money - a lot of money - for all those refugees who, before boarding such a boat, report it and say: There are the smugglers - arrest these people. Why don't we cooperate with the police authorities in the relevant countries by saying: We praise the money, you arrest the people, and then we bring them to justice?

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: - Mr President, immigration may take place legally or illegally, but never, ever can a human being be considered illegal.These categories only generate dangerous invisible walls built on the stigmatization of the migrant population, as, for example, the shameful title of this debate, which exudes the xenophobia typical of fascists in ties.This is also done by the European Union, which constantly talks about illegal migrants as well.The solution is to make a 180 degree turn in the foreign migration and border policy of "Fortress Europe", which is what really stimulates the business of human trafficking in the Mediterranean.The mafias are the fire that we have to put out, but the migration policies of "Fortress Europe" are the gasoline that keep that fire alive.

name: Elmar BROK
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, we need to have a common definition, and that is why it really is time to create a common European asylum law and in this way to have a common definition and possibly also to combine this with an immigration law. Second, I would like to say: Ms. Merkel did not invite everyone, but she also does not let people die. In Poland there are one million migrant workers from Ukraine, just as there are hundreds of thousands of migrant workers from Poland in Germany - please do not count that. Regarding the questions themselves, I would like to say again: We have to make it clear that those who flee from war and those who, in the traditional asylum sense, have to fear for their lives have protection. That is a human and legal obligation! We have to see if that can be done elsewhere than on our soil. But we have a fundamental claim here that cannot be denied and where we cannot bring everything under one roof. We must state that in the event of illegal entry we must of course protect the external borders, which we have been calling for in this European Parliament for years, for 15 years, already in the Constitutional Convention - at that time, Member States did not participate because of Europe's obsession with competence - a failure of the Member States in this question, all together - and we have to see that we better tackle the causes. Better to be able to end wars and have a decent Africa policy and not the lousy one as before. And we have to cooperate with the coastal countries. We have an agreement with Turkey and Turkey is taking action against the traffickers. That is why there are 92% fewer refugees from Turkey today than three years ago. At the same time we support the refugees in Turkey. This is the right way, and here we have the first approaches in relation to Africa;It may be much more difficult with Libya, but there has been progress here that can be seen.This summer there were 81% fewer refugees from Africa than in the previous summer, but we cannot leave Greece and Italy without solidarity either.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe, after a very long hiatus, is now making some progress and we ask that the Member States, the Commission and the Council commit themselves very quickly to keeping their promises. But for a long time, I said, my country, Italy, was left alone, that country criticized here for a paltry and evident remnant of the electoral campaign, here in Europe, for Italy. We alone did the search, the reception, the rescue. Other than talking about business: those thousands of citizens, those associations, that voluntary service, even largely Catholic, those local bodies that have been able to welcome are offended. We have also done all the work on countries of transit and of origin, with difficult agreements; we proudly dictated the agenda in Europe for migration policy, addressing the emergency and tracing the causes. The Migration Compact, the plan for Africa and the Juncker plan are there because some countries have requested them; we worked for the Dublin reform, other than shooting a few shots and then walking away. Here, day by day, in the commissions and in the daily relationship with colleagues, we have achieved some things. And let me say one last word, President, with a little generosity, as you did with my colleague Brok. I have even heard Christian values ​​evoked to select who to let in and who not. Now, I am a Christian, and religion has taught me openness and acceptance, not rejection and perhaps hatred for the different.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: One word about timing. When you are in a position such as this, you are above all a timekeeper. But we are in a parliament in which communication is the most important thing, so we must strike a balance between keeping to the time and permitting and facilitating communication. That is why I am trying not to stop immediately when the time is over, and to let the person finish the ideas, because in the end the communication amongst ourselves is the most important thing. If I don’t manage to keep that balance all the time, well, it happens and I apologise for that. But this is my philosophy, so you should know that and we should all contribute towards making this work.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: - Mr President, I will try to keep this communication in order. Mr Vice-President! Unfortunately, it took so long for more European leaders to realize that the 2015 migration crisis is largely a crisis organized by criminal business and to understand what steps should be taken. The solutions that have been proposed do not, in my view, stand up to criticism, even with the relocation scheme as an example. My country, Latvia, accepted a relatively large number of migrants under quotas, but none of them stayed in Latvia, because, of course, they went to the Member States where the criminals were paid and where they want to live, most often to Germany. So such a system is not appropriate, and it has only created tensions between many European Member States. About the new offer heard here - about legal immigration. Do we think - if we take the best people from African countries, then what do we leave in those countries? Who will stay? We will, in fact, cynically empty the future of African countries if we do so.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Perfect timing!

name: Milan ZVER
text: - In addition to terrorism, migration is the most pressing issue for the European public. We need to understand this as an order to the politician to do everything possible to curb illegal migration. Statistics show that we have been slightly more successful in the last year and a half in the fight against illegal migrants and smugglers in particular. Many hide behind NGOs and recruit migrants for lucrative business. Effective external border control is becoming an existential issue for the European Union. Recently, we have been taking a series of measures, such as the smart borders package, reforming the asylum system and strengthening, albeit slowly, the European border and coast guard. We certainly need to increase the resilience of the Union and the Member States to future crises. There is a real possibility that the Balkan route will reopen. The return system from Greece to Turkey is not working well because the Greek authorities are unable to process second-instance complaints about applications for international protection. As a result, capacity on the islands is shrinking dangerously. As a result, the possibility of moving to the Greek mainland and then, of course, further north reopens. Smugglers recruiting in Turkey are more active again. We know how unstable relations with the Turkish government are anyway. Therefore, we should warn the Balkan countries of the danger of new waves of illegal migration. I hope that this time the Union and its Member States will react differently to this deal, which only benefits smugglers and countries that have been destabilizing the European Union for a long time.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: - Mr President, as the permanent rapporteur for humanitarian aid in this Parliament, I reject the approach taken by the proponent of this debate.An approach to cultural xenophobia wrapped in some brushstrokes of Pharisaic Christianity.This is a complex issue and cannot be addressed simply by treating the symptoms of one of its components.We need a global response that addresses the causes with strong investments in countries of origin and transit;that opens avenues for humanitarian access and also for orderly immigration;to fight traffickers and hunt them down;that it respects the human rights of those who arrive at our borders and that it promotes integration policies in the countries where these emigrants settle.That is a global approach and it is a commitment for the entire European Union.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, illegal migration is a threat. It is a threat to the rule of law, to the security of the Member States of the European Union. Those who support illegal immigration are committing crimes. Illegal, illegal border crossing of any country anywhere in the world is a crime and this should be well known to cultural Marxists and Bolsheviks on the other side of the hall. Moreover, they know it, but pretend not to understand. When a non-governmental organization facilitates illegal emigration, facilitates illegal border crossing, it also commits a crime. And here comes the other question: Where is the responsibility of the so-called leaders of European countries? The responsibility of Mrs Merkel, who as a true populist first invited everyone, then denied her words. Where is the responsibility of those who say that someone must forcibly accept someone into their home? Have these colleagues of ours, in the hall today, received at least one illegal immigrant in their home? No, they are not. Therefore, speaking in this way is a lie and hypocrisy, and this must end.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: - (NL) Mr President, it is not the first time that we have this debate and it will not be the last time either. The fight against illegal migration, tackling people smuggling and protecting our external borders remains important, even now that the influx has declined sharply in recent months. Because that influx has decreased, and that is also due to the efforts here at European level, efforts that will remain urgently needed in the future. But efforts might be a bit of a tricky word for those who seek this debate. It is also much more attractive to get a little angry from the extreme right-wing there in Parliament, to criticize and especially to move air between Brussels and Strasbourg for a lot of tax money. But that does not help European citizens. Improved registration of asylum seekers: you vote against this. Better protect external borders: you vote against it. Travel documents for the return of illegal migrants: opposed. A PNR guideline for our safety: against. Strengthening police cooperation: against. An entry-exit system, firearms directive, EU terrorist directive: against, against, against. And do you know what's the worst? When we discuss this type of legislation in our parliamentary meeting rooms, you generally don't even show up. Either you don't think it's important enough or you are just too lazy to work. You are very good at shouting a little on the sidelines without ever contributing anything. Fortunately, it is a political business model that has had its day. Our citizens deserve better.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, do you really want to combat trafficking in human beings and avoid exploitation? There is only one way to do this: to open legal and safe avenues for access to the Union and to all Member States. Only in this way will we avoid that the only access point to the EU is Italy and Greece on extremely dangerous routes entrusted to traffickers. It is very hypocritical to speak of irregular immigration when neither for those seeking asylum nor for those trying to survive hunger there are ways to come legally, because the immigration policies of the Member States are completely inadequate, including the Italian one, which the Hon. Salvini knows well why he is called Bossi-Fini. The right is the queen of hypocrisy, because when we vote for solutions of equal sharing of responsibilities on reception, which would make the phenomenon easily manageable for everyone, as in Dublin, it does not participate in the negotiations and then votes against. Here, she is loud against illegal immigrants, but not against those who employ them in their companies, she says "let's help them at home" and then votes against development aid. If you look for the reasons why people run away you will find them much closer to you than you think. For example, do you know that African countries have lost trillion dollars in corporate tax evasion and avoidance over the past fifty years? We need coherent European policies on development and trade. Here, there is a lot to do in our house to address the reasons for departures.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: - Mr Chairman!Listening to the speeches of the representative of the Council and of the Commission, the Commissioner, I wondered why some such obvious measures were proposed and applied so late.We all remember 2015, when we heard from a very important European politician that it is impossible to protect the borders of her country, the external borders of the Union.A lot has changed since then.This is the result of the resistance of the societies of the member states and the recent elections in many of these countries.It is impossible to disregard the voice of the nation on such a fundamental issue.One can only hope that the proposal to reform the Dublin Convention will also remove the utopian contents detached from life, because we cannot invite millions of people to the European Union and then individually check their entitlement to asylum.Let me also remind you that matters related to legal immigration fall within the competence of the Member States, not the European Union.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: - Mr President, Mr President of the Council, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, fighting illegal immigration and trafficking in human beings must be a priority. And not just in the Mediterranean. But the great challenge facing the Mediterranean lies in the flow of refugees fleeing the war and over whom we have a duty to protect. Unfortunately, tens of thousands of people have died in recent years, while seeking refuge on our Continent. The real debate, the honest discussion on the Mediterranean, must focus on responding to the humanitarian crisis, on fighting trafficking in human beings and creating legal access routes. That is why, in 2013, we imposed Search and Rescue as priorities in Frontex operations. That is why we have better trained this agency and Europol to combat trafficking. This is also why this Parliament recently approved its position for a mechanism for the resettlement of refugees from third countries and for the new Dublin regulation. Parliament was right when it insisted on a holistic and non-sectoral approach with the report by colleagues Metsola and Kyenge. Saving lives, legal access and fighting crime: these must all be, without exception, our priorities.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Mr. President, about one hundred thousand migrants arrived in Italy this year alone, and the Libyan Coast Guard intercepted 16.5 thousand migrants. The living conditions of those who arrive in Europe are already difficult enough, and winter is coming. Two weeks ago, in just one operation, over 600 migrants were rescued, including 200 children. They all entrusted their lives and the lives of their families to human smugglers. This year, as many as 2,500 migrants have died in the Mediterranean, which has long been the deadliest sea in the world. At the same time, the only concrete things the Council has agreed on are mechanisms for stronger control of external borders. Last week's conclusions on a Mediterranean route full of declarations prove it best. It is high time for concrete solidarity among the members, but also concrete mechanisms for strengthening the European common and security policy. The European Union needs to evolve from a donor to an international policy maker - from payer to player. It must strengthen its presence in devastated areas. The long-term solution is always where the problem arises.

name: Frank ENGEL
text: - Mr President, I will start by saying that I have already heard more disagreeable speeches from our colleague Salvini. He was kind enough today to tell us that from now on he is in favor of legal migration, which is better than being against any form of migration, and that he accepts the existence women and children, at least, who are truly fleeing war, misery, threats, death and lack of prospects, and whom they need the protection we have the right and the duty to give them. This is progress, for the Lega Nord it is not bad! I must say, however, that we will probably continue to address the alleged root causes of migration for a very long time to come, when we seem to miss a few key aspects of this matter. With all the funds that we have implemented and that we are currently implementing in Africa, we have currently raised, if all goes well, 5 billion which, we hope, will multiply to constitute 40-45 billion in l horizon 2020, to be invested in the development of Africa. China alone invested more than 40 billion in Africa in 2016, and will of course continue to do so even more in 2017, 2018, 2019 and 2020. It is no coincidence that Africans look to us with more development skepticism than they do to China today. This is not good for us and it is not good for our purposes with regard to migration in Africa. We will have to review our copy.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: - Sur President, filf fatt illum qegħdin nitkellmu dwar il-ġlieda kontra t-traffikar tal-persuni, u ġlieda bħal din trid tibda minn fuq l-art u mhux tiffoka biss fuq il-baħar. Għalfejn qed ngħid hekk? Għax l-Unjoni Ewropea kkonċentrat ħafna drabi, u wisq, l-isforzi tagħha fuq missjonijiet navali imma r-riżultat li dawn l-operazzjonijiet ħallew ma kienx dak mistenni. Perežempju Operation Sophia ħiet maħluqa biex tkisser il-modelell kummerċjali tat-traffikanti tal-persuni. I tda traffikar ta 'nies qed ikompli bla xkiel fil-baħar Mediterranju. If the applicant is in a position to do so, it will be possible for the applicant to enter the territory of the Member States. Agħar minn hekk, ifisser ukoll li l-kriminali wara dawn iċ-ċrieki tat-traffikar ta ‘persuni, li huma mifruxa u pankontinentali, qegħdin dejjem ikunu pass’ il quddiem. In the present case, the State of the Community's model should be considered as a criminal offense in accordance with the provisions of this Directive. On the other hand, the Community has entered into force on behalf of the European Union, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, - Crimes are criminal.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: - Mr President, proposals to tackle the migration crisis are multiplying like mushrooms after rain. However, all these discussions have been forgotten. It is the personal empathy of politicians. I am afraid that the lack of personal feelings and autopsy is also holding back the solution of problems such as migration. They are journalists who appear at the scene of an emerging conflict within hours or days, while politicians decide to investigate the problem often on the spot, often when the fire has started. Let me give you an example. During his presidency, Martin Schulz banned a delegation of MEPs from leaving for Donbas, Ukraine. He appealed for concern for their safety. It was as if hundreds of journalists did not work in Donbas at the time, as if hundreds of thousands of people, including women and children, did not live there. The President of the European Parliament has prevented MEPs from realizing empathy in the midst of such a major conflict. The same refugees in the Mediterranean. The vast majority of migrants are smuggled from Libya. Today, in the center of the smugglers in the port of Sabratha, twenty thousand people are waiting to be transported. Dozens of journalists operate in western Libya, including Sabratha. And I ask: how is it possible that the European Parliament delegation in Libya, the de facto European Parliament embassy in Libya, does not have a permanent presence in Libya, but in Tunisia? The answer may be: It's not safe in Tripoli. Truth. Courage, ladies and gentlemen! The policy of resolving the migration crisis, including that in the Mediterranean, also requires courage.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, I think that my colleague, Szczecin, kind of recorded for me because, unlike many refugee camps, I actually went. And I actually visited these refugee camps and had the opportunity to meet people who were victims of various smugglers. And most of them were people who were uneducated, very poor and who really wanted to come to Europe and live like their relatives, who even, intentionally or mistakenly, shared photos or videos that showed that Europe has a great life. These people mostly flew. First they came across the promise of some smugglers, then their assumptions and their ignorance and their feelings that they would get better somewhere. I think that, as today, some Member States have succeeded in setting up websites that provide information on the real situation in the European Union, so we, as the European Union, should try to influence people who are victims of smugglers so that they do not go. to European countries and did not give money to these organized groups because they are constantly growing. If we look at satellite images in Libya, where, as a colleague said, it is very dangerous, we can see how the houses of some smugglers are constantly growing.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for this debate. There seems to be a broad consensus on the need to step up the fight against smugglers and irregular migration. We are on the right track, but we have to remain vigilant and implement all actions to stem irregular migratory flow towards Europe. We can assure that the Commission will continue its work to save lives, to put in place safe and legal pathways, to fight smuggling and to protect our external borders and return irregular migrants. To that end, we will strengthen our cooperation with key third countries. At the same time, let me stress that we also need to make progress on managing migration within Europe. In this respect, Member States will have to notably streamline their return procedure, in line with the Return Directive. We also have to work on the reform of common European asylum system. As you know, there is no single, no simple solution. We have to work on all sides.

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the EU migration policy needs to be sustainable. Our challenges are manifold but our goals are clear: to gradually put in place a proper asylum and migration policy with effective control of our external borders. We will pursue the work already underway, bearing in mind that, in order to be successful, all elements must be pursued jointly and all must deliver on their commitments. Greece and Italy, in particular, are very much on the frontline, with thousands of irregular migrants arriving every month. That requires the continued expression of solidarity from all stakeholders.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - After years of emergency in Italy there seems to be a significant reduction in landings, a sign that the new way of opening and dialogue with Libya is bringing some results and therefore represents a suitable political tool to manage the causes of migration at source. The same European Council a few days ago declared full support for the action of my country, recognizing the significant contribution made by Italy in the management of the migration phenomenon. However, it is necessary that the Union soon draw up a long-term strategy, among other things requested several times by this House, in which the development and economic growth of African states are finally placed at the center of political action, because the sustainable management of migration certainly can no longer be based exclusively on initiatives of an emergency nature. However, the migration policy of the Union, and of its member countries, must not, in any way, involve the risk of a squeezing of the fundamental rights of all those people, and among them many minors, who try to arrive on European coasts to escape to serious conflicts, persecutions or discrimination, but on the contrary, it must be aimed at increasingly effectively combating human trafficking and the criminal organizations that manage it.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – Unfortunately, recent reports from international organisations and NGOs have stressed the unpleasant fact that African migrants who are trying to reach Europe through the Mediterranean are being sold like commodities by militants/smugglers in modern-day slave markets in Libya. Victims of human trafficking note that first their captors beat them and then force them to call their families and ask for a ransom. Those who cannot pay their captors are reportedly killed, left to starve to death, forced to work or are sold as slaves for up to USD 500. Many women and even children have been exposed to sexual exploitation. I strongly condemn people smuggling in the Mediterranean. It is despicable and shameful for the EU to look on as humans are sold as a commodity just few hundred kilometres from the European shore. In this context, I believe that the fight against networks of migrant smugglers and human traffickers needs to be stepped up through a stronger focus on measures aimed at tackling these crimes, including cross-border cooperation between Member States, institutional reforms and capacity building. In addition, the EU should facilitate its cooperation with its neighbours in order to address the priorities of the Joint Valetta Action Plan.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing. - The European Union must turn its gaze and attention to the Aegean islands, which Erdoğan threatens to fill daily with refugees and mainly illegal immigrants, to the Aegean islands where thousands of refugees and mainly illegal immigrants are trapped and whose inhabitants can no longer bear this situation. If one visits these islands, the inhabitants will tell him that the situation has reached the point of no return. In Samos, the situation is explosive. The same happens in Lesvos, the same in Chios. And there the inhabitants react. They can no longer stand other illegal immigrants, because most of those gathered there are illegal immigrants. This requires action and severe punishment for those involved in slave trade and networks that transport hundreds of illegal immigrants to the Aegean islands.

name: Artis PABRIKS
text: in writing. – The situation in the Mediterranean has showed that unfortunately people smugglers are often a few steps ahead of the EU. It has turned the migration crisis into a very profitable business. The migratory pressure on the EU external borders is constant and will continue in the foreseeable future as there are considerable economic and political differences between the EU and its neighbourhood. In order to curb, manage illegal migration we need to, first of all, strengthen the EU external border. It is our duty to our citizens to keep our border safe. Second, we need to focus our efforts to restore and strengthen state structures in countries like Libya. Third, we must strengthen the cooperation with African countries, provide our assistance but also ask them to take back their nationals who travelled to EU illegally and do not qualify for asylum. Fourth, we need to give the possibility for people who are in need for international protection to apply for asylum outside the EU, to avoid their dangerous journey to Europe in the hands of people smugglers. Until we have fulfilled these preconditions, it will be very difficult to agree on any relocation schemes across the Member States.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the report by Gunnar Hökmark, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the economic policy of the euro area (2017/2114 (INI)) (A8-0310 / 2017).

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commission for its presentation, and also thank the shadow rapporteurs, who have been working very closely with politically very difficult items. Stability needs a dynamic economy in Europe. If we are to have stable societies and stable social development, we need to have a more dynamic economy that fosters growth. But a dynamic economy also requires stability in terms of public finances, legal certainty and opportunities for new enterprises, innovation and investment.  It is important that, when raising the European Union growth targets, we improve people’s living and social conditions. We will secure stability on the financial markets, but we will also lay the ground for the future competitiveness of the European economy, because if we cannot be in the lead, and if we cannot have the investments we need, then we will lose.  We have an economic recovery going on in the European Union, but it is slow and it is not enough. Investments are not catching up, although it is very much based on a unique monetary policy. We have lower unemployment than back in the days of 2008 before the crisis, but on the other hand, the GDP per capita is not very much above what we had before the crisis.  It is important to note that we have lower deficits, lower debts, more growth and lower unemployment. We should know first of all that this is not enough, but also that there are huge differences between the Member States. Some are still suffering from very high unemployment. Some are still dealing with major deficits. We have very different performances in the economies of the European Union. This proves one thing, and that is the good news. The good news is that we are not doing as well as we can. It would have been depressing if this was the best we could do. But we can do better. We see that through the differences, the fact that some Member States are developing better as regards labour markets, employment and investment. For me and for us behind the report, this illustrates the need to have a look not only on the aggregated level, but also at each Member State.  We need to have cohesion in economic growth, and therefore we need to have cohesion in structural reforms. We need to have a target of potential growth of 3% for every Member State in order to achieve 1% higher growth. We need to reform labour markets. We need to reform other markets, meaning more competition. We need to have budgetary reforms opening up for lower taxes, especially on jobs and investments, and we need to ensure that we in the European Union can achieve an internal market fostering an economy that can be a global leader.  We can achieve a lot if we look at the reality now and at the need for structural reforms and stability at the same time, then we will deliver splendid economic development for the citizens of the European Union, but we need to take action. That is the main message in this report.

name: Yana TOOM
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Mr President, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs adopted 45 suggestions into this resolution, but I only have time for a few remarks. Unemployment rates have not yet returned to pre-crisis levels and the youth unemployment rate remains unacceptably high. Labour market conditions and performance still show substantial differences across Member States. Poverty remains high as well. We need continuous efforts to achieve a balance between the economic and social dimensions of the European semester policies. The efficiency and effectiveness of labour market policies should be increased. The Committee calls for the continuation of the youth employment initiative while taking into account the latest findings of the Court of Auditors’ Special Report. We need an integrated anti-poverty strategy. In this regard, the Committee underlined the role of Member States’ minimum income schemes. We require investment in skills development, particularly digital skills and programming. Otherwise, the Union’s competitive position may be undermined. Better skills-matching and improved mutual recognition of qualifications is necessary to address skills shortages and mismatches.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, it is a pleasure to be here today to discuss this important and timely topic of the economic policies of the euro area. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Hökmark, and all the shadow rapporteurs for the report. As you rightly point out in the report, economic recovery in the euro area is continuing and strengthening. It has become increasingly broad-based across countries. All 28 Member States are back to growth. We are witnessing steady employment growth with unemployment at its lowest level in eight years and improving business sentiment, with confidence at its highest in a decade. We see that our economic policy priorities of supporting investment, structural reforms and responsible fiscal policies are delivering results. But, despite this robust recovery, we still see subdued core inflation, wage growth that does not reflect labour market developments, large current account surpluses in some euro area Member States, high debt levels and persistent investment gaps. Most importantly, we see persistent economic and social divergences in the euro area. These make it harder to manage our economy and mean that the recovery is not benefiting all European citizens equally. The years prior to the crisis saw a trend of real convergence within the euro area. However, it partly masked the boom phase of the boom-bust cycle that unravelled later. But this convergence trend was brought to a halt by the crisis, and since then we have been witnessing persistent divergences. I agree with you that the euro area harbours untapped economic potential and that we have to deploy all our efforts to increase potential growth, while making growth more inclusive. Achieving sustainable and inclusive growth is the ultimate aim of everything we do in the European Semester. This must be done by taking into account and tackling the individual structural weaknesses of our Member States. We see positive tendencies in the EU economy, but there is no time to relax. We should aim at strengthening the resilience of our economies, boosting productivity, growth and inclusiveness. Reforms must combine the goals of creating efficiency and stability with a strong focus on fairness and empowering people over their lifetime by making them ready to face changes. As you know, in November the Commission will issue the Annual Growth Survey and a proposal for a recommendation for economic policy in the  euro area. The recommendation aims to identify common challenges in the euro area, and this will serve as guidance for consequent country—specific recommendations. At the same time, we must continue to work on deepening and strengthening our economic and monetary union. This is precisely about addressing the current lack of convergence in the Union. A well—functioning economic and monetary union should become our main tool for renewed convergence in the euro area. Future reforms should make sure that economic and monetary union delivers on its original objectives: growth and jobs, as well as economic, social and territorial cohesion. The new architecture should create stronger incentives for reforms and support national policies with new instruments at European level. In all, it must be able to deliver on the initiatives for a deeper and fairer EMU, as announced by President Juncker in his State of the Union speech and in the Commission’s work programme. The forthcoming EMU package, which we will present on 6 December, will comprise a number of these initiatives. We will propose to bring the European Stability Mechanism into the European Union legal framework in order to make it more democratically accountable and, at the same time, to strengthen its role and improve decision—making procedures. We will propose the creation of a dedicated euro area budget line within the future EU budget in order to provide for four functions: structural reform assistance, stabilisation function, a backstop for a banking union and a convergence instrument to give pre—accession assistance for Member States on their way to euro membership. We will also propose incorporating the substance of the Treaty of Stability, Coordination and Governance in the EMU into the EU framework, as was initially agreed in 2012.  With a view to 2025, the Commission will also set out views on the possible creation of a permanent European Minister of Economy and Finance and present exploratory work for the possible development of the euro area safe asset. We will also continue our work towards completing the banking union and capital markets union. Our economic and monetary union will only become stronger if solidarity and responsibility go hand in hand. So we need to work closely together towards this ambitious and important objective of deepening the EMU and making it more resilient. I look forward to hearing your views on this very topical report.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, the unemployment and youth unemployment rates in the European Union have dropped to around 9.5% and 19.4%, respectively. But we cannot lower our arms. Despite the improvements, there are still 14 million young Europeans out of work, who neither study nor are in training. This is terrible and unacceptable. In addition to the tremendous social impact, it costs EUR 153 billion for the European Union, knowing that the wider application of the Youth Guarantee across the Union would cost us much less. We need to be more decisive with its implementation, strengthening it at national, regional and local levels, aware of the importance that this guarantee has in preparing young people for the job market. On the other hand, there is also an urgent need to reinforce its monitoring in order to avoid mechanisms that falsify employment numbers using internships and other training programs, creating the illusion of a recovery that, in fact, is too fragile, without guarantees of sustainability. We must be prepared for the future. We must be demanding in investing in education and training, especially in the development of digital skills, to face the new challenges. This is an essential condition for the defense of the European social model, which includes the sustainability of our social security systems. It is precisely in the defense of this European social model, in balance with economic sustainability, that the European Semester must be based. In this sense, we have proposed a procedure for social imbalances which, although not punitive, aims to strengthen the social aspect of European policies, in order to create a true European social pillar that guarantees the future of the Union, which guarantees the future of our young people .

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this is an important moment for the democratic governance of Economic and Monetary Union. In fact, through the report that we are discussing today, the European Parliament, directly elected by the citizens, commented on the direction of the economic policy of the euro area. I want to greet the rapporteur, Gunnar Hökmark, because, despite our political differences - which are, of course, many - we have once again had the opportunity to continue constructive work for a balanced and globally positive report. I believe that is what we have before us today: a balanced and globally positive report. It is important to start by recognizing the signs of economic recovery that we have been seeing in the euro area. Today we have more growth, less unemployment, less deficit and more controlled public debts. But the first message from this Parliament is a warning message. The European economic recovery we have is still insufficient, too fragile and uneven. Despite the Juncker Plan and the turning point of austerity in some countries, this economic recovery is still too much supported by an expansionary monetary policy by the European Central Bank that cannot last forever. That is why the second message of this report and this Parliament is that we urgently need to overcome the investment deficit that still exists in the European economy. There are, of course, many structural changes to correct the architecture of the eurozone and defend our economies from speculation in the sovereign debt markets, but the priority for investment is unavoidable. We need a reinforcement of the Juncker Plan, with a more just geographical distribution, but we also need a different fiscal policy, which makes full use of the flexibility clauses, and this is a central issue. The fact of this report is that, while the European Commission proposed a moderately expansionary fiscal policy, we will continue to have an essentially neutral fiscal policy.This is what we need to correct in order to return the ambition of convergence and the ambition of economic growth and investment to the European economy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, Mr Dombrovskis, the eurozone economic policy based on austerity and violent fiscal adjustment has failed. This is evidenced by the economic collapse of the European South, which was filled with millions of poor people and huge armies of unemployed. This is proved by Greece, which the troika turned into a vast social cemetery, with pensions and starvation salaries, with the looting of public property, with the seizure of Greek homes by "crows". This is evidenced by Germany, which is accumulating huge trade surpluses due to the eurozone. At the same time, the structural and institutional deficits of the eurozone are exacerbating economic deadlocks, increasing deficits as well as huge public and private debt. In addition, Mr Dombrovskis, the competitiveness model you are promoting is based on the Euro Plus Pact, which is leading to the Chineseization of European wages and increasing misery. A change of course is needed. We need a fair distribution of the wealth produced, the remission of the shameful debt and an increase in social spending.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Dear Chairman, Commissioner Dombrovskis, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank Mr Hökmark for his efforts in compiling the report. Thanks also to the other shadow rapporteurs for the positive and productive collaboration. The result is a clear compromise that a large majority can support. Every year we invest a lot of time in analyzing our economy and trying to determine how we can do it better. The main result is the country-specific recommendations. I would therefore ask the Member States to implement them. Of course you can have different views on many measures, but a high debt burden is a risk and a mortgage on the future. We must make sure that our children and grandchildren do not have to pay the bill for this. We shouldn't spend less, but different. We must invest more in research and innovation in order to maintain our competitiveness. Modernize the economy, reduce administrative burdens and reduce taxes on labor, to attract more investment, which will stimulate growth. Investing in innovation will ensure employment and prosperity for the future. Countries that are doing less well, in terms of budget or in terms of competitiveness and productivity, must make more efforts. Emphasis should be placed on education and skills. And financing for businesses and SMEs needs to be improved. On the other hand, Member States that do well should certainly not be punished. Finally, I would like to emphasize the following: the basis of an economy is a healthy balance between income and expenditure, so a healthy tax system. This is the responsibility of the Member States. The semester is a document that gives a broad picture of our economy. Employment, like many other aspects, is part of this. In the future economic and monetary affairs must remain the basis of the report.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Mr Dombrovskis, as you have admitted, in the years of crisis, inequalities have increased dangerously, both socially and regionally. Instead of converging, we have a gap between rich and poor, North and South. That is why there is a need to deepen the political and economic integration of the euro area, but with a focus on reducing unemployment, strengthening growth that mainly supports the weakest and social cohesion. And this requires measures: strengthening the Juncker Fund, more funding to reduce youth unemployment, strengthening the role of the European Investment Bank, stimulating demand and investment in countries like Germany, which has a brutal primary surplus to the detriment of the European South, and also European debt solutions which is a European problem. Mr Dombrovskis, it is time for action, not words and wishes in a "business as usual" spirit. That is what the European Parliament is asking you to do.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur for the cooperation. Even though we had too many divergences to have an agreement on that particular file, the spirit was constructive, and I would like to thank you for that.  We are very critical of the assessment that we will do in the Semester. We believe that, in a way, we are supporting the implementation of a policy mix that is failing; one that basically says ‘cut public expenditure, implement supply-side structural reforms, and everything will be fine’. We believe that the flaws and problems of the European economy are still very big, and we need to correct that. Once the action of the ECB diminishes, our economies are probably still not ready to continue in a sustainable path for growth.  We are, in that sense, too complacent with the report regarding the current state of the euro area economy, and we remain too silent on the institutional reforms required for its future at the current juncture. Furthermore, the environmental and sustainability angle is missing, as the need to increase resource efficiency and to adapt the economy to the fight against climate change is not mentioned in the report. We also have, in the text, a strongly productivist narrative insisting on the need to achieve high GDP growth rates and to increase, as a priority, price competitiveness. There is no mention, as Mr Papadimoulis was saying, of the issue of macroeconomic and financial imbalances inside the eurozone, and we know that the macroeconomic imbalances procedure should be used by the Commission in a much more decisive way, taking into account the imbalances that we have inside the euro area. Finally, there is also no mention of the issues related to taxation and no mention of the CCCTB or the need to advance in other fields regarding taxation. So my Group remains very critical both on the process of the Semester and on the report of its assessment this year, and that is why we cannot support the report this time. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Marco VALLI
text: question "blue card".- I am grateful to my colleague who mentioned the macroeconomic imbalances procedure.I wanted to ask him, precisely, if he does not believe that the time has come to proceed with sanctions against these countries, given that it is precisely the most rigorous countries that very often ask peripheral countries to respect the rules and then only theycomply with them, or they continually receive very mild recommendations.Should we not ask the Commissioner, given that he is here and should answer us?

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: "blue card" response.- Yes, I agree with MEP Valli that there is a procedure that can be activated in the event of very large imbalances, through the MIP.We have, at the moment, a very sustained trade imbalance, a very sustained surplus on the part of some Member States for a long time.And we have asked the European Commission many times what the criteria are, basically for how long and at what level should this level of surplus be for them to activate the IPM.And, so far, they don't respond to it.But I totally agree with the Member that this issue should be activated, because it is one of the main imbalances that the euro area has at the moment.

name: Marco VALLI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that, as every time in the semester procedure, there is an unacceptable relationship, which sees a major compromise between socialists and popular people since the beginning of this legislature towards a failed austerity policy , which is exalted as deserving by the positive data that exist in these moments, when it is clear that the data are positive for a positive macroeconomic trend following the expansionary monetary policies carried out by all central banks. The exaltation of the reforms within these relations is scandalous, precisely because the reforms that have been carried out are aimed at wage devaluation. This is not the way to balance those imbalances, such as the German surplus, which are engulfing the internal demand of the eurozone and above all of the countries of the South. including Germany and the Netherlands, has reached unacceptable levels, and therefore we must face the problem head-on, avoiding, as usual in these relations, not to talk about it because the popular and socialists do not like to come up with the truth about the macroeconomic imbalances of the euro area. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: blue-card question. – Mr Valli, I would like to thank you for accepting the blue card. I couldn’t let that pass; when I listen to you, it is as if it is always the fault of someone else when a Member State has economic problems. Couldn’t you accept that all Member States need to look at the reforms: budget reforms and structural reforms in order to achieve higher levels of growth? Don’t you see that the differences between different Member States tell you something that we need to do, that we cannot just spend and spend more than we have because we will not get more money by that?

name: Marco VALLI
text: answer to a "blue card" question.- I believe that there are many differences between the Member States, but I do not think that the reforms that are pushed by the European Commission, which are very often aimed at wage devaluation in the peripheral countries, are a right way to solve the internal imbalances in the eurozone.This is the politics perpetrated.We have a truly scandalous level of underemployment, especially in countries like Italy where reforms in the world of work have been applied.When there is a reverse on monetary policies we will see the usual imbalances in the euro area come out, so it would be advisable to put an end to these imbalances with concrete measures towards the currency area to make it optimal, which is however very difficult.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are talking here today about the economic policies of the euro area. I believe that the only reform, as far as the euro area is concerned, that is worth discussing is the dismantling of Maastricht. Maastricht, what came after and what was done in preparation for this treaty and for the European Economic and Monetary Union, today represent the main problem not only for the Southern states but for all of Europe. The euro and the Economic and Monetary Union, by their nature and their architecture, are fueling divergences not only between the Member States but also within the various social classes of the Member States. The proof we have from the votes in various countries: this is what happened in Germany, where the poorest population and most defeated by these East German policies voted for parties considered extremist. I believe that the time has come to sit around a table and think about how to dismantle this single currency, which does not work, and to restart Europe on a path of homogeneous growth and development and in cooperation between sovereign states.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, we must finally acknowledge that Economic and Monetary Union, which has been marked by illegal proceedings under the Maastricht Treaty, has caused catastrophic economic, social and political disasters in many Member States, and in my own country in particular. concequenses. Unemployment rates, especially among young people, are structurally high, entire social groups are impoverished, the number of non-performing loans is growing rapidly, investment is not being made due to the prolonged recession and GDP growth rates are steadily declining. Fiscal and monetary policy must be the sole responsibility of the Member States without restrictions and intervention by the Union, as is the case with the signing of memoranda or country-specific recommendations. In a spirit of full respect for democratic principles and the principle of national sovereignty. In addition, a formal democratic, achievable, simple and rapid mechanism for the smooth voluntary withdrawal or self-exclusion of EMU and the single currency must be provided for.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: - Mr President, Vice-President Dombrovskis! The Hökmark report comes at the right time. We have moderate growth in all Member States, unemployment is falling consistently, and we have the expectation and hope that the public deficits in the euro area will also continue to decrease. However, there is still enough untapped potential and we have plenty of room for improvement, because the Member States have still only implemented two thirds of their country-specific recommendations. We know that more structural reforms and more private and public investment would mean at least 1% more growth. We know from the Monti report that completing the internal market means at least 3% more growth if we only do what we have already decided and what we have set out to do. I therefore believe that the report is putting its finger in the right wounds, addressing the right challenges and the need for action, because the European Semester gives the Commission the opportunity to put its finger in the wounds, but the contradiction between data and objectives will become more and more clearly visible. The European semester is no substitute for further developing the monetary union on the basis of Community law towards an economic union. It does not replace the creation of a European Minister for the Economy and Finance. It does not replace the fact that we are making the ESFM the European Monetary Fund under Community law. If we also implement the report in a complementary manner, then we will contribute to deepening the economic and monetary union and expanding it for more growth and employment.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, in referring to the report by our colleague Othmar Karas on the recommendation for the euro zone, you in fact also addressed the question of the reform that we expect for December 6, at the Commission initiative on the deepening and completion of Economic and Monetary Union. Let me say a word about it, because I believe that, in this perspective, this recommendation for the euro area, for once - for the first time - really takes into account this concept to which we attach great importance, namely the question of the aggregate position of the euro area. If we want to have a real tool for managing the area, we must pull all the thread we can from this notion. From this point of view, you mentioned the inequalities existing within certain Member States and between Member States. This is why we must use this aggregate position of the euro zone to identify the points where Member States can have room for maneuver and where we must be able to mobilize both public investment and private investment. This is how we can move forward. You also mentioned the integration of the budgetary pact or TSCG in Union law. You know, we had a debate here some time ago. We will not accept it under any conditions. A margin of flexibility to correct the economic failings contained in this treaty is absolutely essential, including if you want to consolidate this state of health of the policies of the economies of the euro zone which you are delighted with. These, Mr President, are the few contributions I wanted to make to this debate.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: - (FI) Mr President, despite the recovery in the euro area, economic policy has been ineffective in rapidly reducing unemployment.The basic problem, the single currency, is not even mentioned in the report, as are exchange rates in general, even though they have played a key role in the recovery of the euro area.The various structural reforms proposed and implemented have not or will not compensate for the absence of exchange rate policies in the Member States, which prevents rapid adjustments in competitiveness between countries.Increasing economic resilience is, in practice, often about falling wages, which is a slow, painful and risky way of restoring lost competitiveness, and may not even be possible.Unfortunately, this issue is completely ignored in the report.I believe that the report should address all the key economic policy issues.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice President - who is not paying attention to me, but hey - the European Semester tells us that we have achieved a certain stable financial consolidation - we hope it is not fragile -; that job grades improve —we know that that way—; that there is some growth - it is not like to shoot rockets, we hope that the clouds do not obscure it -. I am going to focus on the lack of perception in society, in many areas of Europe, of these improvements. I am going to tell you that there are three fundamental reasons: one is the difficulty of resigning ourselves to the fact that things will not be as before, but we cannot do much; the other is the duality of the job market and lost generations like NEETs - we can do a lot and we have to put it into the European Semester -; and the third and fundamental is the now unacceptable growth of inequalities. And for that we need fiscal distribution policies, investment policies and income policies throughout the European Semester aimed, obsessively, at reducing inequality dynamics.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: - Mr President, in the name of employment, this Swedish-inspired euro zone initiative report supports the most sterile and blind Germanic ordoliberalism. This report certainly supports a hard line in view of the Commission's next euro zone package. The main question is above all to know whether or not the European Monetary Fund will ultimately find itself in charge of the budgetary surveillance of the Member States, as Germany wishes, which will thus have a formidable tool for putting public finances under control. from other European countries. This is an unacceptable political threat to a nation that wants to be independent. In the end, we therefore completely reject this report. In reality, it would be more effective and urgent to combat the surplus in the German foreign trade balance, which is sapping economic growth in the rest of the euro zone. We therefore propose the following alternatives: that Germany should invest in the euro zone; that German companies agree to revalue the salaries of their employees in order to revive German domestic demand; and that the ECB's quantitative easing plan be transformed into a program of monetization of government debt by national central banks.

name: Maria ARENA
text: - Mr President, the loss of confidence in the European market following the 2008 crisis, but also the reduction in public spending had direct effects on European growth, which today remains slow and above all - you said it, Commissioner - is not inclusive growth, given the great disparities in Europe today. In terms of employment in particular, if we note an increase in the employment rate, it nevertheless appears that this increase does not concern all countries or all regions of Europe. Above all, we note that it is accompanied by more precarious jobs and has not made it possible to reverse the curve of youth unemployment. Today, parts of Europe have a youth unemployment rate of over 30%. So it is true that we have to offer better. We have put forward a few proposals: first, to increase public and private investment, which creates jobs in regions that are not benefiting from the effects of the recovery; second, to give importance to education and training within the framework of the European Semester; third, strengthen the “youth” guarantee; fourth, to stress the importance of collective bargaining in improving the purchasing power of workers; fifth, tackle income polarization and strengthen social protection systems; and, finally, work on the work-life balance. All of this must be able to be done through discussions in the framework of the Employment, Social Policy, Health and Consumers Council (EPSCO), which I believe should be associated with the European Semester.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: - Mr President. Any economic policy in the euro area is distorted by the monetary policy of the European Central Bank. The ECB has already repurchased public debt for more than EUR 2 trillion and its balance sheet total is more than 40% of euro area GDP. This is a record in times of peace. The European Central Bank currently buys government bonds in seven times the net debt increase. At the same time, the European Central Bank may not repurchase public debt. At the same time, interest rates have been at zero for a long time, which puts those who save and manage responsibly and, on the contrary, favors borrowers. The European Central Bank is beyond any democratic control, and Commission President Juncker pretends that he is not affected by this huge problem. It is nice that we are dealing with the economic policy of the euro area here, but it is much more important to focus on monetary policy and the actions of the European Central Bank.

name: Jakob von WEIZSÄCKER
text: – Mr President, I welcome this report on the euro area, and in particular that it points to the danger of complacency. However, I fear the danger of complacency is much more profound than this report is able to express.  There is a danger of complacency in the financial sector as the memories of the crisis fade. This week the Commission withdrew the banking structural reform proposal, to the great applause of the European Peoples’ Party and Gunnar Hökmark, and globally significant banks and their lobbyists are having quite a party knowing that the taxpayer will continue to be on the line when things go wrong. Also, there is a real danger of complacency with regard to the future of the euro area. It is regrettable that the report does not elaborate on the rather plausible scenario of interest rates going up within the next 18 months, which would stand to put a lot of pressure on countries that have below—average growth and above—average debt levels.  I fear, while I welcome the 6 December package that the Commission has pointed to, that this package is unlikely to be sufficient. Member States – France and Germany in particular – need to use the present window of opportunity to really move the currency union to the next level. Stopping short of that, there is a real danger that complacency will be our peril.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the report indicates that the rules of the stability pact must be interpreted intelligently. I say this because flexibility is the rule, not a kind concession. In recent years, the European semester has shown its limits, in fact the macro data remain uneven. If we want to converge we must put economic growth, social inclusion and convergence at the heart of the semester. Obviously the rules of the pact and the single currency cannot, alone, solve the structural problems of the euro area. It is therefore crucial to take some clear decisions at the political level. There are several: in particular, given the theme, a positive aggregate fiscal stance in the euro area; a fiscal capacity for the euro area to support investment and an unemployment mechanism, the latter financed from the Union's own resources, to avoid an excessive burden on national budgets; then rethink the institutional architecture of the euro area. This is also the time to acknowledge that during the negative phases of the cycle we need the possibility for the European Union to have a deficit and to issue public bonds at zero risk. I say this because at this moment the risk is to decide not to decide and this could risk plunging us back into the crisis from which the exit has laboriously begun.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Mr President, what we are doing here has got to be judged politically. Social items in the European semester should have been given more priority. We have grown used to the idea that populist discourse, populist and extremist movements, have grown as a consequence of the 2008 crisis. The austerity, the rigid budgetary rules that were introduced in the Eurozone, were meant to reengineer growth and prosperity. Meanwhile, established centrist parties – especially on the left – lost huge amounts of votes. They expected to get them back when growth reappeared.  This semester’s premises seem to show that it has done so. Growth has reappeared. But the political situation remains bleak. A few weeks ago, President Juncker said that the window of opportunity had opened for new steps in the European construction to be taken fast.
