Following the German, the Austrian and the Czech elections, matters look murkier. Is it that voters disbelieve that growth is back, or is there something within the present growth that they do not like? Are social disparities decreasing, or are they widening?  Politically, we need replies to these questions, which again means that the European semester should make the content of its social chapters more relevant and more effective.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the economic policy of austerity has shown all its limits. In order to achieve significant levels of growth, greater investments and structural reforms need to be linked to the stabilization of national budgets, as well as to modulate intervention measures for individual Member States. But, as President Draghi recalled a few days ago, to make the path of structural reforms socially acceptable, it needs to be accompanied by inclusive economic policies with redistributive effects. In the euro area, there is still an investment gap. In some states, investments have already exceeded pre-crisis levels, but in others they are stagnating or not proceeding at the same speed, particularly in Southern Europe, where the unemployment rate, especially among young people, is of concern. Further measures are therefore needed to close the investment gap accumulated since the outbreak of the crisis. Strengthening and making the "Youth Guarantee" program more efficient, but also investing more and better in training, research, young talents and innovative start-ups represent the essential coordinates of an effective economic policy in the euro area.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, as a direct result of an ECB diktat to bail out two non-systemic banks, Ireland is forced to borrow and burn billions. We’re talking about policies of the eurozone: this is a policy of the ECB. In 2015, the Irish Central Bank destroyed EUR two billion; in 2016, EUR three billion; in 2017 so far, EUR 2.5 billion, and another EUR four billion to come. That is EUR 8.5 billion in the last three years.  This is an ECB policy, a policy to pay back a debt that was never Ireland’s. Many here may say, ‘sure, can’t we afford it, isn’t our economy booming?’ Yes, if you accept that one can eat GDP, but GDP growth in Ireland’s case is totally unconnected to ordinary people’s wealth. It does not trickle down. We have record hospital waiting lists. We have record homelessness. We cannot afford the most basic climate change mitigation measures, yet it is the policy of the ECB that my country should continue to borrow and burn billions. And you know what? No one here gives a damn.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: - I very much hope that the British decision to withdraw from the European Union will force us to focus on overcoming various political risks.The wave of populism and protectionism has not yet receded, we must be vigilant, and its causes are well known: high income inequality, social exclusion, the refugee crisis, terrorism, segregation between Eastern and Western European Union countries, and external threats.We need to work and overcome these challenges, which will improve the socio-economic climate and promote economic growth.And it is not at all necessary to rush or force all Member States that do not yet have the euro to adopt it.Sustainable and socially responsible economic growth based on euro area cooperation is very important to all of us.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I would like to start by welcoming the first report expressly dedicated to the eurozone. Following the Commission’s first proposal for a eurozone fiscal stance, I support a positive fiscal stance that will allow Member States to invest more and that directly contributes to the increase of growth and employment. In order to build a stronger Europe, we need to create a more social Europe and to lay the ground for social growth based on a general approach, but also on a country—specific approach. Therefore, we need to ensure that the fiscal policies are led with the necessary flexibility at EU level. Member States must have freedom to manoeuver in their fiscal policies, especially when considering the needed structural reforms to be implemented.  We need to strengthen our fiscal sustainability, vital for our future cohesion. Structural economic reforms should increase EU sustainable growth potential, real economy convergence and social cohesion by reducing economic inequalities and strengthening labour markets through inclusion policies that favour investments.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for the fruitful debate we had today and I would like to acknowledge the work of the committees involved in the drafting of this report.  Hearing your views here today was useful and enlightening ahead of the start of the new European semester cycle. As I mentioned, in November we will issue the proposal for a recommendation on economic policy of the euro area. Indeed, this recommendation, as a number of you have noted, will aim to identify common challenges for the euro area and will serve as a guidance for the subsequent formulation of country-specific recommendations.  One of the key messages from the debate is that cyclical conditions are improving and the economic upswing is strengthening. There are still significant economic and social challenges, and there is no time for complacency.  So, let me reiterate that we must create the conditions to support inclusive and balanced growth, further reduce unemployment and promote investment. We must strengthen the resilience of our economies and restart the process of economic and social convergence in the euro area. For this, the better use of our existing tools of economic policy coordination is essential, but not sufficient. The euro area is now much better equipped to face challenges than it was before the crisis, but we have to make sure that we address the remaining important gaps in our economic governance and the institutional state of the Economic and Monetary Union.  Honourable President, honourable Members, thank you once again and I look forward to continuing cooperation throughout the European semester cycle.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner and not only the shadow rapporteurs, but all of those who have participated in this debate. I think there are mainly two lines that have been presented here. Some think that we can solve the problems by spending more and ignoring the fact that sometimes there is no more money to spend. Some underlined the need for fiscal stability and structural reforms. This goes rather broad, because in the agreement in the report we see the need for balancing some of those. But I would like to warn against those who always say that someone else has the responsibility when it does not go well in a certain Member State. It is not about good luck. It is about good reforms, good management and good governance. Sometimes, I would like not least the friends over there, but maybe also the friends over there, to think whether we are doing as well as we can.  Commissioner, I think that some of the good news that we can take from this debate is the fact that we are not doing as well as we can. We can do much better. We can set the targets for higher growth. Each Member State should have the target of a potential growth of at least three percent and make the reforms that can provide the jobs, the growth and the investment that can give Europe a lead. I think it is time for us not only to take action, but also time to take responsibility. That applies to all of us – none less and none more – but we all need to have the courage to make the reforms we need for a stronger Europe.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Thursday 26 October 2017.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: - The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on: - the report by Paul Tan on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on establishing common rules for securitization, creating a European framework for simple, transparent and standardized securitization and amending Directive 2009/65 / EC, 2009/ 138 / EC, 2011/61 / EU and Regulations (EC) No 1060/2009 and (EU) No 648/2012 (COM (2015) 0472 - C8-0288 / 2015 - 2015/0226 (COD)) (A8-0387/2017) and - the report by Othmar Karas, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on prudential requirements for credit institutions and investment firms (COM (2015) 0473 - C8-0289 / 2015 - 2015/0225 (COD) (A8-0388/ 2017).

name: Paul TANG
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, it is good to have this debate just before the vote tomorrow. And the question is: has a toxic product turned into a medicine for the European economy? That is the question we have to ask ourselves and our voters – our public. I dare to say yes, in the realisation that any medicine can be toxic if it is taken in excess. A medicine can be toxic if it is taken in an uncontrolled manner, meaning that you have to take control. I will come back to that.  I am happy to have had the debate not only now, but also on many occasions in this House. It is an extremely important topic if only because of its history. We know that the financial crisis started with toxic products – mortgages – in the USA and then almost blew up the entire system. This was a major blow to the financial sector, the economy and people’s everyday lives. I am happy that we have had this debate, and I would like to take this opportunity to thank all the people that worked on this, and of course the shadows, especially Othmar Karas – who you could say is my co-rapporteur – as well as the people from the Commission and the Council. I ask forgiveness for having sometimes been strong-headed and a bit stubborn, but I hope I have never been narrow-minded.  The start of this discussion, which was almost two years ago, was with a proposal from the Commission and also the proposal from the Commission tried to draw lessons from the crisis, for example by defining clear responsibilities for issuers and investors. The issuers have to disclose information and the investors have to do due diligence. No longer can someone say ‘I didn’t know what I was selling’, or ‘I didn’t know what I was buying’.  But another question we had in the debate in Parliament was ‘are these all the lessons that we need to learn from a financial crisis?’ Put differently – more technically – what you want is a deep and liquid market at all times, in good times and in bad times. The European Parliament has added some of these lessons.  Firstly, an issue that is not at the core of our discussion: sustainability. We added sustainability by including characteristics of houses and cars. This also shows that we have to do this more consistently as legislators – both the Commission and the Parliament. I know that the Commissioner is working on that, and I very much support it. More at the core of this file was the prudential framework and strong supervision, giving clear roles to the ESRB and to the ESMA. This is important when you want to control the market.  The second was transparency: data repositories now giving a role to European Data Warehouse. There was also a discussion on the retention rates – the skin in the game. As I learnt, through discussions in this House and outside this House, it was not just about the rate, it was about the method.  There is still an important difference between a horizontal and a vertical method, because it is not about the rate, it is about the incentive. The European Parliament has taken a good position by differentiating between the two, but we also know that we will have a review later. This is the part that the European Parliament has to take a very close look at.  Finally, let me say that this is also for the supervisors. They have an important role to monitor and control this market.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President Dombrovskis, ladies and gentlemen! The new rules for securitisations are an important step on the way to creating a European capital markets union, good news for Europe as a financial and business location and a success for the European Parliament. By converting receivables into tradable securities, securitization spreads risk so that it can be borne by those who are best placed to do so. It creates new investment opportunities and it improves household and business lending. Regarding regulation, there were two things that had to be reconciled: on the one hand, we want to learn an important lesson from the financial crisis and ensure financial stability; on the other hand, we want to revive the European market and address the 42% decline in emissions compared to the pre-crisis level. We have achieved the goals for which the European Parliament has worked so hard from the start, and I should like to thank Mr Tang and the other colleagues in committee very warmly. We create simple, transparent and uniform rules - a safe vehicle that helps to finance the real economy and to restore trust in the European securitization market, both between banks and other financial instruments. The two jointly negotiated legal acts - I am the rapporteur and EPP rapporteur - work hand in hand to achieve these goals. If we think of it as a car, then the new framework for all securitisations would probably be the body and the revision of the Capital Adequacy Ordinance its engine. In order to keep the engine running, we in Parliament have ensured that we encourage the spending of high-quality products with risk-based capital treatment for STS securitisations, that we deviate from Basel in the hierarchy of approaches under certain conditions Enabling the prerequisites for taking European peculiarities into account, that we are expanding incentives for SME securitisations and that we are forbidding re-securitisations so that credit risks can no longer be concealed from investors. For a robust body, we have set the risk deductible at 5% in line with global standards, created a securitization register for more transparency, ensured that car securitisations are carried out and enforced comprehensive monitoring of the securitization market. With this legislative package - illustrated in the body and engine - we show that we are serious about drawing clearer, more transparent and stricter rules together and regaining confidence in the market so that poison can become medicine and we can earn up to EUR 150 billion mobilize additional financial resources for the European economy, which we urgently need alongside the reforms in order to make growth and employment in Europe a permanent achievement again.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, today’s debate and your vote tomorrow concern one of the first proposals put forward as part of our capital markets union, and it is an important one. By defining criteria for simple, transparent and standardised securitisation (STS), we can revitalise European capital markets’ securitisation in a sustainable way. There is a broad consensus among regulators, supervisors and companies that this would benefit the European economy. It would free up more lending for investment and help manage risk in the banking sector. Securitisation allows banks to convert pools of individual loans into bonds, which are then sold to other institutions or long—term investors. This helps banks free up capital set aside for existing loans and, in this way, securitisation supports more lending to the wider economy and gives investors access to more investment instruments. Securitisation is believed by many to have been the trigger for the financial crisis in the US. While EU securitisation has performed well overall during the crisis, the crisis still reveals flaws in the way securitisation was regulated and supervised. At the moment securitisation in the EU is very low. Last year, issuance of securitised products in Europe was not even at half of its 2007 level. Given its important role in financing the real economy, in 2015 the Commission put forward a framework for revitalising the market in a prudent way. By rebuilding issuance back to the pre-crisis levels, we could generate an additional EUR 115 billion of yearly funding for households and companies.  After two years of discussions, I am happy to say that the final result is both balanced and ambitious. It will help restore an important funding channel for the EU economy, while learning from the mistakes of the past. The new regulation sets out specific criteria for securitisations to help investors understand the nature and the risk of what they are investing in. The qualifying securitisations would be simple. For example, only comparable loans can be brought together in one product, and the repackaging of other securitisations would generally not be allowed.  They would also be transparent, meaning that the right information is available for investors to assess risk and for supervisors to properly monitor markets. Building on the Parliament’s proposal, the package now includes an ESMA-supervised data repository to ensure the transparency of STS securitisations. Securitisations would be standardised to make them easy to identify and understand.  Our proposals contain appropriate safeguards. The issuer would need to retain at least 5% of the securitised asset. This is to ensure that their incentives are aligned with those of the investor. Underlying assets would also need to be creditworthy according to existing EU rules.  Finally, we are introducing new capital requirement rules for those banks that invest in securitisation in order to promote a stable and resilient banking sector. These requirements build on global standards and will fully reflect the lower risks associated with the STS securitisation.  So we have done important work to agree on the final text. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the European Parliament and, in particular, the Chair of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, Roberto Gualtieri, the rapporteurs, Paul Tang and Othmar Karas, and the shadow rapporteurs. Let us now conclude this important chapter in building the capital markets union so that the benefits to businesses and households can be quickly realised.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, indeed, with this legislative package on securitization, we are taking an important step towards achieving what we call the European Union of capital markets. Why do I say this? Firstly, for the first time, we are introducing common rules on securitization, not only for all Member States, but also for all categories of financial activities, be they banking, insurance, asset management and other activities. Secondly, these rules ensure transparency, standardization, but also the necessary protection in the activity of converting financial assets, through securitization, into new financial products that are offered to investors. In this regard, as a precaution, I would like to emphasize in particular three measures contained in this legislative package: the retention of at least 5% of risk by those initiating securitization, strict conditions under which new financial products, resulting from securitization, can be offered to small investors and, finally, the prohibition of successive securitization operations for the same financial asset. Let's not forget, the financial crisis started exactly in the area of ​​securitization, of excesses within the US economy. I thank the reports and the Commission for this legislative package.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, the truth is that we have already come to this debate after a long time negotiating both Regulations, the one on STS securitizations and the one that varies their capital requirements. Many times the citizens with whom I meet in Asturias, in Spain, ask me what we do in this Chamber. Even the public that is here with us today asks us what is this about securitisations, or what we work on every day. And I have to say that it is sometimes very difficult to explain what our job is, how the regulations, the directives that we adopt and debate in this Parliament affect your day-to-day lives. I believe that today we approved two very important regulations, because many families are thinking, for example, of buying a car that they probably want to finance. Or many small businesses are having problems getting their banks to advance the collection of bills or allow them to place commercial paper. And these two Regulations come to help those people. These two Regulations will allow small companies that, in the large organized markets, do not have shares, that cannot issue bonds in the international capital markets, can more easily place this commercial paper through their own banking entities, Because they will be able to securitize it, they will be able to place it later in those international markets. They will also allow those households that are thinking of buying cars or buying another series of goods that they need to finance to be financed with better interest rates, with better treatment. Therefore, today we are taking a very important step, because we believe that we need to activate that financing capacity to the real economy and we do so. And we do it with prudence, because we have managed to get the European Systemic Risk Board to analyze capital markets to avoid bubbles like the one we experienced in the past crisis. And the We also achieve that the capital requirements or the cost for banks of carrying out this type of operations are a little lower, but always subject to very restrictive quality criteria on this type of loans: important qualities, high qualities so as not to commit againthe mistakes of the past crisis.Furthermore, with these two Regulations we help to create that European capital market.Because we defend that rating agencies, which always discriminate based on the quality of the sovereign, play a lesser role and international investors focus exclusively on the risk of small loans.Look at exactly what the risk is to avoid discrimination between the countries of the North and the countries of the South.So we are going to approve those two reports, and I think that, starting tomorrow, European citizens will notice this on a day-to-day basis.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs Mr Tang and Mr Karas on their reports. Securitised products can be incredibly complicated financial products, yet in the past they had an overly simplified reputation and consequently enjoyed widespread use.  Post-financial crisis, the use of securitisation has severely diminished across Europe, however. I therefore commend the effort shown by this Parliament to encourage understanding and rebuild trust and confidence in these instruments. I am pleased that we have managed to bring this report closer to international standards and ensure that the EU is not placed at a competitive disadvantage globally. However, I personally believe that we could have been even more ambitious in this proposal and, indeed, with the Capital Markets Union project as a whole, as this is an area in which our level of achievement does not so far seem to match up to our rhetoric.  For CMU to work, it needs decisive action, not purely discussion and then compromise. We need an overhaul of national tax laws that favour debt over equity-financing, a reaffirmation of a commitment to global, supervisory cooperation and standards globally. Furthermore, a cultural shift here in Europe from savings to investment is critical.  The aims of CMU need to guide our hand in all ongoing legislation. We need consistency across all legislative files. The EMIR review, for example, needs to be very specifically about finding solutions to the unintended consequences and burdens that we have placed upon non-financial companies. Therefore, the classification of securitisation special purpose entities as financial counterparties, for example, as recently released in the Commission draft report, seems to contradict and threaten what we have achieved in the securitisation legislation. We need to be careful going forwards.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, colleagues, the simple, transparent and standardised (STS) securitisation regulation is a key milestone as we move towards a capital markets union. I believe that carefully monitored, high—quality securitisation can serve to benefit business across Europe. In the EU as a whole, we are too reliant on loans and other forms of funding from banks. Capital markets give businesses a new avenue for funding for their activities. The diversification of funding is important to help deliver more growth for the European economy.  During our negotiations on this regulation, we tried to find the right balance between the lessons learned from the financial crisis and having a framework which ensured that we did not stifle the potential of the securitisation market. We have agreed to have a sensible level of skin in the game, with the risk retention rate for banks of 5%. We have recognised the specificities of the asset-backed commercial paper (ABCP) market, particularly as regards pools of car loans and leases. We have enhanced the transparency of securitisation markets, notably through the establishment of data repositories which will enable competent authorities to have a full overview of the products in the market. We have ensured that those who are responsible for originating securitisation products take full responsibility for the products’ place in the marketplace. They will not be able to shift responsibility to empty shelves such as special—purpose vehicles. In the Capital Requirements Regulation (CRR) file we have adjusted the prudential requirements by adding a new hierarchy approach and a more risk-sensitive prudential treatment of STS securitisation. In my view, the text we will vote on tomorrow is sensible, prudent, and most of us will give European companies more possibilities to grow.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. Mr President, in the name of the capital adequacy of Greek banks, in the name of the liberalization of the securities market and in the name of the management of non-performing loans, the looting of public housing in Greece is taking place. Greek banks, after three recapitalizations that cost the Greek people over 50 billion, are again at a disadvantage with red loans on their balance sheets that reach 102 billion euros. The troika and the Greek government have agreed to hammer out even the first house through electronic auctions and the sale to special funds - the "crows" - of red loans. They do not care about the suffering Greek people, they do not care about the effects of the seven-year economic crisis and the policies of the memoranda that have led to poverty, impoverishment, unemployment and the destruction of the productive base of the country. The Greek people, Mr. President, with the slogan "no house in the hands of a banker", say no to the auctions of public property and housing, and defend their house, their work and their dignity.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, it is now nearly a decade since the financial crisis devastated European economies. At the heart of that crisis was the process of repackaging debt to turn it into new assets, a highly lucrative business, but one that created risks to our financial system when unscrupulous traders bundled bad debts with good, kept the profits and socialised the risks. Today we are debating an attempt by the European institutions to restart this process of securitisation and to give it a seal of approval as STS: simple, transparent securitisation. Sadly, most in the Parliament and Council of Ministers who have agreed on this new legislation seem not to have learned the lessons of the crisis. Greens attempted to limit the damage securitisation might do by proposing that banks share much more of the risk of the loans that they sell off to ensure that they keep adequate skin in the game. They should be discouraged from investing in each other securitisations and should ensure that the products are as simple as possible. This would mean that investors can access the highest-quality information about what is actually in the box, including to what extent the securitisation contributes to sustainability goals. Rather than strengthening standards against a repetition of past problems, the already unsatisfactory proposal from the Commission was watered down in favour of banks and other lenders of specific kinds of loans, specifically car loans, which many have warned may represent a subprime—style bubble. Negotiations with the Council, where Member States demonstrated even less concern for the safety of the financial system, delivered a result that represents a bad deal for ordinary citizens.  This legislation is the latest example of political amnesia and regulatory rollback with the EU’s political leadership favouring the narrow interests of an oversized financial system over the need to promote financial stability, funding to entrepreneurs and small businesses and quality jobs in the real economy. We regret that it will be passed tomorrow and we will certainly vote against it as a group.

name: Marco VALLI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the greed of the financial system and the inability of politics to react led us to the crisis of 2008-2009, where there had been reckless use of these credit securitization products. It seems a bit absurd to me that today attempts are made to relaunch the economy by using securitisations which, despite a security that seems not very aggressive (ie "simple, transparent and standardized"), in fact will not be so because the wrong instrument is used to try to revive the economy. In reality, what will be relaunched will be the profits of speculative funds, very interested in buying these securitisations and managing them. In fact, on the one hand the European Central Bank continues to give ever higher capital requirements to send the banks that lend money to the real economy into crisis and on the other hand there is the European Commission which pushes to speed up this process and incentivize useful to them. Here, with this system we will not go anywhere. We should start with a real banking separation, but unfortunately yesterday the European Commission put a tombstone on it, eliminating it definitively from its program. We need to change course because with these tools we risk other systemic crises.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission! Only recently, the US Treasury Secretary made a series of proposals for reforming the US capital market - including securitization proposals. It bothers him that the post-crisis reforms put securitisations at a disadvantage compared to other, more traditional forms of financing, such as bank deposits. It also annoys him that loan amounts have to be hedged when they are securitized and bundled as if they were listed individually on bank balance sheets. Europe is taking a different path here. In September 2015, the Commission first published the proposal for STS securitisations, i.e. securitisations that are simple, transparent and standardized. Parliament, the Council and the Commission have now agreed on the framework data for a new securitization regulation, which consists of two sets of rules that are being discussed today. These are the Securitization Ordinance - the criteria for all securitisations, in particular STS securitisations, requirements for due diligence and risk retention - and secondly the adjustments to the Capital Adequacy Ordinance (CRR) to implement the revised Basel securitization rules for institutions. For banks, the transfer of the Basel regulations will result in increased risk weights, but these will be lower in the future if they meet STS criteria. In other words, the STS criteria create incentives to make the European capital market more secure and robust.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, one of the main pillars of the Capital Markets Union is the effort to revitalize the securitization market in order to improve the financing of our economy. The regulatory package that we will approve tomorrow establishes common standards for all securitisations and constitutes a framework so that securitization products are, despite the doubts of some, safe, simple and transparent, and are standardized and sufficiently supervised. These new rules will help investors better assess the risks related to securitization, both in the products themselves and in the different product categories. In 2014 we saw the securitization market shrink by almost 50% from its peak in 2007, and this led to many SMEs not getting the funding they requested. This agreement helps to create new investment opportunities throughout the Union and offers an additional source of financing for the economy, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises and start-ups. Thanks to the reactivation of the securitization market, we will achieve more diversified sources of financing and less dependent on the banking sector, thus contributing to the overall stability and resilience of the financial system. The Commission's projections show that if the volume of securitization in the European Union were to reach the pre-crisis average level, it could generate between € 100 and € 150 billion more in funding. The main ones favored would be small and medium-sized companies, which are the engine of the European economy. In conclusion, a well-structured securitization market will help to improve the efficiency and stability of the financial system, provide investment opportunities and create benefits for citizens and businesses, with cheaper and more accessible loans. Welcome this proposal and congratulations to the negotiating team for their great work.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, you know, for the Socialist Group, the idea that the urgency was to relaunch the securitization market, when we know the responsibility of this market in the crisis whose Europe has not yet fully emerged and from which it continues to suffer some of the effects, was not obvious. We had set a number of conditions and welcomed the idea of ​​retention by the banks, in order to refine their responsibility in the production of these financial products. On this point, we were a little disappointed, the rapporteur said. However, I salute his determination, which allows us to have legislation that advances on three very significant points for our group, which I want to reiterate here. First, an explicit role for the European ESMA supervisor so that he can be engaged in compulsory mediation in the event of disagreement between the various competent authorities. This goes beyond what the Council wanted and I believe it is a good approach not to get lost in endless conflicts. The second step forward that I want to underline - it is also the result of our determination - is to ensure that this securitization cannot be based in tax havens, in particular those appearing in the list of countries identified by the FATF. as not contributing to the fight against tax evasion, within the framework of the OECD conventions. The third point, which is just as close to our hearts, is the idea - the rapporteur has reminded us - that, when it comes to mortgages or car loans, environmental criteria are included - in a way, we We have anticipated the work that you are now carrying out within the European Commission - which we also introduced in the context of the PRIIPs, and which we will continue to promote, so that the financial markets also make their contribution to the sustainable development of our planet.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: - Mr Chairman! Despite the lack of enthusiasm, the Polish delegation of the ECR group decided to support the draft framework plan. On the one hand, we appreciate the fact that securitization can increase the efficiency and stability of the financial system and create additional sources of cheap financing for SMEs, but on the other hand, this system has serious drawbacks. Credit risk is only shifted from a banking institution to a non-banking one, which will make it difficult for regulators to control financial operations. What kind of transparency - Ladies and Gentlemen - are we talking about? The second major risk is that banks may manipulate the ranking of these artificially generated instruments, again without external control. In my opinion, the project requires constant supervision and impact assessment so that its only beneficiary does not turn out to be the powerful banking sector, but that it primarily protects the ultimate interests of credit service recipients, i.e. entrepreneurs and retail clients.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, securitisation is a measure that allows for the transformation of illiquid financial assets into fully tradable financial instruments. In this way, asset-backed securities deepen the liquidity or financial markets and increase the capacity of banks to extend more credit. Moreover, they allow the risk and term structure of available marketable financial instruments to better adjust to the different risk preferences of individual investors. In this sense, securitisation is able to contribute to financial stability and the more efficient allocation of resources across the economy. However, securitisation may carry also risks. Investors may not have access to full information about the underlying assets and their quality. Securitisation may also involve deals that are overly complex and even opaque. This may result in excessive risk taking by investors and may lead to accumulation of systemic risk in the entire financial sector. The idea behind the two legislative measures we are discussing today is to reduce these risks and to promote a safe and liquid market for securitisation in the EU. Firstly, the regulation strengthens requirements for due diligence and imposes minimal risk-retention standards to ensure that banks retain a net material interest in asset-backed securities they issue. Secondly, there is a ban on re-securitisation. Thirdly, all underlying documentation relevant for any transaction is made readily available to investors. Fourthly, the crucial amendment to the CRR ensures that the capital treatment of securitisation for banks better reflects the risks involved.  Mr. President, I would like to express my thanks to both rapporteurs and to the European Commission for their work. When adopted, this package will not only help us establish a clear set of criteria to identify simple, transparent and standardised securitisations, but it will also contribute to building the Capital Markets Union in Europe.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, we have heard that 10 years ago a major US bank announced losses of USD 8.4 billion in a quarter due to subprime mortgages. The following months were the start of the subprime crisis due to the meltdown of securitisation products affecting European banks. The rest, we all know, is history. But here we are today debating a new securitisation proposal that should ensure the impact of any future crisis is limited. So my congratulations to the rapporteurs, Paul Tang and Othmar Karas, for getting this complex regulation agreed. I do welcome the fact that it makes financial instruments safer and more transparent, and that there will be greater standardisation. This is a real step forward, and it ensures that an important source of capital can support SMEs in the European economy. It will also bring more substance to the CMU initiative. So there are three points that stand out for me: a new macroprudential framework to ensure efficient oversight of the securitisation market to detect new bubbles; the creation of a data repository to increase transparency for investors and making it mandatory for insurance to make the information public; and a more sustainable financial system. Nonetheless, Commissioner, I believe there are issues that you still need to be addressing. How do you see the impact of this new regulation in the context of Brexit, given the high level of activity that takes place in the UK and how confident are you that history will not repeat itself, given the trends in the US towards deregulation?

name: Sander LOONES
text: - When banks repackage a lot of loans and then sell them to other financial players, we call this securitization - securitization in correct Dutch. All very complex, but very important. For example, if you look at the movie “The Big Short”, it nicely explains how this securitization was at the root of the financial crisis in the United States. A good film by the way, highly recommended, Oscar won too, a film with Ryan Gosling and Christian Bale. But we must therefore be careful with those financial tricks, with those techniques, and that is why I think it is really important that the European Parliament proposes measures to make this simpler and, above all, more transparent. That is the only way to ensure that our financial system becomes stronger, more stable, while at the same time ensuring that sufficient resources are pumped into our economy and, in particular, our SMEs.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: - Sir. Chairman! Sir. Commissioner! Trading financial services, special loans, bonds, securities and other inventive ways to raise capital is a risky affair. The gains and benefits can be huge, but so can the losses and consequences. While in the years leading up to the financial crisis it was far too busy to deregulate the financial sector, today we are busy cleaning up after the barn of the past. With these new regulations, we are cleaning up some of the pockets of the financial world's wild west that still exist. It is hardly particularly popular in the executive aisles, but it is healthy for both the economy and ultimately for the industry itself. The recipe is straightforward. You take a proper shot of transparency, new demands for information about the real owners, end with hidden backers. We also require documentation of where these companies are located. No more hidden drawer companies. In addition, we require information on exactly how much money is involved in these constructions. In addition, a good deal of regulation in the form of a ban on operating from tax havens and countries with artificially low taxes, a ban on operating from countries that do not cooperate on the exchange of tax information, and last but not least, stricter penalties for those who do not can find out how to follow the common rules, both cash fines of up to one and a half million kroner, but also fines set based on a percentage of the company's turnover and wealth of private individuals. This is really good and much needed news in the fight for better regulation of the financial markets.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: - Mr President, securitization is at the root of the financialization of the economy and at the heart of the speculative bubble that burst in 2008 and plunged Europe and the world into a social and economic crisis, the impact of which still remains on our economies. Securitization is an instrument created by bankers to clear their balance sheets, gathering more or less doubtful credits and creating financial products that were never, nor will be, simple and much less transparent. This relaunch of the securitization market represents a step in the wrong direction. Europe does not need more finance. Europe needs more real economy, more jobs and more development. To speak of a lack of liquidity when the ECB has been drenching Europe with the purchase of assets for months is, to say the least, strange. In short, what we need is a public financial system and at the service of the economy of companies and workers. But this objective does not fit in this neoliberal European Union at the service of finance and large multinational companies.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, Mr Dombrovskis, the problem of red loans has hit the ceiling in Greece, exceeding 100 billion euros. Mr. Draghi's recent announcements about increased forecasts on banks' balance sheets due to red loans give commercial banks the alibi to securitize and sell red loans to special funds, ie to the "crows" and instead of a lentil plate. Since March 2016, I had proposed that the Cypriot model, which establishes the borrower's pre-emptive right to buy his loan at the first offer price made by the "crows", apply in Greece. At the same time, I had proposed the creation of a rescue fund for borrowers so that the Greeks could save their homes from the "crows", in order to put a full stop in the electronic auctions. Thus, 4.5 billion euros out of the 25 billion euros left over from the third loan package of 86 billion can finance the borrowers' rescue fund so that no house passes into the hands of a banker.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, first of all, I’m grateful for your engagement and support in the whole process that gets us to the positive result, and I hope that tomorrow’s vote will confirm this. With your support, we now have a clear set of rules to ensure that simple, transparent and standardised securitisation benefits the real economy. The new rules will clearly differentiate between those products which satisfy the criteria and those that do not. This works towards an important funding channel for the EU economy, without endangering financial stability.

name: Paul TANG
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you to all the contributors to this debate. It is interesting to hear that we still have a difference of opinion, and I think that these proposals – with good work from Othmar Karas – that we have brought together have been able to unite Parliament, but not entirely. Let that also be a warning that there are still some doubts that have been part of the debate.  There are opportunities that are emphasised: it could be an opportunity for refinancing the European economy, especially when the policy of cheap money will end one day. Securitisation will then be an important way of financing, but there are not only opportunities – there are also threats. I would like to call also on the supervisors that have been given an important role in this piece of legislation to take on the duty of closely monitoring and following the market, especially when the market starts – it is crucial that it starts in the right way, and that the market gets functioning. This is what I would like to see: if you want to develop a strong market, you also need a strong government and strong supervision. This is what I hope for, because we will see these markets start – maybe not today, maybe not tomorrow, but the day after tomorrow, when opportunities to finance become scarcer and securitisation becomes more attractive.  Finally, I would like to say that this debate will continue. We have a review, issues have been addressed in the debate, and the European Parliament should follow this market closely at the appropriate times – and I am sure that we will.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Rapporteur. - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! Almost everything has been said. But the debate has shown one thing: that we are capable of having a serious discussion with one another, even though the subject is so complex. That is parliamentarism. We have to seriously deal with the worries and fears and the opportunities and hopes and look for solutions together, and we have done that together here. I would like to take up the second point. Even if we now praise the results of the two reports and the trialogue, this is a single measure that cannot solve our problems on its own. We need the combination of the various measures and, above all, we need these measures to be implemented. I do not want to give hope that with these rules alone we will solve the problem we have and have learned all the lessons from the crisis. Again a small piece of the mosaic has succeeded. Thirdly, the debate has clearly shown: the causes of the crisis, on the other hand the risks of securitisations and, on the third hand, the opportunities. We tried to minimize the risks, to seize the opportunity and to regain trust through these regulations. We hope that we have succeeded in this with this package, and we will see that during the evaluation. But a good job has been done and I would ask colleagues to give their approval to these two reports tomorrow as an important contribution to the creation of a capital markets union that needs to be further developed.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint discussion on: - the report by Daniel Caspary, on behalf of the International Trade Commission, on the negotiating mandate for trade negotiations with Australia (2017/2192 (INI)) (A8-0311 / 2017), and - the report by Daniel Caspary, on behalf of the International Trade Commission, on the negotiating mandate for trade negotiations with New Zealand (2017/2193 (INI)) (A8-0312 / 2017).

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, maybe the plenary is so efficient today that people have not had time to go down the stairs, but for those Honourable Members who are here, I would like to talk about Australia and New Zealand tonight. As you know, they are friends, allies and partners of the European Union. We share a lot with them – our norms, our values, different approaches – and strengthening that relationship is a priority. The EU has signed political framework agreements with both countries to further strengthen the partnership on the basis of these values: respect for democratic principles, human rights, fundamental freedoms, the rule of law, promotion together of international peace and security, and also our joint work to strengthen the multilateral system and global rule—based trade. The EU has a healthy and mature trade and investment relationship with both these countries. We are one of the biggest partners of Australia and New Zealand in the trade of goods, services and foreign direct investment.  Australia and New Zealand have concluded foreign trade agreements with China, with ASEAN, with Japan and with Korea. They are part of the Trans—Pacific Partnership with 11 countries, and they are moving ahead. These developments have put European exporters of goods, services and investors in a comparatively less favourable situation compared to their competitors in other countries. The Commission has carried out an impact assessment, clearly showing the benefits of these agreements for European producers and consumers. The already considerable EU exports to both countries, on a par with our exports to Canada, could increase by a third in the long term.  The submission to the public consultation and the Commission’s impact assessment paid particular attention to some significant sensitive sectors in European agriculture in the context of these free trade agreements, and also what we do on our broad agenda: dairy, beef, sheep meat and sugar. The Commission made it absolutely clear to our partners in Australia and New Zealand that agricultural sensitivities must be taken into account in these negotiations. No full liberalisation can be imagined. The Commission has therefore proposed that the negotiating directives specifically include this aspect to ensure that the future agreement will not cause any disruption in the EU, including in our outermost regions.  On 13 September, as you recall, the Commission adopted recommendations for negotiating authorisations and directives for free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand. An important difference with our recent practice is that these recommendations do not cover investment protection. That does not mean that we will not negotiate investment protection agreements with Australia and New Zealand, but it does not have to be right now. We are reflecting, following the opinion of the Court of Justice on the Singapore Free Trade Agreement, and we are engaged in a discussion with Member States about the future architecture of the EU trade and investment agreement. We have also taken into account what some Member States said, namely that if investment protection is proposed additionally, then Parliament should of course be consulted on that aspect as well.  I just want to end with a few words on transparency. This is something that you, this Chamber, often – and very rightly so – demand of the Commission. As I strongly support transparency as well, we have made these recommendations public to the world. We invited Member States to engage early with their national parliaments so that there could be an early discussion on these two negotiations and of course also to facilitate your work on this and to give the general public an idea what trade negotiations are about and what is in this agreement. This is to strengthen, not to undermine, the important work that you do in this regard. These proposed directives are now under discussion in the Council. I hope that they will soon give us the authorisation to launch these negotiations without delay. In this context, we in the Commission very much welcome your contribution – the debate tonight and the votes you will have tomorrow on this – which contribute to giving us a clear steer of the priorities of Parliament in the upcoming negotiations. We will of course, as always, keep you closely informed about developments as we take these initiatives forward.  The free trade agreements will help EU companies to have better access to the markets in Australia and New Zealand. These trade agreements can create jobs, bring about benefits to consumers and also support workers’ rights and environmental and climate change objectives. This initiative is framed by our strategy to promote openness based on values and standards with like—minded partners committed to progressive rules for global trade. This is another part of our work to build bridges, not walls, with a circle of friends who share our values and this is also very much a political message, as well as an economic and trade policy question.  I very much look forward to the debate tonight.

name: Godelieve QUISTHOUDT-ROWOHL
text: on behalf of the rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I'm sorry I ran in here at the last moment. But we were having a discussion on this dossier in our group at the same time. I see that two representatives of the Agriculture Committee will speak here after me, and there was a heat between trade and agriculture. That's why I forgot the time a bit. On behalf of the rapporteur Daniel Caspary, I would like to ask for support for the recommendations to the Council on the mandate for the EU's trade negotiations with Australia and New Zealand. It is an old demand from the EPP Group, but also from Parliament, to start free trade negotiations with these states. We all know that now that the United States has withdrawn from TTIP, we have a very different geopolitical situation and it is the right moment for the EU to show that we are for free trade. But mind you - and I am also addressing my colleagues on the Agriculture Committee - for free trade also for the benefit of our agriculture. We have already started negotiations or concluded agreements with several countries in the Asia-Pacific region. So it is logical that we should do it with these two now. The rapporteur would like to highlight three points in particular. Firstly, on 13 September the Commission presented mandates that relate exclusively to trade and investment liberalization agreements. The mandates only include content that is within the competence of the European Union. That is the approach that the political group and also Parliament should support, as it ensures that European trade policy is able to act. With this in mind, the political groups have also agreed to exclude the subject of investment protection from the reports to let. However, should either the Council add the subject of investment protection to the mandate or the Commission submit a proposal for a second agreement, including investment protection, Parliament will then definitely take a position on this. I add here: must position. Agriculture is a sensitive issue in trade with Australia and New Zealand. The political groups have accordingly agreed on a compromise that takes this sensitive issue into account. Third: enforcement mechanism in the sustainability chapter. This is a contentious issue between the two big groups - all the other groups have different opinions on this. S&D calls for a sanctions-based mechanism, the EPP is critical of such an approach. As a compromise, we agreed on a formulation between the two large groups, as we have already adopted in other resolutions, for example in the resolution for the negotiations with Chile. I hope the other groups will follow us. Here, too, on behalf of the rapporteur, I would like to make it very clear to colleagues in the Committee on Agriculture, but also to all colleagues who fear that globalization and free trade could change our continent too much: we in the Committee on Trade will ensure that our standards are met social standards, environmental standards and consumer protection standards are guaranteed.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Malmström, New Zealand and Australia are our traditional partners and we have the potential to find common ground. However, full liberalization, implemented in the short term, would be detrimental, especially in the agricultural sector in Europe. I support the report on New Zealand, so that products such as sheepmeat, dairy products and, I would add, honey are considered sensitive and have a more specific approach to them, for example through quotas or transitional periods. High European animal welfare standards and European geographical indications must also find a worthy place in the negotiations. I call on European producers concerned about Brexit and its effects. Existing import quotas for products traditionally sold on the British market now need to be reviewed and reduced reasonably on the basis of market presence, for example by almost 40% for sheepmeat. Without change, there will be serious pressure on European producers, and we cannot allow them to fall victim to the British decision to leave the EU.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. –Mr President, it has been clear for some time that Europe has been keen to open trade talks with Australia and New Zealand. I am firmly of the belief that ambitious, balanced and comprehensive free trade arrangements with Australia and New Zealand can be of mutual benefit to both sides. However, any deal must respect the sensitivities of European agriculture, and I welcome the fact that the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development has the opportunity to come forward with this opinion. Producers across Europe are not anti-free trade. All they ask is a level playing field, treating as sensitive products that would be exposed by EU producers to excessive unsustainable pressure. For instance, by introducing transitional periods, appropriate quotas and factoring in respect for seasonal cycles, which we expect to see particularly for the lamb sector. Can I also say that agriculture cannot be made the bargaining chip of these negotiations. The Commission needs to keep the European agri-foods sector and MEPs informed of all aspects of negotiations, and I thank my shadow rapporteurs for Australia and New Zealand and Mr Andrieu for putting forward these opinions. May I say to Ms Quisthoudt-Rowohl – whom I have known for a long time in this chamber as she entered the same time as I did, that, although she’s not listening at the moment – that she doesn’t have to fear agriculture as much as she thinks.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: for the PPE Group. - Mr President! It should be a matter of course for the EU to sign free trade agreements with two like-minded countries such as Australia and New Zealand. After all, these are two of very few countries facing the EU's full tariff wall. These are two of very few countries with which we have no agreement. Other such countries are Russia, China, Taiwan and North Korea, and Australia and New Zealand do not deserve to be in that context. The big conflict issue we have is, of course, how to deal with sensitive sectors. This resolution calls for us to exclude sensitive sectors, but I think that would be completely wrong. I understand if you want to exclude sensitive products, but sectors? We know what we're talking about: the agricultural sector. I think we need to have better self-confidence when we talk about trade in agriculture in the European Parliament. We are the world's largest exporter of agricultural products. We have so far won on trade in agricultural products. I am convinced that we will continue to do so in the future, especially with Australia and New Zealand. That is why I suggest that we look at it positively, instead of worrying about trade with Australia and New Zealand.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, dear Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen! Australia and New Zealand are highly developed countries that share our values. That is why it must also be possible that we can conclude a fair, balanced agreement at a high level with high standards. The negotiations must be transparent because everyone, the European Parliament, national parliaments and the public, have a right to be fully informed. I am optimistic: as the Commissioner said, it was the first time that the draft mandates were published. I also appeal to the Council to comply with this and to publish the negotiating mandates once they have been adopted. In addition, the European Parliament must continue to be strengthened and involved in the negotiation process, from the adoption of the mandates to the conclusion of the negotiations. A fundamental pillar of trade policy is also a strong, enforceable sustainability chapter that serves to protect workers, consumers and the environment. In the event of violations or non-compliance with provisions, there should be a sanction mechanism as a last resort. Social, labor law and ecological standards must be more easily enforceable. Let us seize the opportunity for a model agreement with Australia and New Zealand from which all citizens benefit equally! These agreements could serve as a model for future agreements, if the negotiations are no longer conducted behind closed doors but are transparent, and the question of sustainability is given the same priority as the reduction of tariffs.

name: David CAMPBELL BANNERMAN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr. President, it seems odd that only the ECR Group seems to recognise that Australia and New Zealand are different countries with separate trade deals, and not one nation as this debate suggests. I would not advise calling an Australian a New Zealander, nor a New Zealander an Australian, especially not if they play rugby for the All Blacks, but I do welcome doing free trade agreements with both these great, independent and democratic trading nations. It is well overdue. Now existing bilateral arrangements and regulatory cooperation make the case for a deeper agreement to be negotiated relatively easily. I note that the New Zealand deal may be based on around 80% of the recent Canada or CETA trade deal, which is considered to be a gold standard. My group does take issue with two key points in the report though. Firstly, the inclusion of a sanctions-based mechanism on the trade and sustainable development – or TSD – chapter. This is an ineffective approach which discourages goodwill and damages engagement in negotiations. Secondly, the exclusion of the so-called ‘sensitive’ agricultural sectors from the report. Australia and New Zealand have the right to promote their agricultural exports, and it is a sorry state of affairs when the EU embraces protectionism.  Our partners have made it clear that they would enter negotiations with an open mind and it is a shame the European Commission is not doing the same.  (Applause)

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. - (FI) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Australia and New Zealand are two separate countries, as we all know, but an agreement is being reached with both. However, both countries share the same values ​​as the European Union. It can be said that when we share the same values, it is also natural to deepen trade relations with them even further. We also now have the Court's opinion on the limits within which we must move in trade agreements, so we can guarantee that the agreement will be ratified and applied quickly. I am mostly satisfied with this report, but I want to highlight two points where I believe we can still slightly sanded text to better and more balanced direction. I would like to delete the reference to removing sensitive agricultural sectors from the mandate. It is self-evident to me that the Commission can and will, if necessary, delimit the agricultural sectors during the negotiations, but the premise of excluding some of the sectors from the mandate is not a pragmatic approach, and I would therefore like to delete this entry. Furthermore, with regard to the possible sanctions in the sustainable development chapters, I personally would like the right pragmatic approach in this regard as well. First we need to find out how this is technically possible, and then only move on to this practice. However, these entries are already covered by dispute resolution. I therefore hope for a good and balanced agreement, and I trust the Commissioner and his troops that they will be able to do this in order to have a free trade agreement that benefits both parties. As I said, it is also very important to remember when it comes to trade agreements that it is basically about values ​​and value-based agreements, and when we work with New Zealand and Australia here, we share the same value base. It is good to proceed on this basis.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, the negotiations with Australia and New Zealand are not, as you say, a partnership. They constitute the free-trade headlong rush into the economic war of multinationals, without any consideration for small European agricultural producers. While we have not yet settled the disputes at the World Trade Organization on the distribution of agricultural import quotas that will result from Brexit, here we are negotiating with two agricultural giants among the most competitive in the world and, of moreover, in sectors which are already in crisis in the European Union, in particular the entire livestock and dairy sector. Pursuing these negotiations after CETA and following up on the Commission's desire to launch another treaty, with Mercosur, is sure to sign the death of peasant agriculture, which guarantees quality food and jobs. We defend cooperation with Australia and New Zealand, but we reject this deadly free trade. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: blue-card question. – I would just like to pose one question to the last speaker.  I wonder if you are aware of the fact that France, which you represent, is a net exporter of agricultural products, and yet you seem to want to roll back agricultural trade in general as you think it doesn’t benefit the farmers. But don’t you think the French farmers happen to be one of the biggest winners, due to the fact that you are one of the biggest exporters? Who do you really represent when coming with such claims?

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: answer "blue card".- In my country, more than a third of farmers earn less than 350 euros per month and there is a farmer suicide every two days.Therefore, in terms of benefits for French agriculture, we will come back.Second, because of imports from New Zealand, Australia, our sheep production is totally dismantled.The combination of the agreement with Mercosur, the import quotas that we have just accepted for Canada and that agreement will literally destroy our cattle breeding.We are exporters of agrifood products, but our French agriculture and particularly small and medium-sized farmers are dying, and I don't want this to continue.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Dear Mr President, dear Commissioner, dear colleagues! Should this apple come from New Zealand in the future? Then he has more air miles behind him than some ministers. The EU wants to sign new free trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand. Tomorrow we will discuss this in plenary and also vote. The question arises: Do we even need these agreements? Our industry certainly wants to export machines, cars, etc. For example, Australia wants to export sheep meat, coal, uranium and ores, New Zealand meat, dairy products and other agricultural products. Does it really make sense to e.g. B. To transport milk or agricultural products halfway around the world, when we ourselves have so much of it? We have a milk lake, we have enough sheep meat. We don't need these products. But in these countries production is cheaper than in ours because they have lower animal welfare standards. That means our agriculture will lose jobs. It is not true that we are creating new jobs through these agricultural products - at least at all levels. On the contrary. Let's see how things went with NAFTA, the agreement between the USA, Canada and Mexico. 800,000 jobs have been lost there - mainly in agriculture. Besides, these agreements are not just about trade; it could be regulated more easily if the tariffs were abolished and the same standards were created. We don't need these agreements for that. Modern free trade agreements contain very different things: They restrict - at least to some extent - our legislation. The wording in the CETA agreement still melts in my mouth. There it is explicitly stated that unnecessary barriers to trade and investment must be dismantled or that no new ones may appear. What is unnecessary We do not decide here in Parliament, but some industrialists decide.That means a very deep interference in our sovereignty, in our freedom.You can put it another way: You can say that these free trade agreements introduce the neoliberal economy into our country.

name: Nathan GILL
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, yes trade talks with Australia and New Zealand will be a litmus test for the EU and the UK to see how each fares after the so-called divorce.  It is no surprise that the EU has chosen these countries to kick off post-Brexit talks and wants to complete a trade deal as soon as possible. I suspect it may be a case of one-upmanship.  As it is said, if you cannot do trade with New Zealand, you cannot do it with anyone, as New Zealand is one of the most liberal trading nations in the world.  In fact, no other country has so many mutual regulatory agreements with the EU already in place than New Zealand, preparing the ground for a swift and a smooth FTA. No other country that is but the UK. Like our self-determining Commonwealth cousins we are also champions of free trade. Yet the UK starts from a position of even greater commonality with the EU, following decades of harmonised legislation. So do a good deal with New Zealand and Australia. Prove to the world that the EU is serious about free trade. But be warned, you must also do a good deal with Britain. The eyes of the world are watching, and if another nation sees petty, preferential or protectionist treatment to spite a Britain that simply wants to govern itself, as indeed they do in Wellington and Canberra, it will be Brussels that is judged, not Brexit.

name: France JAMET
text: on behalf of the ENF group. –Mr President, Madam Rapporteur, is it necessary today to remind this House, as some have done, that Australia is the world's third largest exporter of beef and the third largest exporter? of sugar, that it is in a dominant position in the milk and grain sector, and a global colossus in the export of agricultural products? As for New Zealand, it is one of the main exporting countries of sheepmeat. Cattle, sheep, cereals, sugar, these are all the sectors that will invariably and directly be affected in France and Europe, without mentioning the carbon footprint, since the steaks on our plates will have traveled 15,000 kilometers, so even that we have beautiful and healthy meats here at home, and that, alongside this absurdity, the European Union advocates respect for the environment at all times. But what worries us the most is the threat to the health of consumers since, I remind you, these two countries allow the cloning of animals for food. We no longer want these negotiations which, like those on TAFTA, are carried out by the Commission in the most total opacity, where neither national parliaments nor governments have been authorized to access documents. , while they were available to the big bosses of multinationals, for the good and simple reason, you will tell me, that they were part of the negotiations and the drafting. Today, can you simply or only guarantee that the national parliaments will be consulted, and when? Finally, this arbitration system directs us towards a system governed by the principles of Common Law, where the text will not be fixed, since it will have to evolve according to the decisions taken and the particular interests of multinationals, and that , we don't want it not.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - Mr President, I too want to congratulate Mr Caspary on his work on this matter and I am going to refer essentially to Australia. It is an important country in a region as economically dynamic as Asia and the Pacific. Australia has a highly developed and open economy, and the European Union is already the second largest exporter to Australia after China. A balanced and mutually beneficial free trade agreement will enhance our economic and trade relations with that country. With Australia, in addition, the European Union has just signed the so-called Framework Agreement, the Framework Agreement. With this Agreement and the future trade agreement, we would have a very solid platform to deepen our relationship with Australia, a distant but very close country from the point of view of history, principles and values. Australia is, in Asia Pacific, a natural ally, so to speak, of the European Union. Let's help strengthen this relationship. Furthermore, the future Europe of the 27 must also be very present in Australia. On the other hand, the European economy and European companies need foreign markets. That is why, Commissioner, I encourage you to continue your line of weaving this extensive network of trade agreements, and that the agreement with Australia is one of them.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, trade policy, while it cannot solve all the issues of our time on its own, is a powerful tool and we therefore appreciate President Juncker's momentum on trade during his State of the Union address. The European Union, in the vacuum left by the United States, must harness the momentum and establish itself as the leading global player in trade matters. We therefore welcome the request for the launch of negotiations with Australia and New Zealand because we believe in the possibility of establishing common, virtually global rules with them, which promote a model of sustainable development. However, we believe that certain considerations must always be taken into account and that we must insist: first of all, so that the renewed commitment of the Commission in the matter of transparency is followed by equal discipline on the part of the Council; second, so that the effects on our internal market of agreements are always considered, in order to intervene in the event of imbalances, especially in the transitional phase of adjustment; third, for the chapter on sustainable development to be an effective and binding intervention tool; fourth, so that during the whole phase of the negotiations the Parliament is immediately part of the process, is constantly kept informed and actively participates in order to make democratic participation more and more effective, in the full performance of its functions and to give the necessary reassurance citizens, but also to inform them about the potential opportunities that will open up; fifth, to ensure maximum reciprocity not only in terms of market access but also in terms of public procurement, product quality and safety in the treatment reserved to national authorities. Finally, we therefore hope that the negotiations and the agreement can be the framework for a dialogue that improves each other's potential e prevent distortions.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, Madam Commissioner, it has been a long time, but finally we’ve got there, and I have to say that I am very happy that we are about to start negotiations about free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand for at least three reasons. One is that what we have here are two like-minded partners, very stable countries and the fastest-growing developed economies. Free trade agreements with them will definitely help to deliver jobs, growth and investment and will benefit EU businesses and citizens alike. Secondly, I see a window of opportunity for the entire European Union to promote free trade worldwide, after the United States became a bit more hesitant in that direction, and I think that we should take advantage of that.  And thirdly, last but not least, as a rapporteur for the free trade agreement between the EU and Vietnam, I can only welcome the fact that we are opening up new opportunities in the Pacific region, and it can only be good news that we will cooperate more with the most dynamic economic region in the world.

name: Monika VANA
text: - Mister President! It cannot be that the essential democratic control function of the European Parliament and the national parliaments when drafting trade agreements is circumvented under the guise that the negotiating mandate only affects EU competences. The experience from TTIP, CETA and TiSA shows that when trade agreements are negotiated, little or no consideration is given to the interests of European citizens and we, as MEPs, are also excluded from the negotiations. We Greens are therefore calling for an inter-institutional agreement to ensure that the European Parliament will become a co-legislator in future free trade agreements and can actively represent the interests of the citizens. The national parliaments must also be able to comment on the negotiating mandate before the Council gives the mandate to the Commission.
