We Greens want a just and fair regulation for the world economy, which is not dictated by large corporations and profit maximization. We want public services to be excluded from the negotiating mandate, and we want to protect environmental, social and consumer standards, because they are not barriers to trade, they are important achievements for Europe's citizens.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, kind Commissioner, Australia and New Zealand are certainly distant countries but they are and can also be leading trading partners for Europe and Italy and above all, in some cases, they are partners advantageous. We Italians export to New Zealand twice as much as we import (400 million against 200) and to Australia even seven times more than what we import (3.5 billion against less than 500 million). Furthermore, undoubtedly, these countries play a bridging role for Europe to the Asian and Pacific region. If that is the case, a trade treaty can be an important option to support. However, we have set a mandatory condition, which we cannot compromise in any way: to protect agriculture, livestock and the dairy sector. These countries, in fact, are among the world's leading producers of milk and meat: New Zealand, for example, has an average of 419 head per herd, against 36 in Europe, and exports 88% of its production abroad. . Without safeguards in these sectors, therefore, there will be no agreement for us. But tomorrow we will not vote on a treaty with these countries, but only the directives to negotiate it effectively. In recent months here in the European Parliament we have negotiated hard, we fought firmly to ensure that the final treaty contains a protection of geographical indications, safeguard clauses, tariff quotas and special protection measures, as also requested by the trade associations . We wanted to set limits that protect the sensitive sectors of agriculture and milk, we asked for fairness, transparency and guarantees for the rights and interests of citizens. At this point all that remains is to hope that the Council does the right thing, that it listens to our words and that, when it releases the mandate to negotiate, it provides for a mixed competence of members and the European Union, without thereby circumventing national democratic processes.For us the rights of citizens and the rights of consumers are in no way negotiable.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: - Mister President! With Trump breaking off the trans-Pacific partnership negotiations in January of this year, there is of course a trade niche for the Union, and this should of course be used. With regard to the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership - China, Japan, India, etc. - there is a bridging function here, which could also be advantageous. However, I do notice a few formulations in this mandate that leave a lot of room for interpretation. For example, it is stated that enforceable commitments in the field of energy - but also state-owned companies - are important as such, and of course that leaves a lot open. Furthermore: A major concern is of course the flood of agricultural products that are produced in Australia and New Zealand and which are of course also to be imported, and finally the controversial arbitration agreements that are again included in this mandate, which is of course incomprehensible. So there remains a lot of hope, but also bitter taste and the vague hope that some critical points can still be negotiated here in transparent negotiations, and that would of course be very, very important for our citizens and for future negotiations.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr Chairman!The cooperation between the European Union and New Zealand and Australia is at a very good level.The exchange or turnover between the two sides amounts to a total of approx. 58 billion euros: 8 billion goes to New Zealand, 45 to Australia, but all this is not the limits of our parties.In this short speech, however, I would not like to devote any time to economic matters.In her speech, the Commissioner, I liked the statement that we want to build bridges, not walls, with this agreement and also with these agreements.I have heard many speeches here that are part of building walls, and not bridges that the European Union wants to build in the world in order to create a world based on mutual understanding, mutual cooperation and cooperation, a world based on peace and building prosperity.

name: David MARTIN
text: – Mr President, this for me is a bittersweet moment. I have argued in this Parliament for over 20 years for free trade agreements with Australia and with New Zealand, and they have finally arrived. Negotiations are about to begin, and by the time these negotiations are complete, I am afraid that my country will no longer be part of the European Union and thus unable to take advantage of the free trade agreement.  It is also a bittersweet moment though because the Committee on International Trade – of all committees – has, in my opinion, produced quite a protectionist resolution, and I hope we can amend some of that tomorrow. It is quite right, as colleagues have said, that we should want to defend certain sensitive products, make sure we have quotas on certain products, and make sure we negotiate safeguards for certain products, but to ask for a whole sector to be excluded from negotiations is a crazy way to begin negotiations, especially if that sector is the key sector for our negotiating partners. Why would the Australians or the New Zealanders make concessions to us on GIs, on non-agricultural market access or on sustainable development, which is so important to my group, if we are not even prepared to start talking about agriculture? It is a cloud—cuckooland position to have.  (Applause.)

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! As I speak in the debate on the mandate of the Commission for trade negotiations with Australia and New Zealand, I would like to emphasize strongly that European agriculture cannot be sacrificed at the altar of a trade agreement with these countries. Australia is a market of 23 million consumers, New Zealand is a market of 4.5 million consumers, while the European Union of 27 countries (excluding Great Britain) is a market of 440 million consumers, i.e. a market twenty times larger. And since both Australia and New Zealand are countries with large agricultural production, conducted in specific climatic conditions, with much lower production costs than in Europe, in over 70% of exports, the threat to European farmers is obvious in this situation. Therefore, in trade agreements with these countries, in addition to the restrictions already mentioned in this room, it is necessary to include safeguard clauses that will be automatically triggered if imports of agricultural products from Australia and New Zealand exceed established limits, which could cause serious imbalances in the country. the European market for agricultural products.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, coming from Ireland, which has very close links – both culturally and in other matters – with Australia and New Zealand, I can see the logic of doing a trade agreement with them. Indeed, right now our President, Mr Higgins, is in Australia, and he opened our first embassy in New Zealand today. One-in-six New Zealanders claim Irish ancestry, so it is logical that we should – and particularly at the time of Trump’s actions in the United States – try to expand free trade with places with will be beneficial to us and to them. Unfortunately, the timing here isn’t the best, with Mercosur and Brexit, the agricultural community is very concerned, and their concerns must certainly be taken on board and they must be brought on board if this agreement is to go ahead. You cannot force something through if one sector doesn’t see it doing them any advantage, or worse, doing them a disadvantage. So, I would think that it is right we should negotiate, but we have to do so and ensure that we get a very balanced, acceptable deal at the end of the day with our good friends from the southern hemisphere.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: - Mr President, I apologize in advance to my colleague David Martin, for whom I have a real affection, but I have a very different point of view compared to what has just been expressed, because I believe that beyond our debate on Australia and New Zealand, the question that arises is this unbridled activism of the Commission, for which negotiating agreements has become a sort of Pavlovian reflex . Moreover, Commissioner, one of your colleagues said that an agreement would have to be signed every six months if that was possible. The question is: why? I am not the only one asking this question. There are millions of Europeans who have concerns and who do not necessarily understand why. In this case, for Australia and New Zealand, it is argued that they are historic allies and that we need to be open. But it's a bit short, because the expected economic gains are minimal, if not zero. On the other hand, the risks are real - this has been said, but I repeat it - for the milk, livestock and sugar sectors, and it takes very little knowledge of the situation in certain countries, Mr Fjellner, to believe that there is not an agricultural model that is going to be threatened, because it is the case of small farms which are threatened by this type of agreement. So, frankly, when we talk about climate change, let’s not forget that it’s about stepping up trade with countries that are over 10,000 kilometers away; in terms of the carbon footprint, I don't think that's good. So take a break. Take a break and reassure our fellow citizens rather than worrying them.

name: Artis PABRIKS
text: – Mr President, on 21 September, the provisional agreement between Canada and the European Union came into force. We can already see how beneficial and right this agreement was. We can also see that many of those who opposed this agreement were actually basing their opposition on false facts or were simply not well enough informed. I am afraid – and I would also like to give a warning – that once we start to open these negotiations with such countries as New Zealand and Australia, we have to keep in mind that there are certain lessons we should learn from previous paths.  First of all, I would like to say that, as America is now hesitant about doing trade deals, we, the European Union, should go forward. Secondly, I would like to say that there is no place for the exclusion of a number of sectors, or certain sectors, from these trade deals. If those people who are trying so hard to stand by our farmers are so afraid of New Zealand, they should rather direct their energy to giving right and just subsidies to such countries as Latvia and Lithuania, because even inside the European Union we still have no justice in agriculture. We can make a nice and good deal where both sides can benefit.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: - Mr President, Australia and New Zealand are among the few countries in the world with which the Union does not have, or is not negotiating, a trade or investment agreement. We now finally have the opportunity to change this absurd situation with the launch of these negotiations, which is already late. Australia and New Zealand are relevant allies and partners of the Union, who share the same values ​​with us, including the ambition for a high level of social and environmental protection and a regulated global trading system. We therefore have all the conditions to conclude progressive, new generation agreements that promote sustainable development, and the European Parliament is responsible for ensuring transparency, but also for safeguarding European interests, including in sensitive areas that it is clear that we need to negotiate, like geographical indications, the meat, milk, cereals and sugar sectors. If we do so, if we make progressive and balanced agreements, then we will live up to the demands of European citizens.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: - Mr President, we know that in this negotiation - I am addressing this too to the Commissioner - agriculture is undoubtedly the most sensitive part of our project or of these draft agreements. New Zealand is the leading producer of sheepmeat and a major exporter of dairy products, with the lowest producer prices in the world. Australia is the world's third largest beef exporter and enjoys production costs 70% lower than the EU. The same goes for sugar, and especially special sugars, for our outermost regions. Meat, milk or sugar, these are particularly weakened and very sensitive sectors within the European Union. Moreover, agreement after agreement, the accumulation of the Union's concessions is becoming unsustainable for certain sectors, not to mention the repercussions of Brexit. These realities must not be forgotten by our work and must absolutely be taken into account by the Commission and the Council. In these agreements, agriculture must not be used as a bargaining chip. Also, I believe that it is imperative that these sensitive sectors - meat, milk or sugar - be excluded from the negotiations under way concerning Australia and New Zealand.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Mr President, Australia and New Zealand are among the fastest growing developing open and dynamic economies. Both countries have concluded numerous trade agreements with other partners. As the European Union does not have preferential bilateral trade arrangements with either of them, EU businesses have comparably less favourable conditions to access these markets. Our relationship with Australia and New Zealand has evolved over the past decades from a basic economic one into a strategic, political one that is based on common values, social and environmental standards, data protection, food safety requirements and so on. Certainly, there are sensitive sectors in the EU Member States’ economies, like the meat and dairy sectors, so their interests and concerns have to be reflected in the trade agreement, and we have the necessary instruments available to achieve that. It is also extremely important that negotiations are conducted in a transparent way and a strong sustainability chapter is a must.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I express concern, which is the same as millions of European citizens, regarding the potential risks of the new trade agreements with Australia and New Zealand, first of all because agriculture should not be used as a currency of exchange to gain greater market access for non-agricultural products and services. The precautionary principle, on which EU food safety regulation is based, and the "farm to table" approach, which sets more stringent EU standards, must be ensured within the framework of both the agreements. I draw attention to the sensitive nature of certain sectors of European agriculture, such as those of beef and sheep and goat meat, sugar, cereals and dairy products, many of which have recently gone through serious crises, needing urgent introduction of exceptional support schemes. The Union should refrain from making commitments of any kind in relation to these agricultural products, for which, in my view, it would still be necessary to include relevant and effective bilateral safeguard measures, transition periods and adequate quotas.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the European Union agreement with Australia and New Zealand could strengthen Greece's economic relations with New Zealand, and especially with Australia, where there is and is a dynamic and numerous Greek community. The agreement covers many sectors of the economy and of course covers agriculture, livestock, meat production, dairy products, sectors in which Australia and New Zealand are very strong. That is why there is a need to have measures to protect agriculture and livestock in Greece in other European Union countries, as well as to protect products of designation of origin, such as feta, Kalamon olives and yolk. And so that we do not have situations like we did with CETA, there must be transparency in the negotiation and it must be made clear that, as this is a mixed agreement, we must have the involvement and involvement of national parliaments and it must this agreement, to be ratified by the national parliaments, not to go through a process like we went to CETA with supposedly temporary implementation of the agreement without being ratified by the national parliaments. We make this clear from the beginning so that we can move forward smoothly during the negotiation.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Mr President, it is a shame that the huge European Union is afraid of the small New Zealand, lying 10 000 miles from Europe. It is a shame that the European Union, who takes care of the poor people, now takes interest in the producers – not of the poor people, who want to have cheap New Zealand butter. New Zealand’s butter is very good, and I want to eat cheap New Zealand butter.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, perhaps for the first time in my career here in the European Parliament, I will agree with Mr Korwin-Mikk.I consider New Zealand to be a country that is really very close to us, culturally and politically.I consider it almost impossible for the level of trade to reach only EUR 8 billion a year.I think we should put an end to protectionism.Certainly there should be insurance for trade, but it is not possible for trade to be tied to protectionism, that is certainly a thing of the past.I would like to remind you that it is precisely the era of President Trump that we should use to establish international relations, including free trade, with these countries, which have been in question for twenty years.I think it is time to negotiate a good fair agreement that includes certain safeguards, but it is not possible to completely exclude certain sectors from this free trade.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, as so many of you have said we are talking about two friends and allies – New Zealand and Australia – who share not only values, our commitment to rule of law, human rights and progressive trade, but also a strong commitment to upholding international organisations and global rules when it comes to trade. And in this world today that is not negligible: we need friends like that. Our current exports to these countries are more than our exports to Canada, and they can be much bigger. We have done very thorough preparatory work with both Australia and New Zealand: they are aware of the debate here in Europe; they are aware of our sensitivities; they are aware of the political discussions in some of the countries relating to trade. Of course we cannot exclude the whole agricultural sector – that makes absolutely no sense – but we are aware of the sensitive parts of this. But it needs to be put in perspective: it is worth noting that New Zealand and Australia already today benefit from preferential access to the EU for sensitive products because of WTO quotas. And while for beef the small country-specific quotas are almost entirely used, the use of quotas for sheep meat and dairy have declined the past years – and that means that Australia and New Zealand have found new, other, more attractive markets for their exports, and have diverted their exports increasingly to other countries in Asia, where they have trade agreements. In the case of New Zealand, about two—thirds of our imports are agricultural goods. Sheep meat makes one—third of EU agricultural imports from New Zealand, and it already today enters duty—free as a result of a historical and very large tariff—rate quota. In the case of Australia, agriculture is less than one—sixth of our total imports, and the biggest import is oilseed – canola – mostly used for biodiesel production in the EU. We actually have a growing surplus in agricultural trade, and especially in high-value added processed agricultural products. So we do have sensitive products – absolutely – and there are ways to deal with that, with tariff rate quotas, phasing—ins, etc. But we also have offensive interest, and not least if we can get New Zealand and Australia to accept the geographical indications which mean so much for our agricultural sector. On transparency: yes, you can rely on the Commission – we will do this in utmost transparency, continuing the tradition to publish documents and to liaise with you in different areas. We sent the draft mandates from the Commission directly to the national parliaments so that they can start yesterday looking into them, setting up the different committees or sectors, etc., to be able to follow closely these relations and these negotiations. Of course they should be involved. They don’t necessarily have to vote in the end, but they should be involved, much more than in the past – that is a national responsibility as well. And, as you know, we are setting up a permanent advisory group for all our trade agreements where businesses, trade unions, environmental organisations and consumer organisations will be involved, because we do want to listen to their advice, and that is part of the new, more inclusive trade policy. New Zealand and Australia are, of course, two different countries: different traditions, different politics. We started the process at the same time. We have finished the scoping. We finished the Commission’s work of proposing the mandate at the same time, and I guess – but I’m not sure – that the Council will allow us to start the negotiations at the same time, as you have chosen to deal with the report at the same time. But each country will have their own path of negotiation. If we are ready with one country then we will conclude with that country; it will not have to wait for the other one. And, as I said, in this process rest assured that the European Parliament will be fully aware. Thank you very much for this debate, and I hope that you vote wisely tomorrow morning.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, on behalf of the rapporteur, Daniel Caspary, I would like to thank Ms Malmström for her presentation. One thing that I am a little bit sad about – and which is sad about this debate – is the fact that it does not in any way reflect the trade that we have today with Australia or New Zealand. 99% of this debate – maybe a little more – was on agriculture, but if we take Australia – that everybody is concerned with – around ten percent of our trade with Australia is agriculture. And do you know what? In agricultural trade with Australia, we are winning. We import around EUR 1.9 billion worth of agricultural products from Australia, but we export EUR 3.1 billion worth of agriculture products.  So those of you who are set on voting tomorrow to exclude a sector – the agriculture sector – please think twice. Think of what we could be losing. We live in dramatic times. In the United States of America, Donald Trump has withdrawn from his commitment to do free trade in the region. In dramatic times, when the winds of change are blowing, some build walls and others build windmills. Let’s be optimistic, not protectionist, when we do this. If not, Europe will be losers and that is not at all what I want us to do in trade policy.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the question with request for an oral response (O-000075/2017) presented by Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar, Luis de Grandes Pascual, Wim van de Camp, Claudia Schmidt, Georges Bach, Elissavet Vozemberg-Vrionidi, István Ujhelyi, Maria Grapini, Rolandas Paksas, Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska, Rosa Estaràs Ferragut, Deirdre Clune, Kateřina Konečná, Andor Deli, Marek Plura, Gabriele Preuß, Olga Langitnalová-y, Paul Ritnalovlin, Matt Brentliny Nessa Childers, Seán Kelly, Tom Vandenkendelaere, Claudia Țapardel, Isabella De Monte, Izaskun Bilbao Barandica, Peter Kouroumbashev, Ivo Belet, Miltiadis Kyrkos, Ivica Tolić, Lucy Anderson, Fernando Ruas, Massimiliano Salini, Georgi Pirinski, Inés Ayala Sender, Antonio López -Istúriz White, Roberts Zīle, Salvatore Domenico Pogliese, Franck Proust, Renaud Muselier, Kostadinka Kuneva, Pavel Telička, Merja Kyllönen, Ivan Štefanec, Anneleen Van Bossuyt, Artis Pabriks, József Nagy, Ramon Tremosa i Balcells, Eduard Kukan and Daniel Dalton, to the Commission: Neutrality of reservation systems for air transport (GDS) and restrictions on access to flight information (O-000075/2017 - B8-0604 / 2017) (2017 / 2900 (RSP))

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: Author. - Mr President, I would firstly like to thank the colleagues who supported this proposal of mine and who have allowed us here today to discuss the neutrality of airline reservation systems and the restriction of access to flight information. Today, we are witnessing practices that violate the current legislation on the code of conduct for computerized reservation systems, a code that aims, as we know, to prevent abuses in competition matters and to guarantee the provision of neutral information to consumers. We also see practices that restrict access to flight information, search engines and online agencies. The possibility of comparing prices is limited. In the end, it is consumers who are penalized with fewer flight options and see increased ticket costs. The reference today is Lufthansa, which since 2015 has applied a fee of 16 euros to purchase tickets outside its own website. From November, British Airways and Iberia will apply an additional fee of EUR 9.50. Since July 2015, the Commission has been analyzing several complaints made by associations in the tourism and travel sector. Two years passed. Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, there has been no response or action. It is up to the Commission to guarantee the rights of European consumers and travelers and these practices obviously undermine the consumer's freedom of choice. We cannot accept a weight and two measures in a Europe at 28. Commissioner, we cannot wait another two years. Is Lufthansa or is it not violating Union law? When is the Commission going to end these illegal airline practices? And please give us the state of play regarding these complaints that came to the Commission in 2015.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the Honourable Members who put forward these questions. I am taking the floor on behalf of my colleague, Commissioner Bulc, who unfortunately has had to return to Brussels. There are three important questions being asked in relation to ticket distribution in the airline sector and the charges that can be incurred by the travelling public. These questions address concerns about the consumer’s access to unbiased travel information and the possibility to freely compare and use different distribution channels. The Commission is aware that the Lufthansa Group has added a so—called ‘distribution cost charge’ on tickets purchased through computerised reservation systems, while allowing travel agencies to book tickets for several cooperating airlines directly on the airline group’s own platform without any surcharge being added. We also know that other airlines have announced that they intend to do the same.  The Commission has received four complaints against the introduction of these distribution cost charges. The complainants consider the airline’s own platform to be a CRS (central reservation system) and claim that, as such, it should comply with Regulation No 80/2009. This is a complex case and the Commission investigations are still ongoing on the basis of the regulation.  In the Aviation Strategy adopted in December 2015 at the initiative of Commissioner Bulc, the Commission considered that the EU rules governing airline ticket distribution might no longer entirely reflect market reality and that several evolutions should be taken into account when considering whether the legislation remains appropriate: first, the engagement of airline ownership in the CRS; second, increased access to the internet; third, the development of alternative distribution channels; fourth, the regulation of CRS in other geographical markets. The Commission is carrying out a comprehensive evaluation of a regulation on common rules for the operation of air services in the EU. The regulation includes provisions on price transparency. We have also launched an evaluation of the regulation establishing a code of conduct for CRS systems. The results of those two evaluations are expected next year. They will not only assess the performance and effects of its provision, but also pay specific attention to the technological changes and challenges in the market. These evaluations will allow the Commission to determine whether EU action is needed to continue to guarantee that EU consumers have adequate access to travel services and unbiased travel information.  Thank you once again for your questions, and I look forward to your follow—up remarks.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Thank you very much, Mr Chairman. I would also like to thank the Commissioner for his first-term answer to my colleague Cláudia Monteiro's questions. Mr President, it is a well-known fact that the EPP Group is committed to European aviation. We have discussed the aviation strategy here under the leadership of colleague Pavel Telička and we are currently working on the bilateral aviation agreements, all to help the European aviation industry further. I think that there should be something in return. Especially when it comes to consumer protection. The Commissioner said it already: we have a regulation from 2009 and it has not been applied by a major player in this field for a few years now, and we think that is a shame. This is about transparency for the consumer. This concerns objective price information. But it is not only about the consumer, it is also about the travel agents and the travel agencies. The fact that the Commissioner is now announcing certain actions - yes, I almost have to say, it is the usual response from DG MOVE: “We are on it. It may take a while, but you will be informed in due course. ” What I do not understand is that in the meantime those airlines are not being reprimanded. I mean, we can talk here with DG MOVE and the Deputy Commissioner for Traffic and Transport, but we still want to see action. Is it not possible to speak to that large German airline in the short term? Thank you very much. Oh no, I have one more minute. I think this was it, thank you.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, consumer protection and healthy competition are fundamental principles and they must be respected, even when it comes to aviation and airline tickets. Distribution and marketing are increasingly digital and the amount of information available makes it difficult for the user to compare prices and offers. We know that some airlines charge 16 euros in price increases if the ticket is not purchased directly from their website or reservation center and this causes discrimination and indirect fare increases. The Commission is considering a revision of Regulation (EC) No. 80/2009, which protects users from abuses in the distribution of airline tickets. There is therefore a golden opportunity to strengthen existing rules to enable consumers to make informed choices based on reliable data. And, to conclude, the rules on transparency are of vital importance for the conscious choice of the consumer.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, well I’m sorry Commissioner that it is you and that you have to listen to my remarks, as I know it is not your portfolio, but I need to say that I’ve been living in an illusion. I thought that we have an internal market, that we want to foster the internal market, and that we want transparency and neutrality. However, at the same time we have one carrier that will introduce a EUR 16 surcharge, which in reality means EUR 32, and I wonder why? Extra costs since it goes via different web portal? What does it mean? I, as a consumer, will pay EUR 32 more. Is there any justification? Secondly, if I am a well-informed consumer of course I will not choose any other than the Lufthansa website. So this is a serious issue that we have known about for two years. For one year it has been under investigation by the Commission with zero results, and I need to say, Commissioner, that unfortunately your reply is completely dissatisfactory.  I really wonder whether there is a lack of cooperation among the stakeholders of the company which means that we don’t have a decision yet. If so, which are the ones that are not cooperating? Is it because you know there is no case at all? We should know; there should be a decision if there is no case at all after one year and if the rules are insufficient. What is it that doesn't really work? What are the rules?  Or is it maybe, without any disrespect, is it because it’s Lufthansa? We really need other carriers to do the same so that we can really investigate and pursue the issue of the case. We’ve been discussing in this plenary with a good understanding with the Commission; we want to proceed with integrated ticketing, which means dismantling barriers, but this is exactly the opposite. So I must say, Commissioner, please pass on the message to my good friend Commissioner Bulc that this is insufficient. I would be ready, with my staff, to investigate it within a few weeks because the case is crystal clear.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, The growing popularity of flying is largely due to the possibility of quick and simple booking of tickets. Existing open global distribution systems allow you to choose the best offers by comparing prices for a ticket on the same route with different carriers. This means huge benefits, including, above all, actual savings when planning a trip. From the consumer's point of view, the introduction of additional fees for the use of price comparison websites or the services of agents selling tickets from different lines means access to a smaller offer and higher ticket prices. Such a charge can be considered discriminatory and the announcements of its introduction by other airlines sound disturbing. The practices of third-country airlines in this area also bear the characteristics of unfair competition. I am glad that the Commission has finally noticed the problem, although there were complaints about this solution two years ago when Lufthansa introduced the fee. I hope the Commissioner will look at this and examine it carefully.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, I wonder: what else needs to be done for the Directorate-General for Competition to finally act? The extra charge that Lufthansa arbitrarily decided to impose in 2015 puts too much burden on passengers and at the same time blackmails them, because if passengers want to avoid the extra charge, they have to book through its own platform without being able to compare prices. If this is not the definition of monopoly and unfair competition, then what is? So why has the Commission turned a blind eye to this monopoly blackmail against consumers, travel agents, tourism and the transport industry as a whole for the past two years?

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! We are now discussing aviation and how consumers do not get the information they deserve. I also intended to highlight the climate aspect of this issue. Once again, customers are in a quandary due to greed from the airlines. Charging unreasonable fees because the consumer does not book the ticket on the airline's own website is not okay. This also focuses on the question of what information consumers are entitled to. For us greens, it is obvious that all consumers have the right to clear and complete information about what prices apply when booking their trip, and this information must be available from the first step, regardless of which platform you use to book the trip. The companies must also not be allowed to charge unreasonable fees for fictitious costs. The climate can also benefit from more information. What do I mean by that? Well, information about the effect of air travel on the climate is an important complement to economic instruments for the customer to be able to make wise decisions about their travel. Stopovers are an example of something that increases the climate effect, and the type of aircraft an airline uses also makes a difference. We think it is important that the regulations that this issue is about provide the consumer with clear information in order to be able to make their decisions. We Greens want to evaluate the regulations to provide protection for Europe's consumers and support for them to be able to make wise and climate-smart decisions.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: - Madam President! Technological progress, the development of internet services, as well as available mobile solutions allow consumers to buy online a convenient air ticket, and the key role during the booking process is reliable and credible information about the final price of the ticket, and its final purchase is always preceded - as practice shows , but also common sense - comparing ticket prices between different alternatives. Charging additional fees when purchasing with the use of global distribution systems, as well as the lack of reliable information, firstly constitutes unfair competition, and secondly, violates the rights of passengers and does not explain this type of practice applied by some airlines. Just as we called here in this Chamber three weeks ago to enforce the rights of Ryanair passengers whose flights have been canceled, so today we are calling, through Commissioner Stylianides, to Commissioner Bulc to make a decision, but not a decision that will take two years, or more years, only a quick decision that passengers and residents of the European Union are waiting for. We are asking for a thorough examination of the matter, for example in the context of the regulation on the code of conduct for computerized reservation systems.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, although we have been talking about this practice for two years, during which several complaints have been submitted to the Commission, including by me, we have zero concrete solutions and actions, and the number of companies restricting access to information. is growing. In a globalized and increasingly digital economy, restrictive practices such as introducing additional fees for booking tickets through agencies or online platforms are illogical and losing. In the 21st century, consumers have the right to be fully informed about the services they purchase and to be able to make a comparison between everything available on the market, and these changes must be reflected in the business model as well. of companies. As a member of the Committee on Transport and co-chair of the Intergroup on Tourism, I want European aviation to become a success story, especially in the context of fierce competition with other regions and third countries. But this success can only be achieved by maintaining high standards for consumers, standards that start with access to information and the possibility of choosing the best offer based on the price ratio, available budget, flight schedule and time saved.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Madam President, it is in matters like this, Commissioner, that the Commission and the European institutions risk our credibility. We are dealing with companies that join forces to prevent the normal functioning of 2020 businesses, such as global ticket distributors or price comparators. Both are based on creating value by analyzing public data that are on the internet, such as airline prices and routes, and creating a new useful and very cheap service for the user. Faced with this type of digital economy initiative, several airlines partner with the sole purpose of building a dominant position and abusing it, without also offering any new service, benefit or discount to their own customers. This kind of tariff is, in my modest opinion, an attack on consumer rights, but it is also incompatible with free competition and lethal for entrepreneurs who, based on knowledge, innovation and imagination, create value where there wasn't. That is why, in order to guarantee the health of the internal market, and especially to protect our main source of wealth and employment, I advocate exemplary measures to prevent such practices. But immediately, Commissioner. Today we have not had the response we expected.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: - The pricing maneuvers of airline tickets and the peculiarities of purchasing them through different reservation systems often come as a surprise to consumers.Therefore, the introduction of new surcharges will certainly not facilitate the travel planning and ticketing processes.If more and more airlines start introducing charges for the distribution of tickets through other systems that they do not control, passengers will not only face rising ticket prices, but will in principle lose the right to freely compare and use different distribution channels.It is also worrying that third-country air carriers are increasingly choosing to provide incomplete information on their flights on price comparison sites, forcing passengers to opt for more expensive and not always more convenient connecting flights.The European Commission must take steps to protect consumers from such dubious initiatives by the air carrier and to ensure the transparency of ticketing channels.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Madam President, I say to the Commissioner: transparency in whatever market ultimately benefits consumers and increases market efficiency. It is very important – and has been a long-established goal of this Parliament – to enhance knowledge of consumer rights, to strengthen the enforcement of those rights and to integrate consumers’ interests into key sectoral policies. We need to empower consumers through access to choice, information and awareness of their own rights. And the fair and open competition in the EU’s aviation sector has always been to the ultimate benefit of the consumer. Parliament here has been one of the strong and key components of Europe’s open and connected aviation market. Regulation 80/2009 and the code of conduct for computerised reservation systems oblige all systems to be neutral and the owners not to discriminate. These rules have all helped to facilitate the transition from an aviation market that had minimum competition and high prices to a market today where many consumers can afford to fly thanks to more choice and to more transparency. And large airlines have a strong market position. They then have the power to charge higher prices, which is only compounded by a lack of transparency. And for the same reasons there is also a vested interest for these large airlines to limit price market transparency. So we need answers, I, like others, am frustrated at the time it is taking to come to a conclusion on this matter. But we need to know – yes or no – whether it is in contravention: whether or not it is giving consumers the entitlements to which they are obliged.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: - Madam President, measures that make it difficult for websites to compare ticket prices have recently been introduced not only by carriers from the European Union but also from third countries. Additional charges for the sale of tickets through other distribution systems severely limit passengers, who are therefore unable to properly compare flight prices on all airlines. All passengers must be able to choose freely and transparently the most advantageous offer, as provided for in the regulation on a code of conduct for computer reservation systems. There is a need to protect the interests of consumers and to ensure that reservation systems offer information impartially. The Commission should therefore regularly monitor for discriminatory practices through CRSs and, if it finds a breach of the rules, take clear and swift action against those practices of airlines. But such an investigation cannot last indefinitely.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, tourism is precisely one of the sectors that has changed very rapidly thanks to the Internet, and an increasing proportion of air tickets, among others, are now being booked directly via the Internet. For consumers, it has meant a significant improvement over the past. It is these many new services that can be used to compare air fares that have benefited both consumers and, of course, airlines, as consumers have been able to compare prices, speeds and different route options, among other things, and airlines have been able to fill their seats more efficiently and find customers. who would not otherwise have chosen that company. It is quite clear that such digital services cannot run unless all parties in the chain receive their own credit fairly from that chain. It is therefore important that the European Parliament and the European Union ensure that we have a fair competitive environment and sufficient transparency and openness, and that dominant positions are not used, for example, by imposing unfair contract terms. In this new situation, it is really important that the Commission now carefully reviews the practices that have emerged. We know that, on the other hand, the distribution of airline tickets has been dominated by a few large GDS distribution companies, and now airlines have also developed their own systems and open standards that allow other airlines and distribution channels to participate more effectively. As a result of digitalisation, the whole sector is now undergoing major change and it is important that we ensure a fair competitive environment.

name: Peter KOUROUMBASHEV
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I would first like to point out that it is a remarkable practice for the Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid to be responsible for transport matters, and it may be worthwhile for the European Commission as a whole to reconsider this practice. It is also noteworthy that after 2 years, the European Commission was able to note the fact that the practice introduced by Lufthansa must be investigated. Did you know that other airlines that are not in the European Union are ready to prepare such a practice, as some hotel chains already do? Do you think that there is neutrality of the information and the reservation system? I tell you no. Does the performance of this airline improve the competition? I tell you it doesn't improve. Is this action beneficial for small and medium-sized enterprises, small travel agencies? I'm telling you it's not. Is it good for consumers? I tell you it is not. Is it in favor of the digital single European market? I tell you again that it is not. And I ask for your clear answer, as well as for a clear statement by Mrs Bulz.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: – Madam President, I agree with Mr Telička that it is really high time that we discuss this issue in the plenary session, and I thank all colleagues and all Members who brought up this question. It is extremely important for consumers and for a well—functioning digital single market to have neutral, independent access to the search systems of air transport services. The consumers cannot be discriminated against online, and their choice of best offers cannot be restricted by business models. Transparency and neutrality in the search for flights increased competition and made travel within the EU affordable for many Europeans. We should therefore protect and promote this, and I appeal to the European Commission to undertake all possible efforts to protect the transparency and neutrality of searches and of free competition in the aviation market.  We will continue a discussion on this subject in our working group on the digital single market, which I chair, and precisely during our next meeting on 22 November, and you are all invited to join us. But let us not forget that this is not the only problem that consumers encounter when booking flights. They are often geo-blocked and have to pay a higher price because of their place of residence, or – to put it more precisely – because of the temporary location based on their IP address. This must not take place in our single market. We are now working on the geo-blocking regulation, and this regulation will enable us to get rid of this kind of discrimination – at least on independent distribution channels, I am sure. I really do hope that we will be able to reach an agreement on this with the Estonian Presidency very soon.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, I would like to say that, of course, I have great respect for air carriers, but what is the subject of the current debate is a matter of great concern to me. If we accept this principle that the neutrality of information will be violated, with impunity, without fundamental supervision by the relevant DG MOVE, then I think it is really scandalous. We should insist on following the rules, and if consumers are pushed to behave in a certain way, then, in my opinion, it is unfair competition. This is an infringement of competition rules. The consumer has the right to complete information and not to follow it only in a certain chosen form and way. I think that has been said quite a bit. I think that the most important thing is that in the European Union, the principle of fall to whom applies. If this principle is violated, it really raises fundamental questions as to whether equality of rights applies in the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, during the previous session here we discussed Ryanair. The situation he had created was unacceptable. So now we are talking about Lufthansa, which imposes a special fee of 16 euros, if the ticket is not purchased from its own website. It is obvious that we have a violation of consumer law. It is obvious that this is unfair competition, but above all, Mr Stylianidis, I consider it an exploitation of Lufthansa's dominant position in the aviation market. Because this is a huge, very large company. Therefore, you need to initiate antitrust proceedings, because only then will he understand. In addition, I want you to investigate the following: Lufthansa is also a shareholder in Fraport. Fraport is a huge company that manages Frankfurt Airport and has seized all 14 regional airports in Greece, while it has other airports in total. Thus, Fraport becomes a partner with Lufthansa and thus strengthens its dominant position in the aviation market. Take action on this matter, please.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank our colleagues for their contribution to this very interesting debate just now. Colleagues, I understand your concerns and I can promise you that I will make sure to relay all these concerns to my colleague, Commissioner Bulc. As I said on behalf of my colleague in my opening remarks, the Commission is currently investigating the four complaints received, so I would not like to say anything which might prejudice the outcome. I note your concerns and your criticism, which will be very constructive as we continue to evaluate the regulation, in particular as we evaluate the provision on price transparency. Our debate here this evening has been useful and informative as we try to find a way forward in order to ensure that consumers are treated fairly and continue to benefit from safe and convenient transport. In conclusion, let me assure you that the interests of the travelling public are what is driving the Commission’s work in this area.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - The fact that some airlines charge a surcharge of EUR 18 if passengers do not buy a ticket through an airline-controlled reservation system has a negative impact not only on passengers but also on European aviation in the long term. After all, this move threatens free competition and the achievements of the single market, and restricting flight information significantly violates passengers' right to free choice. The problem is not new, with a fare of € 18 per trip introduced by one of the largest airline groups two years ago. Although the Commission has begun an investigation, it has not progressed in two years. I believe that stronger action is needed against such market-restrictive phenomena. Every day we can see the damage caused by national protectionist measures in the field of road transport. It is therefore necessary to react in time to avoid undermining the single European market in aviation.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the debate on Council and Commission statements on forest fire response mechanisms in northern Spain and Portugal (2017/2899 (RSP)).

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, this year a number of countries in southern Europe have experienced particularly severe and devastating forest fires. Many people have lost their lives. Portugal and Spain have been among the most affected countries. On behalf of the Council, I would like to express my deepest condolences and sympathy to the relatives of the victims, to thank the countries which have provided assistance and also to thank the Commission for its coordination efforts. Last but not least, let me warmly thank all the firefighters for their huge commitment and effort. As honourable Members are aware, the Union Civil Protection Mechanism, which we jointly adopted in 2013, provides for a number of measures to prevent, prepare for and respond to disasters. This includes the European Emergency Response Capacity, which is a voluntary pool of Member States’ assets pre—committed for immediate deployment inside or outside the EU. Several Member States have registered their forest fire fighting capacities in this pool. These resources have been deployed a number of times to provide assistance in combating forest fires across southern Europe. However, despite significant efforts at national and EU level to prevent forest fires, we have to stay prepared and ready to respond in a more efficient manner to these catastrophes. At the same time, a swift and efficient response is dependent on costly, and therefore limited, resources. EU solidarity might prove its limits when similar disasters occur simultaneously in a number of countries. Of course, when the Commission proposes the mobilisation of the EU Solidarity Fund, the Council will examine such a proposal as a matter of utmost urgency.  Finally, the Council has attentively examined the Commission’s recent interim evaluation report on the Union Civil Protection Mechanism. It includes a number of recommendations for further application of the mechanism. Some of them are particularly relevant for the prevention of, and response to, forest fires. This evaluation has marked the starting point of reflections on the future framework of the Union Civil Protection Mechanism which the Council will continue in the coming months. In this context, the Presidency has taken note with interest of the recent announcement, reiterated yesterday by President Juncker, of an upcoming Commission proposal to revise the Union Civil Protection Mechanism. We look forward to bringing debates on this matter forward.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me also start by expressing once again my condolences to the families and the loved ones of all those who perished in the terrible fires of last week. Also, to those who have lost their homes in Portugal and Spain. It is unfortunately not the first time this year that this region has been affected by deadly forest fires. I also wish to pay tribute to the heroic firefighters – brave men and women – and ordinary citizens that stepped in to help. In 2017, the forest fire season has been one of the worst in the last decade; southern Europe has been very exposed. Helping Member States affected to fight forest fires has been a priority for the European Union. The truth is that national capacities alone are not enough. Climate change makes weather conditions more extreme in natural disasters more often. This is the harsh reality.  The European Union civil protection mechanism was activated 16 times because of forest fires in Europe since mid-June. We have never seen so many activations in so little time. Capacities such as firefighting aircraft, firefighters and vehicles were deployed on nine occasions. As Commissioner for crisis management, I warmly thank all the EU Member States that offered assistance through the mechanism. This is a true example of European solidarity.  We did our best to provide support with the means at our disposal, but let me be clear: the mechanism has specific legal and practical limitations. Our role, our mandate, is to coordinate – as my dear colleagues already said – and help with the transport costs only. We don’t have our own means, therefore we have to admit that sometimes our contribution is not sufficient. I would like to be very sincere: sometimes it was too little and too late. This is why we have already been exploring in the previous months ways to strengthen the mechanism. It was one of my top priorities.  President Juncker mandated me – and I want to thank him for this – to come forward with concrete proposals next month on how, together with our Member States, we can do more to better respond, prevent disasters and be better prepared for them.  This is not only – I would like to clarify this – about forest fires: just days ago, we had hurricanes hit Ireland and the UK. Floods have struck eastern and northern European Member States in the recent past, and earthquakes have consistently shaken Italy and Greece and other countries. So we owe this initiative to our citizens, to the European citizens.  It is now a priority of the Commission work programme, which we adopted yesterday. The proposals will be on the table before the end of November. There are three areas that I want to explore. First, through additional financial support we must increase capacities to act rapidly and effectively. Second, prevention and preparedness need to be at the core of the initiative: enhanced prevention and preparedness should be a precondition for additional support. Finally, we must improve the efficiency of the mechanism to enable a faster deployment of assistance during emergencies. In order to do this, I will need your support. Time is of the essence. The beginning of the next flood season has already started. The forest fire season has been dramatically extended this year, and the next one is in a few months from now. It is therefore crucial that we act fast, in a spirit of solidarity and efficiency. I know I can count on the European Parliament to be a strong ally to support our proposals, because we must rapidly offer solutions to our citizens. They expect more from us as European institutions.  In addition to the EU actions in the field of civil protection, let me also mention another important tool: the European solidarity fund. As you know, the European solidarity fund can provide valuable financial assistance to help cover a part of the cost created by disasters. Support is subject to fulfilling two conditions. First, total direct damage should exist as a threshold which is specific for each Member State or region; second, national authorities have to submit an application within 12 weeks of the start of the disaster.  Portugal has already submitted an application covering the forest fires that occurred between June and August. The Commission will soon finalise its assessment; we are working on the basis of significant support from the solidarity fund. In parallel, we are currently discussing with Portugal the possibility to extend their application to also include the most recent fires of October. For the recent fires in Spain, notably in Galicia, the damage has not been fully assessed yet. The Commission stands ready to provide guidance and support to the Spanish authorities, should they intend submitting an application. In terms of operational programmes, the Commission also rapidly adopted the proposal from Portugal to modify the original 2014-2020 central operational programme through internal relocation of the European regional development fund, ERDF.  We added two new actions. First, the replacement of the productive capacity of the SMEs that were lost during the fires, with a total ERDF budget of EUR 25 million. Second, the replacement of public municipal infrastructure equipment with a maximum budget of EUR 20 million. In addition, in Portugal, the operational programme for sustainability and resource efficiency provides the possibility to finance a range of investments to strengthen disaster resilience, prevention and preparedness. In Spain, the operational programme Galicia provides the possibility to finance investments in early detections, prevention and civil protection.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Mr President of the Council, Commissioner, first of all, I would naturally like to express my deep dismay at the fatalities of both the June fires and, in particular, the fires of the weekend of 15 October in Portugal and Spain, as well as all the material damage that obviously damages the lives of hundreds, if not thousands, of families. Secondly, I would like to thank the European solidarity that is being demonstrated in this quick and efficient way that the Commissioner made clear here, which is also being demonstrated by the desire to reform the civil protection mechanism and which is also being demonstrated for the will that, eventually, all the measures that we will take to reorder the forest - because there is, here, a structural problem - may have an accounting in terms of deficit that could favor the Portuguese situation in European terms. However, I would like to draw your attention to the fact that here, in this same House, in the State of the Union speech, I was the only person who asked for the creation of a European Civil Protection Force, following the 2006 Barnier report, and that, in Portugal, during these months, I drew attention to the fact that the Portuguese State and the Portuguese Government have divested in civil protection and are neglecting the situation and, naturally, as shown in the technical reports presented in the meantime, there were failures also serious from the Portuguese Government, which are to be regretted and which could have avoided some of the most harmful effects of this situation - and this cannot be left out. Here, however, I wanted to leave a challenge, and a challenge, say, of greater scope: it is that, in addition to emergency measures, even at the level of the support mechanism in civil protection and in fighting fires, earthquakes, nuclear accidents , industrial accidents and floods, we are able to create a genuine European protection force civil society, of rapid action throughout the European space, and that can even serve as aid to developing countries, which suffer many disasters and who have no means at all.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, more than a hundred dead, many hundreds injured, the destruction of natural and built heritage of immeasurable value, images of pain, suffering, bravery, firefighters who were heroes - all of this is memory, it is feeling strong and needs a response to match. European institutions have been aware of the seriousness of what happened in Portugal and Spain. I would like to thank, on behalf of Portugal and the Portuguese, for the profoundly symbolic gesture of donating to victims of the Princess of Asturias da Concórdia prize, attributed to the European Union. We are facing a systemic challenge. We need to respond to forest management, combating desertification of territories, strengthening prevention and updating prevention and relief mechanisms. Each country has to do what it has to do and Europe can help and can complement - and it has done. I underline the readiness of the institutions to activate the support mechanisms more quickly. Eventually, Commissioner, the joint application of Portugal and Spain may help to speed up the response of the solidarity fund. It is obvious that the failure to account for recovery and prevention investment for the purposes of structural deficit is an appropriate, intelligent and must be applied measure. In July we discussed another cycle of catastrophes. At that time, I defended the need to create a European permanent civil protection mechanism. What has now occurred shows that it is absolutely essential to do so. The President of the European Commission acknowledged yesterday, in this same Chamber: if we have a defense union, Commissioner, if we have a security union, we must also have a Civil Protection union. This is how Europe is done: it is responding to people's needs when they need help, in solidarity. We need to start acting now. This is the second debate in four months.We do not have to ask a third party to discuss what we are going to do.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, the tragedy of forest fires in Portugal is due to the convergence of several factors, among which are the massive predominance of eucalyptus, the ineffectiveness of fire-fighting organisms, climate change and the policies of successive governments, which have encouraged depopulation and abandonment in the interior of the country. The Portuguese State has largely failed to combat forest fires, because it has itself been captured by powerful webs of private interests that dominate the parties of the so-called “arc of governance”. Never have the Portuguese paid so many taxes as today, but never has the State been so ineffective in providing public services that it can legitimately be demanded of it. The tragedy of forest fires is thus also one of the most evident consequences of the fact that the bodies responsible for preventing and combating these fires have been occupied and managed by people without the necessary qualifications for these functions - and that is because of friendliness and patronage have become the official philosophy of my country's governance.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, this dramatic scenario, as said here, results in part from specific climatic circumstances, but the abandonment policies of the rural world and the total absence of adequate strategies for our forest cannot be overlooked. It is important, at this moment, to mobilize all possible support to repair the immense losses, the balance of which remains to be done, and, for that, we need to streamline and adapt the funds and that they arrive on the ground in the coming weeks. It is also important to free Portugal from the bonds of the euro, which have limited Portugal in its ability to invest and carry out structural prevention actions in the forest that have been long sought, either by experts or by my party. In short, what we emphasize here is no more than what has already been granted to other countries, that is, that the expenditure necessary for the reconstruction of the regions affected by this scourge is not accounted for in the deficit of public accounts in the framework of economic governance.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, first of all I want to show my solidarity to the families of the dead people and to the hundreds of injured in Galicia and Portugal. The cocktail of superfires — a true social and environmental drama — is well known — deliberate fire, rural neglect, cuts in fire prevention and suppression, and climate change. Let's be clear: Spain and Portugal do not burn spontaneously, in the Spanish northwest, for criminal or cultural reasons, up to 70% of the fires are intentional. Furthermore, we have abandoned Mt. Today development rhymes with depopulation, lack of preventive management and spatial planning, and the Iberian Peninsula is currently suffering the worst drought in the last twenty years (extremely high temperatures and the first hurricane ever recorded so far east in the Atlantic). What can we do? The drama of hyperfires can only be ended with the persecution of those responsible, prevention policies, public awareness and long-term territorial planning. Let us dedicate more resources to environmental prosecutors so that those who set fire to the forest can be identified and sentenced. Let us prioritize investments in high fire risk areas and greater prevention through the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development. Let's recover the pre-crisis budgets, because, like it or not, we will have to extend the high-risk campaign and the fire operation to the entire year. Let us ban eucalyptus and other flammable species in the surroundings of nuclei and cities to reduce the risk for local populations. Let us implement a landscape management policy through prescribed burning, sustainable forestry or extensive ranching. Let us finally approve a climate change law in Spain, at the height of the challenge of climate change. Let us have more ambition in the European Union and establish a policy of forest fire prevention that prepares forests in the context of climate change.In fact, let's bet on a rural world and diverse and ecological mountains with jobs, wealth and life.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, thank you also for your condolences and your explanations on the steps that the European Commission is going to take with regard to the civil protection mechanism and the Solidarity Fund. I want to start by expressing my feeling of regret to our Portuguese neighbors for the high number of fatalities suffered. Also in Galicia, my land, we have had to mourn four deaths: my deepest condolences to their families. And I want to add some information about Galicia. The fires were the result of intentional arson activity, not the result of chance. The security forces and the justice system are now investigating the responsibility of these fires. Some criminal hands took advantage of the extreme weather conditions on Sunday the 15th: extremely high temperatures for October preceded by a prolonged drought and very strong winds due to the effect of Hurricane Ofelia. That day there were many fires —125—, tripling the number of those that appear the most risky days of the worst months of August. In addition, most ignited in the afternoon and at night, so that the aerial means of extinction could not be used. Even so, many fires were put out, but some difficult circumstances, especially the wind, made it impossible to put them all out. Commissioner, Galician forests do not burn by chance, they are burned by criminal hands. It was not a problem of lack of resources, there were never as many operational resources as this month of October: 5,600 people, 350 brigades, 220 motor-pump trucks and 40 large shovels or bulldozers, in addition to a score of aerial resources. To this must be added the important troops of the Military Emergency Unit. Nor is it a problem arising from the type of tree species. For example, Orense, the province of Galicia most affected these days, has practically no eucalyptus trees. We are essentially facing a problem of criminal delinquency, which took advantage of extreme weather circumstances.I end by expressing my gratitude to President Juncker for his commitment expressed yesterday in this chamber to study as soon as possible the application of the Solidarity Fund to these serious fires.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: - Madam President, just ten days ago Galicia was burned again. Thousands of hectares of high ecological value burned. Towns and cities were surrounded by fire. Homes and businesses were lost. And, most tragic, human lives were lost. My condolences. And if we know anywhere about the consequences of fire, it is in Galicia. The easy thing now is to talk about plots that burn the forest, of arsonists that must be punished, but that is not the underlying problem. Galicia has serious problems that its Government does not face: depopulation and abandonment of rural areas, lack of territorial planning, erroneous forestry policy, lack of prevention. What happened in the terrible wave of fires of 2006 is that we came from several years of government that looked the other way in terms of spatial planning and forest policy. And now the same thing happened. It is therefore urgent that governments take comprehensive measures to combat and prevent fires seriously and it is urgent that measures be taken and that inaction be abandoned in the face of climate change. The European Union must also be more belligerent to face the challenge of climate change, to reorient its policies. The Solidarity Fund must be reoriented so that it is effective in alleviating the consequences of the disaster caused by climate change. Funding for the Natura 2000 Network for conservation should be improved and the European Civil Protection Mechanism should be strengthened to improve the capacity and speed of response. Climate change does not admit of excuses. It requires commitment.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: - Madam President, last June we discussed the fires that ravaged Portugal and that claimed the lives of sixty-four people. Most of the deputies agreed to demand a forestry policy focused on prevention. Four months later, we find ourselves lamenting a new tragedy: Galicia, Asturias and Portugal have burned again and their hell has left a line of desolation and death. Spain is not Portugal, and the extinguishing devices are not comparable, but the decades-long forest policy based on pine and eucalyptus is an added risk to the weather. We cannot stop chasing illegal plantations, many forests have not been cleared and there is a lot of neglect. We also need information systems that rely on new technologies but, at least in Spain, surely the big problem is crime, surely the business of burnt wood, where until now there has been ignorance or lazy tolerance. And now I'm going to do our thing. Mr Juncker intoned the mea culpa this week about the European Union Civil Protection Mechanism. He said it cannot be that a fire starts on a Sunday and the first plane from the European Union arrives on Wednesday. Has coordination failed? Shall we go from words to deeds, Commissioner?

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: - Madam President, first of all, I would like to express our solidarity with the victims of forest fires. Second, in Galicia, we note the abandonment of rural areas that provoke agrarian policies as one of the main causes of the spread of fires, which is aggravated by climate change. Commissioner, we think that Europe needs to do much more. Here are some ideas for another policy to combat forest fires. Firstly, decided support for current farms and the installation of agricultural people across the territory. Second, to restore forested agricultural land, eliminating eucalyptus and pine trees in the vicinity of houses and villages and putting an end to the monoculture of these species. People's lives have to be the priority. Thirdly, we want economic support to restore native forests and to introduce sheep, goats or cows into the hills. The fire extinguishing service must be completely public and the profession of firefighters must be dignified.

name: Nuno MELO
text: - Madam President, at the moment, which is in pain, I offer my condolences and thank you for the condolences you have left. More than causes: these are for internal debate. I ask you to understand the consequences. To speak of these fires in Portugal, as in Spain, but in Portugal, is to speak of lost lives, many. More than 100, when one life would be too much. It is talking about destroyed companies. It is talking about extinct jobs. It is talking about secular villages in ashes, pieces of our history. It is talking about half of the forest burnt this year in the European Union. It is talking about people who lost everything, poor people, old people without the strength to redo what they only existed before, old and poor people who often fought the fire alone. It is talking about helping those who really suffer. It is this aid that makes sense to the European Union and, at a time when my country suffers and justifies support, I ask here also the European Union that, if it says it is flexible and willing to clever interpretations about deficit rules, it does not it can give less when it comes to interpreting solidarity mechanisms, under penalty of denying its very essence. Theorized about a European civil protection force - no gunpowder is invented, it has been drawn up since 2006 in a report by Michel Barnier. Run. I also repeat here what, by letter, I have already appealed to the President of the European Parliament: make a commitment, using your money for what matters most. Help to rebuild lives and, if existing measures are considered insufficient, mobilize themselves to be endowed or to create new measures. I finish by saying that it is in moments of tragedy that great leaders are forged. Let us all know how to live up to these difficult times.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: - Madam President, the truth is that the climatic conditions that we face in the worst days of the fire are not common conditions at this time, but it is true that, behind all the fires that devastated Asturias, they are incendiary, there are criminal behaviors that we must Chase. But, regardless of persecuting all the people who are committing criminal acts by lighting the mountain, lighting the forest in Asturias, we need to improve prevention conditions, because climate change is a challenge to which we have to respond globally, as has said the commissioner. Because it's not just the fire, it's the floods. We need those preventive measures. We appreciate and hope for this improvement in the European civil protection system, but we clearly need to improve prevention systems and there we need more support from Europe. And right now we need support from Europe to make the use of the Solidarity Fund more flexible, which we have to put into operation now. And I end by thanking the Union for donating the amount of the Princess of Asturias Award to the people who have suffered this serious crisis, these serious fires in Asturias.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Madam President, I want to begin by expressing my solidarity with the victims and families of this wave of fires and my deep regret for the emotional, environmental, economic and social damage that this tragedy is causing. But next I ask you to urgently implement the European solidarity mechanism in the event of natural tragedies and to accelerate all the initiatives underway to improve cross-border coordination and prevention. In the Galician case, for example, a surveillance plan with drones co-financed by the Commission does not appear to be operational.
