There are complaints about the abuse in the cultivation of highly combustible fast-growing species and also for poor coordination and little foresight after knowing five days before that the heat and wind could increase the risk and harmfulness of fires. Therefore, Commissioner, we must activate the aid, better control the programs that are co-financed, promote cross-border cooperation in the field of civil protection and extreme vigilance to make it difficult for arsonists and so that no one can do business, or put out fires nor with burned wood. These are the concerns of our friends from Compromiso por Galicia.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: - Madam President, Asturias burned again. And it is not the first time that the devastating fire has left the people of my land ruined. For that reason, and like the mountains, we too burned, but with rage, because it gets tired of always throwing balls out. This is not solved only by talking about arsonists, as some of the deputies did here today, or as did the Spanish Minister of Agriculture, Mrs. García Tejerina. Political responsibilities must be assumed. Ladies and gentlemen, fires are the fever of a diseased territory, they are a consequence of climate change and the absence of sensible forest management policies that stop placing in the center and promoting the monoculture of eucalyptus, among other species. But it is also the consequence of a devastating economic development that leaves people out of land and livestock and forces people to abandon villages and orchards, because, as we see, this abandonment is painful insofar as it puts in it endangers the lives of people and the planet. We must make a collective reflection: more citizen participation, more value to those who care for the mountains and villages, more value to those who feed us, and more value, above all, to the most important heritage that we have as humanity, which are our mountains , our villages and our forests. Because to put out the fires, what is needed is to enliven the towns.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: - Madam President, first of all, I wish to convey my condolences to the families of the victims and, of course, condemn what happened. On October 15, Galicia and Portugal burned. In Galicia there were four deaths and 35,000 hectares burned; in Portugal, forty-three dead and 150,000 hectares burned. However, the extinction contingent was practically the same. In Galicia, two thirds of the budget is allocated to fire prevention and a third to combat. In Spain, about 2 billion euros a year are allocated to fire fighting - only the United States has an equivalent budget per inhabitant. In addition, this budget has been increased by almost 20% in 2012, and coordination with the autonomous communities and forest policy has been improved. It is not a problem for this government, as Mr. Blanco has just said - he has already left. And by the way, I remind you that, in August 2006, 110,000 hectares burned in Galicia with his party ruling Galicia and Spain. Is that not the case. In this case, however, it was not forest fires, but rather real criminal fires. Drought, wind and high temperature can explain the spread of a fire, but do not explain its onset. What is not explained is that, with all these meteorological conditions, such a number of fires would start simultaneously, at dusk and in peri-urban areas and natural spaces: this can only be intentional. I would like to end by reiterating that in Spain we are well prepared to fight fires, and the European Commission itself recognizes this. Now, fighting this type of environmental crime, which causes human tragedies, is quite another matter.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: - Madam President, in Asturias we have already had ninety-six fires in forty-one municipalities of the seventy-eight that we have. Certainly some have been provoked, but there is a political responsibility as well. One of the main causes is the poor management of the territory and public resources, neglecting, for example, the cleaning of the mountains and especially that of the firebreak strips, and also applying unacceptable labor policies to the means of extinction of fires, with intermittent temporary contracts, instead of having stable public places. And, in addition, the watchtowers have been removed. These are the consequences of the cuts. The cause is also in the policies of the Union and especially in the CAP, which have led to the depopulation of rural areas and the abandonment of the countryside and forests. Not even the people of the rural environment, already aged, can enter to clean the mountains because of the application of subsidiary rules in natural parks. Of course, when firefighters are missing, of course, the army is sent. There is money for that. Too many police and too few firefighters, Commissioner. And as if that were not enough, in our region, in Asturias, there is an open investigation also for the misuse of ERDF funds that should have been used for reforestation and cleaning the forests.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: - I am the only one who is not from the Iberian Peninsula who is speaking here now, but disasters such as this and all other forms are indeed a matter of European solidarity. It could be a flood, it could be a fire or other situations. Therefore, from that point of view, and in addition to my pity and piety towards the deceased, I would like to make a few somewhat critical comments. In the first place: for the first time - and I was somewhat shocked about that - you hear that there is a mixed form between climate change and between what is caused by citizens. I therefore think that if we provide aid - and of course we should do that, a fine proposal, Commissioner - then we should also ask for a report from the Member State on how they work in that balance between prevention, between assistance and recovery. You also said that we have created the opportunity to release 95% of European funds from the European Regional Development Fund. Part of it is already being used. We can do more, there is more space. But now I also want to know how that rural policy, that rural recovery, how that is done. That is not just short-term assistance. These are structural measures to indeed make the countryside safe for people again, and we must reclaim that. Not just offering, but also seeking a balance, as it were. Second, you say that a plan has been put forward for those first fires - we discussed that here. Now they certainly cross that threshold. Do you want to deal with this quickly and indeed finish it as soon as possible. I thank you.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, there is no doubt that you will have an ally in Parliament. Parliament has already worked with great enthusiasm in the last parliamentary term to implement this European civil protection mechanism and the natural disasters that so many Member States have faced, and continue to face, tell us that we need a stronger response. We are perfectly aware that what is there is not enough. As you said, national capabilities alone are not enough and this is demonstrated, as you recalled, by the 16 times in which the mechanism had to intervene this summer only for fires. We need to improve our ability to react, prevention and preparation must be our priorities. The European citizens are on our side, they are with us, they ask us this, they want to see more Europe here, much more Europe. I too believe that it would be a nice thing, perhaps, to have a real European civil protection mechanism, but we also know that the primary responsibility for responding to these disasters lies with the Member States, so much so that in the last legislature subsidiarity has it had to be our North Star to be able to deploy this mechanism. So I believe that, if this must and can be our goal, we must also be very pragmatic and therefore I think we should start with what you said, because we absolutely must improve quickly. Therefore, we can improve what is already in the field, we can improve cooperation between and with the Member States, we can simplify procedures, we must increase co-financing and financing instruments but above all, I repeat, we must act quickly. Good job!

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: - Madam President, an initial word, as I could not fail to do, to address the meaning of regret to the families of all those who prematurely lost their lives in Portugal and also in Spain. The loss of more than 100 lives, in these circumstances, is the case that there is no memory in Portugal. The Portuguese State failed in one of its fundamental tasks: it did not guarantee the protection of people. It is unfortunate and objectionable. Legitimized by the citizens who elected me, I could not fail to give voice to the manifest discredit of the Portuguese in the State. We need and want answers and solutions. European solidarity must be felt. The response to emergency situations must be immediate. We don't need to discuss more mechanisms. It is urgent to present the necessary remodeling in civil protection, which we have already detected is not working well. We have been discussing the importance of a European civil protection force for a decade, capable of intervening in the event of catastrophe in the community space. This is the time for the Union to show even more its ability to guarantee the protection of all European citizens.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Madam President, Portuguese and Galicians, mourning and stunned, are faced with the result of decades of poor forest management, territorial disorder, depopulation of the interior and abandonment of rural populations, capture of the State by interests and divestment prevention and civil protection, aggravated by the impact of climate change. In Portugal we already have diagnoses, expert recommendations and government decisions to support victims, reconstruct what has to be reconstructed and correct what has to be corrected. To put them into practice, we need citizens who are attentive to watch and ask for accounts; we need European solidarity, which must be, first of all, to allow the national investment effort in reconstruction and reorientation not to count towards the structural deficit; we need the quick activation of all financial aid; we need, of course, a genuine European civil protection force, with the means to get there on time; we need an attentive and intervening European Commission, because this generational challenge for Portugal and Spain is, of course, also a challenge for the entire European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, we extend our condolences to the relatives of the victims in Portugal and northern Spain. It is a given that this is a very big disaster. At the same time, the debate highlights the need for a European civil protection system, for the means to exist. And I would say, Mr. Stylianidis, that a combination could be made: to have increased funds in the Solidarity Fund and to change the conditions a little, which are quite high. There must be a catastrophe of 1.5% of GDP. There are such procedures that cover only the infrastructure. They do not cover disasters suffered by individuals or farmers. So we need a complete change of legislation at European Union level to be able to cover these catastrophes that are occurring. It should also not count on the deficit any funding given by either Portugal or Spain by national media to deal with these disasters.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, at the beginning of my speech, I would like to express my condolences to the families of the bereaved and greatly appreciate the cohesion of the people affected by this disaster. At the same time, I would like to say that I think the basic motto applies, who gives quickly, gives twice. I think that is our challenge. The European Solidarity Fund has already been modified this term, its rules for spending these funds, but I think more can be done. Firstly, to allocate more resources in this Solidarity Fund and, secondly, to be even faster and more efficient. We cannot fight criminals who set forests on fire, but we can strengthen our prevention more. I think this is very important and should be reflected in our land use and in rural governance and development. At the same time, I would like to say at the end that fire protection is a matter for individual states, but an effective response fund should be the common task of all of us.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, firstly, my sincere sympathy to my colleagues from the Iberian Peninsula on what they have suffered as a result of the forest fires in Spain and Portugal. I would also like to commend the Commissioner for his genuine affinity and empathy with those who suffered, and for his desire to help. That is as it should be, and he is portraying a very human face for what is often seen as a bureaucratic Commission. Certainly not in his case. In my own country, we had some very serious flooding recently as a result of Hurricane Ophelia, the worst storm we have had in over 50 years – followed on last week by another storm, Storm Brian. Five people were killed during that, and a huge amount of damage was done. Having discussed it with him, I know the Commissioner would like to help us, but there may be difficulties in terms of the high threshold that it takes to qualify and I think that is something we need to look at going forward. We should reduce the threshold and definitely increase the funding for the Solidarity Fund, because this is one way of really showing citizens that we care for them – especially in their hour of need.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I say to the House: dear colleagues, thank you so much for your participation and your contribution to this timely debate. I have taken very careful note of your suggestions and your proposals, which will definitely feed into my reflections and proposals to the College next month. Thank you so much for your support and your encouragement in reaching this very critical objective, namely to give to our citizens a real European response to these unprecedented natural disasters inside Europe. I would like to respond to some of your observations. First of all, as I said, we need to take a comprehensive approach. I want to come forward with proposals, not only in response to the forest fires – as I said – but also to hurricanes, earthquakes and floods. This is quite important for me. To do this we need – as I said – at least three things. I would like to stress this because it is a sort of strategic plan. First, additional financial support, to be better equipped to respond to disasters. I am sure that we all agree on this. Second, we need to put more emphasis on prevention and preparedness, with better links to the structural funds. I thank you because I saw again that we agree on this. For me, increased prevention and preparedness should be a precondition for any extra support. Finally, the third point is that we of course need to improve the efficiency of the mechanism, so that we can deploy assistance more rapidly during emergencies. This is quite important, and this why I accepted that sometimes our response was not as fast as the emergency required. My dear friends, we are not starting from zero in terms of coordinating the civil protection activities of our Member States. In my contact with the Council and our Member States through the EU Civil Protection Mechanism, some Member States are now already pre—committing capacities, such as firefighters, for rapid deployment. This is quite important. We certainly need to be able to deploy more firefighting teams when requested. This will be an important element of our work. I would also like to respond to the idea of new planes. We all agree that there are not enough planes and capacities to deal with the increasing number of forest fires. One of the objectives of the revision is to address this gap and develop additional operational capacities. We will look at all options in order to find the most efficient solution. The mandate that I received from the College, President Juncker and the Council is very clear. We must provide better support to our citizens at times of crisis and emergency, with maximum efficiency and minimum bureaucracy. As I said, we are not starting from zero in terms of coordination. The experience of the Civil Protection Mechanism is positive, but it has its shortcomings. We will therefore come forward with concrete proposals in order to deliver these rapid and tangible results on the ground, and tangible European solidarity to our citizens. So we need to be better prepared for future natural disasters and to have more capacity to respond to the next natural disaster. Time is of the essence. We should be in place to help our citizens practically. At least this is our duty as representatives of the European people. Thank you again for your support and your suggestions.

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, dear Members, after having listened to this debate all I have to say is that I am looking forward to action and to receiving proposals by the Commission – and from what I heard from Commissioner Stylianides, right now I feel quite encouraged already about the path that we have chosen in order to tackle these issues. I can reiterate that the Council will give high priority to these proposals when they come.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. - The tragedy of forest fires, which, once again, fell on Portugal, causing more than a hundred victims and material damage of a very high dimension, caused deep pain in all of us. I want to express my solidarity with the relatives of the victims of this unfortunate event that has caused absolutely irreparable losses. The European Union, through Jean-Claude Juncker, President of the European Commission, and Antonio Tajani, President of the European Parliament, has already expressed a strong solidarity with the Portuguese people. We registered these gestures, which made us very sensitive. It is now important to continue with the task of promoting integrated mechanisms at European level in the field of civil protection, in order to ensure, in the future, a more effective response to disasters with the characteristics of what has now occurred. This way, it will be possible to prevent the repetition of tragic situations like the one we just witnessed. I am sure that this will be the path chosen by the governments of the different Member States and by the other European decision-makers.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - Last week we witnessed with horror the more than 200 fires registered in Spain and Portugal, which ended up burning thousands of hectares, causing incalculable ecological damage and which ended the lives of dozens of people. In Galicia, the fires were especially numerous. The Xunta did not have an effective plan against the fires, carrying out a devastating forest policy and even firing 436 brigade members from the forestry teams, even though they knew that the risk of fires was very high, due to the unusual lack of rain. The losses, both human, material and ecological that will take decades to recover, are to blame. And much of the fault for omission lies with the Government of Galicia, the PP, which does not invest in active policies regarding fire fighting or fire prevention, something that experts consider key to ending this sad tradition of fires in our mountains every summer. And from here I want to thank the Galician people, who did not hesitate to participate heroically in extinguishing the fires, seeing that the help either did not arrive, or was totally insufficient. I also want from here to send all my support to the families who are victims of these fires.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - After the devastating fires that occurred in northern Spain and Portugal, articulated aid mechanisms from the EU are essential. The main aid mechanism is the EU Solidarity Fund, which was created to intervene in the event of serious natural catastrophes. To be effective, the damage must exceed a percentage of the GDP of the region or country in question. There are also other actions that may come into play, since around 90% of the Union funds allocated to forests come from the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), a fund that contemplates a measure to repair damage caused to forests due to fires, natural disasters and catastrophes. Regional ERDF funds and the LIFE program are another possibility. Despite this aid, we Socialists have called for the priorities of the EAFRD and the CAP to be reoriented. At the same time, we are committed to reviewing the Solidarity Fund to make it effective, increasing the funding received by the Natura Network - the LIFE program is not enough - and strengthening the Civil Protection Mechanism of the European Union.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: written. - The series of criminally arsoned fires in recent weeks have left in southern Europe, particularly Spain and Portugal, a trail of human misfortune and intolerable environmental destruction. This year alone, 750,000 hectares have been burned in the Union and more than 100 people have died from this cause. I would like to acknowledge the symbolic initiative of the President of the European Parliament, Antonio Tajani, to donate the 50,000 euros of the last Princess of Asturias concord award to the victims of the fires. I also endorse the proposals of my colleagues in Parliament to improve our civil protection mechanism against fires and to ensure that the European solidarity fund does its job more effectively. A vertebrate and united Europe cannot afford to have weak links that test its natural and human heritage so dramatically. The challenges of climate change and interested crime that have such an impact on the environment, especially in the rural world, demand not to leave the States and citizens alone. We need to move towards a common European response against environmental terrorism.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: written. - A cluster of negative circumstances caused 146 fires during the same weekend in Galicia, all of them attributable to humans. Furthermore, 2017 will be the warmest year on record, due to the undeniable greenhouse effect increased by our lifestyle dependent on fossil fuels. The abandonment of the land, low environmental awareness and the negative effects of fire as a destructive instrument do the rest. To this we add a forestry model, lacking adequate planning and based on monocultures of pyrophytes such as eucalyptus, and the disastrous regional management of means of prevention. Unconcerned about an autumn with temperatures of up to 35 ºC, and criticized by the unions, the Xunta de Galicia fired 465 brigade members who finished their contracts, just 15 days before the gloomy weekend. The environment is not perceived as a source of wealth, and this pedagogical task is an essential task for administrations. In Spain, it is the responsibility of the regional government, with full transferred environmental competencies, to assume the obligation of planning, conservation and prevention with a long-term horizon. It is unfortunate that the current fires are repeated for decades before the passivity of the administration.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. - The fires that devastated Portugal on the 14th and 15th of October caused the loss of four dozen human lives and millions of euros of material damage. In addition, they inflicted a severe blow on the Portuguese forest. In this regard, it is worth mentioning the vast burnt area, equivalent to the total recorded in Portugal in many of the previous years. These unfortunate events call for a deep discussion about the reasons, the immediate response, but also what we can do to prevent tragedies like this from recurring in the future. The possibility of establishing a European civil protection force has been increasingly suggested. Such reflection should, from now on, be welcomed, as it would be an efficient way of guaranteeing a quick and adequate response to the emergency support needs of Member States. In addition, this force is, in essence, embodying one of the Union's founding principles: solidarity. Of course, other measures must be taken. Especially because, we know, it is not enough to regret tragedies, we must avoid them. And, in the Portuguese case, this involves an effort to reorganize the forest, which will only succeed if it starts with a broad national political consensus.
